revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-16 00:59:04.000000000', 'message': 'Sync with oslo-incubator

This syncs keystone with oslo-incubator commit hash
5fa2dae429a9e37dfd1a527eb3957cea57a3e8c4

Commits since last sync (e9bb0b59):
-----------------------------------
0506d17 cfgfilter has graduated, remove it
e5c78bb log: make set_defaults() tests clean up properly
05ae498 Add JUNO as a target to versionutils module
569979a Fix tests.unit.reports.test_base_report with python3.4
e184dd3 Fix exception message in openstack.common.processutils.execute
3d90045 Backport code for i18n to check lazy at runtime
43b0df3 Updated from global requirements
ef37e03 Added missing jsonutils.dump() function
5fd77eb Ability to customize default_log_levels for each project
4d9328c Python 3: enable tests/unit/test_log.py
b8db732 Delete 'deprecated' directory
a44ad7b Allow test_lockutils to run in isolation
8b5bc62 Allow test_service to run in isolation
80284aa Mark gettextutils obsolete
d6b55fb Remove `processutils` dependency on `log`
cb5a804 Move `mask_password` to strutils
9502a21 Use the standard python logging in network_utils
3310d8d update new requests logger to default WARN
e377393 Changes calcuation of variable delay
ab5d5f1 Use timestamp in loopingcall
5c68515 Updated from global requirements
011fc27 Python 3: replace "im_self" by "__self__"
5c11c4d Don't import fcntl on Windows
33afb20 Fix broken formatting of processutils.execute log statement
6751b30 Remove extra whitespace

Change-Id: I853469f1fb5f5274ef52caaeb2d12b3164433697
Related-BP: non-persistent-tokens
'}]
commit_message:
Sync with oslo-incubator

This syncs keystone with oslo-incubator commit hash
5fa2dae429a9e37dfd1a527eb3957cea57a3e8c4

Commits since last sync (e9bb0b59):
-----------------------------------
0506d17 cfgfilter has graduated, remove it
e5c78bb log: make set_defaults() tests clean up properly
05ae498 Add JUNO as a target to versionutils module
569979a Fix tests.unit.reports.test_base_report with python3.4
e184dd3 Fix exception message in openstack.common.processutils.execute
3d90045 Backport code for i18n to check lazy at runtime
43b0df3 Updated from global requirements
ef37e03 Added missing jsonutils.dump() function
5fd77eb Ability to customize default_log_levels for each project
4d9328c Python 3: enable tests/unit/test_log.py
b8db732 Delete 'deprecated' directory
a44ad7b Allow test_lockutils to run in isolation
8b5bc62 Allow test_service to run in isolation
80284aa Mark gettextutils obsolete
d6b55fb Remove `processutils` dependency on `log`
cb5a804 Move `mask_password` to strutils
9502a21 Use the standard python logging in network_utils
3310d8d update new requests logger to default WARN
e377393 Changes calcuation of variable delay
ab5d5f1 Use timestamp in loopingcall
5c68515 Updated from global requirements
011fc27 Python 3: replace "im_self" by "__self__"
5c11c4d Don't import fcntl on Windows
33afb20 Fix broken formatting of processutils.execute log statement
6751b30 Remove extra whitespace

Change-Id: I853469f1fb5f5274ef52caaeb2d12b3164433697
Related-BP: non-persistent-tokens

commit_message:
Isolate the identity get_endpoint function

This logic is going to be needed in at least the auth_token middleware
for an identity plugin that can't be re-authenticated.

Isolate it into it's own function for re-use.

Change-Id: Iab82a33639ffebb291d48b6c840f6756f2351032

commit_message:
Avoid loading a ref from SQL to delete the ref

In the mapping_backend there is no need to load the ref just to
issue a delete, it can be handled as a single SQL query.

Change-Id: I4cec4fe5de4530d8da79e3be10e2d8fe431ed1f1

subject: Disable case-changing behavior in Eventlet
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 124, 'name': 'Kazutaka Morita', 'email': 'morita.kazutaka@gmail.com', 'username': 'morita-kazutaka'}, {'_account_id': 330, 'name': 'John Dickinson', 'email': 'me@not.mn', 'username': 'notmyname'}, {'_account_id': 597, 'name': 'Pete Zaitcev', 'email': 'zaitcev@kotori.zaitcev.us', 'username': 'zaitcev'}, {'_account_id': 2622, 'name': 'Samuel Merritt', 'email': 'sam@swiftstack.com', 'username': 'torgomatic'}, {'_account_id': 4608, 'name': 'Kota Tsuyuzaki', 'email': 'kota.tsuyuzaki.pc@hco.ntt.co.jp', 'username': 'tsuyuzaki-kota'}, {'_account_id': 5600, 'name': 'Brian Cline', 'email': 'bcline@softlayer.com', 'username': 'briancline'}, {'_account_id': 6968, 'name': 'Christian Schwede', 'email': 'cschwede@redhat.com', 'username': 'cschwede'}, {'_account_id': 7233, 'name': 'Matthew Oliver', 'email': 'matt@oliver.net.au', 'username': 'mattoliverau'}, {'_account_id': 8871, 'name': 'Elastic Recheck', 'username': 'elasticrecheck'}]

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2014-05-15 18:51:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

I don't think this belongs in Swift, but rather in the swift3 middleware."}, {'account_id': 124, 'date': '2014-05-15 19:09:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

At least, we need a new parameter "capitalize_response_headers=False" to wsgi.server in swift/common/wsgi.py.  Otherwise, Eventlet overwrites the response headers in either way, even if the swift3 middleware normalizes them.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2014-05-15 19:16:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes, that is true. A patch to disable case-changing behavior in Eventlet would be welcome; it's only the knowledge of S3-specific things in Swift that is objectionable."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2014-05-15 19:19:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Also, FWIW, I believe that Apache lower-cases all headers unconditionally, so it might be worth investigating a similar fix for Swift-in-Apache. (In a separate patch, of course. I don't want to expand the scope of this patch to include Apache stuff too.)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-15 19:46:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

I'll need to look at this again once I've had some more sleep, but it doesn't have any Amazon-isms in it any more, so I'll remove my -2.

Thanks for the fix."}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2014-05-16 17:30:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Aww, I expected a new unit test with "FOo" and "Foo" for success and failure cases, but there's none.'}, {'account_id': 124, 'date': '2014-05-30 06:06:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Pete,

What this patch does is just turning off the Eventlet's feature.  Should we
have a unit test for that?  Eventlet capitalizes a response header outside of
the Swift proxy app.  It sounds like there is no chance for Swift unittest to
check the returned header to clients.  In addition, Swift proxy never returns a
header name like 'FOo' without swift3.

Eventlet already has a unit test for the header capitalization feature, and
Swift3 project will also have a functional test for that.  I guess there is no
need for Swift to have the test too."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-30 06:06:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Verified

[{'created': '2014-05-15 18:43:16.000000000', 'message': "Normalize response headers as S3 clients expect

RFC 2616 says that HTTP header fields are case-insensitive.  However, there are
some clients who don't accept headers normalized by Swift.  For example, AWS
Java SDK expects that a etag header is 'ETag', not 'Etag'.

This patch normalizes Swift response headers as those clients expect.  Note
that this change requires a fix for Eventlet, which will be included in the
next Eventlet release (v0.15).

commit_message:
Disable case-changing behavior in Eventlet

RFC 2616 says that HTTP header fields are case-insensitive.  However, there are
some S3 clients who don't accept normalized header by Swift and Eventlet.  For
example, AWS Java SDK expects that an etag header is 'ETag', not 'Etag'.

This patch disables Eventlet's header capitalization so that the swift3
middleware can normalize the response headers as those clients expect.

Note that this change requires a fix for Eventlet, which will be included in
the next Eventlet release (v0.15).

Change-Id: I6d3428b0dafef776bdb3ebac7639b3126fa5e60d

[{'created': '2014-07-17 00:36:59.000000000', 'message': "Change help string related to router's distributed attribute

This is currently supported by the NSX plugin and the ML2 one
(only on OVS/VxLAN). Since the compat matrix is inevitably
subject to change, we are better off dropping the list of
supported plugins in the help string and rely on external
documentation where we specify which technologies do support
the ability to distribute routers.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I9f71b731e5de07712daf0bb9db5aa6c663663c8c
Supports-blueprint: neutron-ovs-dvr
"}]
commit_message:
Change help string related to router's distributed attribute

This is currently supported by the NSX plugin and the ML2 one
(only on OVS/VxLAN). Since the compat matrix is inevitably
subject to change, we are better off dropping the list of
supported plugins in the help string and rely on external
documentation where we specify which technologies do support
the ability to distribute routers.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I9f71b731e5de07712daf0bb9db5aa6c663663c8c
Supports-blueprint: neutron-ovs-dvr

commit_message:
Freeze models for healing migration

Take a snapshot of all models from the code base at the time when the
healing migration merges. The healing migration needs this frozen view
of the models to be available (even as the models change in the future)
to compare with the current DB schema. The healing migration will use
this comparison to heal the schema.

partially implement bp: db-migration-refactor

Change-Id: I438147c7961b1ecad47f6146cc7fc9396aee7bc5

Build succeeded.

- gate-heat-templates-dsvm http://logs.openstack.org/59/106159/1/check/gate-heat-templates-dsvm/39312df : FAILURE in 13m 47s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2014-07-14 15:09:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Looks good - as a future enhancement, it would be nice to move towards all-native resources, e.g replace the AWS SecurityGroup resource with the neutron one, and either migrate to SoftwareDeployment resources or use the native WaitCondition resource I'm currently working on (the former would probably be best, if possible)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-14 15:09:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-14 15:32:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-heat-templates-dsvm http://logs.openstack.org/59/106159/1/check/gate-heat-templates-dsvm/4d674a3 : FAILURE in 18m 32s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2014-07-14 23:15:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

Looks great Jeff!

I have a bunch of ideas for directions this could be improved in the future to take advantage of new features in Icehouse, which I'll collect here for posterity (we should absolutely go ahead and merge this though).

* Place nodes in an autoscaling group with the node template as the scaling unit.
* Define the user data script for the broker in a separate file retrieved using the get_file intrinsic function
* Use software deployments to configure brokers

It would be interesting if that + maybe DNSaaS support were sufficient to enable us to put the brokers in an autoscaling group too (or if not, to find out why not).

A couple of micronits inline. I'm not clear on whether support for Havana is an explicit goal here; if so then just ignore the second one."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-16 05:05:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add HA templates to deploy OpenShift on CentOS

These templates are heavily based on the existing OpenShift enterprise
templates for use with RHEL. The OpenShift installer utilized in these
templates has been slightly modified to support CentOS as well as make
the install completely automated (aside from creating districts if so
desired.)

Change-Id: I74acfdd553eb6a4c7ac771b6c0ec6543e1e63ea9

commit_message:
Add API schema for v2.1/v3 create_backup API

By defining the API schema, it is possible to separate the validation
code from the API method. The API method can be more simple.
In addition, a response of API validation error can be consistent for
the whole Nova API.

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-schema

Change-Id: Ie8a1ce6d0d7b90fb73555981fa974e9029344d3b

commit_message:
Add API schema for v2.1/v3 migrate_server API

By defining the API schema, it is possible to separate the validation
code from the API method. The API method can be more simple.
In addition, a response of API validation error can be consistent for
the whole Nova API.

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-schema

commit_message:
Add API schema for v2.1/v3 attach_interfaces API

By defining the API schema, it is possible to separate the validation
code from the API method. The API method can be more simple.
In addition, a response of API validation error can be consistent for
the whole Nova API.

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-schema

Change-Id: I0c4066c34f6da0934946aa9eda907b911dbede16

[{'account_id': 6786, 'date': '2014-02-02 21:23:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

We don't needed as stubs based on current Flask REST API. We should use Pecan/WSME to build v2 API."}, {'account_id': 7555, 'date': '2014-02-02 21:36:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

more important than the stubs here are the calls we're defining. please review the api, not the stubs.

we should not block forward progress on the stable v2 api on decisions about changing framework implementations.

re pecan/wsme - i'm not opposed to looking at another framework, but it's lower priority for me compared to providing the stable v2 api. we can always convert from flask to pecan/wsme during the actual implementation, or even after."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-02-02 21:44:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

commit_message:
Create v2 API structure

This is the proposed structure for the v2 API. It is not necessarily
complete and has no implementation. It serves as the foundation of the
v2 API.

Implements: blueprint v2-api
Change-Id: I7265c4ca325fbecd6141b8dbe555a2d7f786e1ba

commit_message:
Create an empty stack when creating the pipeline

When Heat creates a stack it needs to create a trust,
at the moment this can't be done in the context of a mistral task as
a trust token is passed into the task and creating a trust
from a trust token is not currently allowed.

This patch is a workaround to create the Heat stack with
a "normal" user token. Then the mistral task will only
do a stack update, which can be done with a trust token.

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/solum/+spec/pipeline
Change-Id: I23ce79761e3ebcd46cfbef810330ff6b7c9bde4e

commit_message:
Prevent excessive keystone client connections

Try and reuse the keystone client object by creating it in the
pipeline handler constructor.

Change-Id: If4fb4258779c128df96826cd855ba09f63ad35bb

[{'created': '2014-07-11 07:16:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add spec for retargetable functional testing

This spec proposes the addition of support for retargetable
functional testing.  Retargetable tests are intended to be written
to an abstract client interface that can have multiple backends,
allowing an API test to be written that can be run against the
plugin API and a Neutron service with minimal extra effort.

bp retargetable-functional-testing

Change-Id: I1aa1e147012f853d3c192de80505e6ce0d50b5c4
'}]
commit_message:
Add spec for retargetable functional testing

This spec proposes the addition of support for retargetable
functional testing.  Retargetable tests are intended to be written
to an abstract client interface that can have multiple backends,
allowing an API test to be written that can be run against the
plugin API and a Neutron service with minimal extra effort.

bp retargetable-functional-testing

Change-Id: I1aa1e147012f853d3c192de80505e6ce0d50b5c4

[{'created': '2014-06-02 16:07:26.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce neutron:config to manage neutron configuration

This neutron::config is aim to use all types of neutron
config resources to manage custom configurations in all
neutron config files.
This will make end user easy to add their own custom options
in Hiera data.

Fully implements blueprint neutron-custom-config

(cherry-picked from e420021699f5fd0b5b13cbf8b070070ba8e03b9b)
Change-Id: I2a6b79a48f011c84a8b73467c9bf813741f6e898
'}]
commit_message:
Introduce neutron:config to manage neutron configuration

This neutron::config is aim to use all types of neutron
config resources to manage custom configurations in all
neutron config files.
This will make end user easy to add their own custom options
in Hiera data.

Fully implements blueprint neutron-custom-config

(cherry-picked from e420021699f5fd0b5b13cbf8b070070ba8e03b9b)
Change-Id: I2a6b79a48f011c84a8b73467c9bf813741f6e898

I think this usecase can be resolved by let Firewall policy uses another Firewall policy.
IMO, firewall policy is a grouping of firewall rules, right?
Also, service-group in this bp is actually grouping of firewall rules.
so if we can composite firewall policy, we can accomplish this use case. 

- Usecase should be added.
  I understand the usecase of this bp, but I think we need explicit usecase section in this one.

- Naming sounds like too general
service-group & service-object sounds like really general name. However service object is almost same with firewall rule.'}, {'account_id': 10041, 'date': '2014-07-14 20:36:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Nachi,
Thank you for review.
I will add new use case as you have request.

For the service group/object naming there are two reasons:
1. the service group/object naming really came from the fact that many vendors using it (PAN, Jnpr and netscreen). And even unix is also grouping the protocol/ports into /etc/services
2. During the Hongkong summit, some developers asked to make the service group as  a common resource than FWaaS resource.

The other names I can think of are:
layer4-service-group,
l4-service-group,
transport-service-group.

Please let me know which one is more preferable.

commit_message:
Service group and service object for FWaaS
blueprint fwaas-customized-service

In the traditional firewall design a service is used to define type of traffic
in firewall. This blueprint creates an extension that allows the firewall
administrators to create customized service objects. The customized service
objects can be grouped together to form a service group object. The policy
rule of FWaaS can reference more than one type of traffic by referencing to
service group objects.

Change-Id: I7a05799a2f8e51438852267cd62d1030ae74ceab

commit_message:
Add spec for removal of autodeletion in tests

This spec proposes the removal of autodeletion of Neutron resources
in the unit test suite.

bp remove-unit-test-autodeletion

Change-Id: Ifbf839d442d658ad74c14fdfde3dd685f9bc9775

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be

    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also

    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2014-03-28 13:47:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

One comment inline, also, one comment from https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/add-bootable-option whiteboard that need to be addressed:

1. >>$ cinder create --bootable true 10
This means you are creating a new cinder volume and setting bootable to true, which is wrong, and misleading. For most cases, a newly created cinder volume will never be bootable to begin with. So with this there exists a time window where the volume is not yet bootable, but has bootable=true. For the scenarios you mentioned, isn't it more appropriate to have somethign like cinder update --bootable true <volid> whcih the user can *after* the OS is installed and/or volume is made bootable ?

(Not sure who made it, but it is a good point)

Also, do we copy over the glace metadata in the case we make a bootable volume using block-device-mapping syntax? If not, is that a problem? Seems like an easy way to bypass licensed images and such if we don't copy it over.


Thanks for looking at this though, there is a clear need for this work."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-03-28 14:42:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Add set-bootable command

Bootable Status is set to "True" automatically when user
create a volume from a image. But user have to set bootable
status manually when creating a bootable volume manually.

blueprint add-bootable-option

this commit is related to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/84057/

Change-Id: Ib4a44334001b7b9e3b896c2e44607c414e75e952

commit_message:
Remove definition of Python Source Code Encodings

The definition of Python Source Code Encodings is no longer needed.
This patch remove those.

Change-Id: I3eebb245e9e41b92c9ec82ebbd2dd6b417704819

I put my comment about the overall approach in the commit message. I'd like to revisit the idea and know what you think about it."}, {'account_id': 7448, 'date': '2014-04-28 16:02:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

Assaf, your idea is a good one.  I have been thinking about your comment and I do appreciate your feedback.  You spotted some very important mistakes in PS 8 that I hadn't yet had time to work through because this patch had been on the back shelf for so long.  For that, I'm very grateful.

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-03-07 00:09:50.000000000', 'message': "L3 agent gives preference to processing RPC messages over full sync (WIP)

Please provide feedback on this approach to solving the bug before I
commit too much more work on it.

This is a preview.  It is far from complete.  Here, I propose
combining the work from _rpc_loop and _sync_routers_task in to a
single loop that I call _process_routers_loop.  This loop has worker
threads that pull from a priority queue.  The queue ensures that RPC
messages are handled before maintenance tasks.

With multiple worker threads, I needed to handled the case where an
RPC message came in while a thread was working on a router.  We don't
want another thread to handle the same router.  Instead, I add a
mechanism to single to the working thread that an update came in for
the router it is working on.

Closes-Bug: #1289066
Change-Id: I39afe86c66f864d71adf865d7bd1c9db35511505
"}, {'created': '2014-03-18 00:01:21.000000000', 'message': "L3 agent gives preference to processing RPC messages over full sync (WIP)

This is a checkpoint that I want to get up for feedback.  There is
more work to do.

Here, I propose combining the work from _rpc_loop and
_sync_routers_task in to a single loop that I call
_process_routers_loop.  This loop has worker threads that pull from a
priority queue.  The queue ensures that RPC messages are handled
before maintenance tasks.

With multiple worker threads, I needed to handled the case where an
RPC message came in while a thread was working on a router.  We don't
want another thread to handle the same router.  I add a mechanism to
single to the working thread that an update came in for the router it
is working on.

Closes-Bug: #1289066
Change-Id: I39afe86c66f864d71adf865d7bd1c9db35511505
"}, {'created': '2014-03-23 05:45:21.000000000', 'message': "L3 agent prefers RPC messages over full sync

Combine the work from _rpc_loop and _sync_routers_task in to a single loop
called _process_routers_loop.  This loop spawns threads that pull from a
priority queue.  The queue ensures that RPC messages are handled before
_process_routers_loop.  The latter is generally maintenance tasks
triggered by the agent rather than user triggered tasks.

Synchronization between RPC and sync routers loops is no longer
necessary since they both feed in to a single queue.  There were
places where it was necessary to reorder some things to allow for the
lack of synchronization.  For example, it is necessary to list
namespaces before fetching the full list of routers to ensure that it
doesn't delete a new namespace that gets created after listing
namespaces.  The lack of then need for synchronization between loops
is probably the main strength of this patch.

With multiple worker threads, need to handle the case where an RPC
message came in while a thread was working on a router.  Another
thread should not handle the same router that is already in progress.
Adds a mechanism to signal to the working thread that an update came
in for the router it is working on.  The original thread will repeat
processing the router when it is finished to get the update.
Multiple rapid updates to the same router will be consolidated.
Essentially, there is still synchronization of work for a given router
but not between routers.  Much better than before.

Closes-Bug: #1289066
Change-Id: I39afe86c66f864d71adf865d7bd1c9db35511505

commit_message:
L3 agent prefers RPC messages over full sync

When the L3 agent starts up and runs the sync task it doesn't process
any incoming RPC events until the sync task is complete.

This change combines the work from _rpc_loop and _sync_routers_task in
to a single loop called _process_routers_loop.  This loop spawns
threads that pull from a priority queue.  The queue ensures that RPC
messages are handled before _process_routers_loop.  The latter is
generally maintenance tasks triggered by the agent rather than user
triggered tasks.

Synchronization between RPC and sync routers loops is no longer
necessary since they both feed in to a single queue.  There were
places where it was necessary to reorder some things to allow for the
lack of synchronization.  For example, it is necessary to list
namespaces before fetching the full list of routers to ensure that it
doesn't delete a new namespace that gets created after listing
namespaces.  The lack of the need for synchronization between loops is
probably the main strength of this patch.

With multiple worker threads, need to handle the case where an RPC
message came in while a thread was working on a router.  Another
thread should not handle the same router that is already in progress.
Adds a mechanism to signal to the working thread that an update came
in for the router it is working on.  The original thread will repeat
processing the router when it is finished to get the update.
Multiple rapid updates to the same router will be consolidated.
Essentially, there is still synchronization of work for a given router
but not between routers.  Much better than before.

blueprint l3-agent-responsiveness
Closes-Bug: #1289066
Change-Id: I39afe86c66f864d71adf865d7bd1c9db35511505

commit_message:
Rename to monasca, setup for tox, removed legacy bits

Removed manual tests which are no longer valid with a modern mini-mon
Removed debian creation bits all distribution is with pypi now
Minor pep8 fixes

Change-Id: I1f2fc4d0ad6375f4c39446f9627247945066e4ad

This patch is part of the larger initiative to move rendering logic to clientside. As demonstrated here, it can be achieve in 3 easy steps:

1. Inherit JSONTableMixin in your view and specify an encoder class.
2. Define a data-binding template (can even include scripts).
3. Reference this template in your table by overriding template.

commit_message:
Angularize admin flavors table

This patch is part of the larger initiative to move rendering logic to clientside. As demonstrated here, it can be achieve in 3 easy steps:

1. Inherit JSONTableMixin in your view and specify an encoder class.
2. Define a data-binding template (can even include scripts).
3. Reference this template in your table by overriding template.

Change-Id: I02779d0b7c279d37a81666115e4a340b3a705a89
Implements: blueprint table-client-rendering

commit_message:
Use auth_token from keystonemiddleware

The auth_token middleware in python-keystoneclient is now
deprecated and has been moved to keystonemiddleware.

Closes-Bug: #1342274

Change-Id: Ic8ba2d2f470ec052ba13c3b63b26d5e2270f7412

This really doesn't seem to warrant a backport based on the stable branch maintenance policy:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/StableBranch

It's also a bit misleading IMO because the bug referenced was actually a problem where the volume would be put in an error_deleting state because the case of the volume being open etc.  The logging level was added later after the actual fix of catching the exception, handling and re-raising (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/60105/3/cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py)

It just doesn't seem like it's really backport material or that it's even related to the bug referenced in the commit message, let alone a bug at all."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-12 01:52:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

commit_message:
Change RBD delete failure log level to warn

This is a recoverable issue in the backend, so we don't have to provide
the message on the error level.

Change-Id: I35711876b2c088ad28f32abd39248dc9a467d00d
Closes-Bug: #1256259

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-06-30 14:16:22.000000000', 'message': "Fixed wrong assertion in test_vmops.py

There is wrong assert method in
nova.tests.virt.vmwareapi.vmwareapi.test_vmops.py:640
while checking a number of calls mocked method 'mkdir'.

We should use assertEqual(3, len(mock_mkdir.mock_calls))
instead of self.assertTrue(3, len(mock_mkdir.mock_calls))

But number of calling method 'mkdir' not always is 3.
If dict block_device_info contains key 'block_device_mapping'
with any information, method 'mkdir' wouldn't be called in method
self._vmops.spawn(). That is why corresponding check been added.

Change-Id: Ifc26e112b9c2974e0fb7a91ba39d5b2d887bd549
Closes-Bug: #1335859
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed wrong assertion in test_vmops.py

There is wrong assert method in
nova.tests.virt.vmwareapi.vmwareapi.test_vmops.py:640
while checking a number of calls mocked method 'mkdir'.

We should use assertEqual(3, len(mock_mkdir.mock_calls))
instead of self.assertTrue(3, len(mock_mkdir.mock_calls))

But number of calling method 'mkdir' not always is 3.
If dict block_device_info contains key 'block_device_mapping'
with any information, method 'mkdir' wouldn't be called in method
self._vmops.spawn(). That is why corresponding check been added.

Change-Id: Ifc26e112b9c2974e0fb7a91ba39d5b2d887bd549
Closes-Bug: #1335859

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow"}, {'account_id': 11614, 'date': '2014-05-26 14:16:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-26 14:16:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add -s option for neutron metering rules

While adding iptables rule, cidr is added as destination for both ingress
and egress directions. Modified code to add -s for egress and -d for ingress.

Closes-bug: 1310589

Change-Id: Id9ca10855e6527d4bec689f8f9bcd6f681221954

first there is a bp reduce-flake8-ignored-rules you could mention

and second, more importatnt - this needs a *very* careful testing. Some packages, including eventlet, can raise BaseExeption, which is not caught by "except Exception:", but is caught by bare "except:". So you need to be completely sure that there no BaseException is might ever be raised in those places you changed (most concirning places for me are scheduler and locks which do use eventlet). I tried once to dif through enebling this rule but failed to get a complete understanding :('}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2014-06-26 11:38:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

- check-devstack-dsvm-cells http://logs.openstack.org/78/102778/4/check/check-devstack-dsvm-cells/017f66a : SUCCESS in 14m 43s'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2014-07-09 16:48:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Some inline comments.

TBH I'm not really sure that this check is providing any value, given that "except BaseException:" is equally bad for swallowing exit exceptions. Whether it's bad or not depends only on what you do with the exception, not how you catch it, and that's not something PEP8 can check for.

If that were the whole story I would probably be inclined to go ahead (that's a real bug you fixed in nova_utils!). Technically, "except:" is _not_ the same as "except BaseException:" though. There are actually exceptions this can miss:

  >>> try:
  ...   class OldStyle: pass
  ...   raise OldStyle
  ... except Exception:
  ...   print 'Caught Exception'
  ... except BaseException:
  ...   print 'Caught BaseException'
  ... except:
  ...   print 'Uh oh...'
  ... 
  Uh oh...

So this change is introducing semantic wrongness in exchange for passing an arbitrary linter check that is orthogonal to the dangerous thing we actually want to prevent. I'm not convinced that is a good trade off.

Maybe it would be better to add the "## noqa" comment to the legitimate uses of "except:" in resource.py, scheduler.py and stack_lock.py.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-09 16:48:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Verified

Personally, I think this check is a little valuable:

- explicit exceptions catching is a good code style. which is
  friendly to code reader
- use "except:..." will catch all exception,include
  KeyboardInterrupt and SystemExit e.g. that will disable
  ctrl+c to kill process and others effection.

yes, this work should be careful, your suggestion will be done :)

- check-devstack-dsvm-cells http://logs.openstack.org/78/102778/6/check/check-devstack-dsvm-cells/8a02e33 : SUCCESS in 15m 23s'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2014-07-10 22:34:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)

- explicit exceptions catching is a good code style. which is
friendly to code reader

IMHO good style is code that does what it says.

  except:

says that it catches all exceptions, and it does.

  except BaseException:

appears to say that it catches all exceptions, but actually (in Python 2) may miss some.

 - use "except:..." will catch all exception,include
KeyboardInterrupt and SystemExit e.g. that will disable
ctrl+c to kill process and others effection.

As will "except BaseException:". So what is gained by changing it? It's completely orthogonal to the real problem.

This is safe:

  except:
      raise

This is unsafe:

  except BaseException:
      pass

yet PEP8 says the opposite.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2014-07-10 22:41:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8290, 'date': '2014-07-11 02:11:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)

Yeah, you are right, I was wrong, for the safe of code, maybe some  "except:" should be reserved and use " # noqa" to skip the check.

thanks very much!'}, {'account_id': 8290, 'date': '2014-07-11 02:19:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-11 02:19:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
Fix H201 violations and re-enable gating

H201 got stricter in hacking 0.9, so fix new violations and
re-enable gating.

Change-Id: Ie79b04bc1ae2d4784318c19661584d02b7bee088
Implements: blueprint reduce-flake8-ignore-rules

commit_message:
Fixed configuring instances for Vanilla 2.0

Fixed configuring instances and starting services using threaded
SSH command for Vanilla Hadoop 2.0.

Change-Id: I2357f72762a3a73adb42208fe64a835cffa5716b
Closes-bug: #1324289

Note to reviewers - automatic deletion via context managers is problematic from the perspective of both performance and complexity and will hopefully be going away this cycle.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2014-07-01 02:52:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

There is also suggestion/effort underway to not perform implicit deletes. I would recommend that this change be reconciled with that effort. See the comments from the reviewers kevinbenton and marun in this patch:

I think this patch is ready to go, but I have some comments:

- Regarding the unrelated removal of a unnecessary comment, I don't recommend doing mixing changes as a general rule and would encourage splitting patches up as much as necessary to ensure coherency.

- Try if at all possible to avoid mixing rebases with changes requested by a reviewer.  It would be better to submit changes and then rebase, so a reviewer can verify the requested changes without having to sift through rebase noise.  It's also helpful to identify each rebase patch with a comment so a reviewer can treat it accordingly.  I see that has been done on some patches but consistency of practice is important."}, {'account_id': 7293, 'date': '2014-07-15 07:25:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2014-07-15 17:31:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I agree with both of your comments. Regarding the 2nd one it's because I use git review which rebases by default - I'll have to improve my workflow."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2014-07-16 01:47:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-16 01:47:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: -Verified

commit_message:
Change all occurences of no_delete to do_delete

Previously, ports, networks and subnets had a do_delete=True
parameter. By default, these resources were deleted at the
end of the context manager scope. All other resources used
a different semantic: no_delete=False.

This caused confusing situations such as:
with self.subnet(network, do_delete=False) as subnet:
    with self.security_group(no_delete=True) as sg:
        pass

Now all resources use the same do_delete semantic.

Closes-Bug: #1336196
Change-Id: I4627481813f714819efe85831e2a55975ea71ed4

commit_message:
Set default repos/puppets for releases

Since Fuel 5.1 repos/puppets paths are sent by Nailgun to Astute.
So we need to set defaults here, and remove them from Astute in
order to make our code more clear and centralized.

Closes-Bug: #1342168
Change-Id: Id0917d1044824879d348cf1ff2f8fa1588d716fb

I guess I wonder if changing something like this, sort of a "title" in the logs could impact other folks who may already have tools for log parsing that are going to have to change now and wonder "what the heck did this change for?" kinda thing. That's a very good point! I didn't consider that. 

From an end users point of view, the binaries are called swift-object-* so having a object-* name in the logs makes sense. But I didn't take into account all the existing swift clusters and existing log reporting that is out there. 

I think this requires additional thought! Changing my vote to 0 until a consensus can be made."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-03 00:14:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

I had considered that as well. From an OCD point of view, consistency is good, but not breaking existing clusters is better. My gut feeling is that anyone looking at the user agent string is more interested in requests coming from the proxy server (And the documentation of the logs at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/logs.html#storage-node-logs only mentioning the proxy server would possibly agree with that), or requests going to the proxy server.

If there is enough doubt about changing the user agent string, that is probably enough to justify an explicit unit test of the current behavior. Right now, the tests that cought the change only incidentally did so, and only for some of the services.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2014-07-03 01:10:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

It does not appear that, aside from the user-agent string, the strings
"obj-server", "obj-updater", or "obj-replicator" (or "obj-<anything>"*)
appear in the swift code base, aside from the directory containing the
object services code being named "obj".

user-agent string, as reported in the logs, using their full name. In
addition, this full name also shows up as the name of the process via
"ps" or "top", etc., which can make it easier for admins to match log
entries with other tools.

prefix rather than "obj-" in its user agent string.

code.

commit_message:
Object services user-agent string uses full name

It does not appear that, aside from the user-agent string, the strings
"obj-server", "obj-updater", or "obj-replicator" (or "obj-<anything>"*)
appear in the swift code base, aside from the directory containing the
object services code being named "obj".

Furthermore, the container, account, and proxy services construct their
user-agent string, as reported in the logs, using their full name. In
addition, this full name also shows up as the name of the process via
"ps" or "top", etc., which can make it easier for admins to match log
entries with other tools.

For consistency, we update the object services to use an "object-"
prefix rather than "obj-" in its user agent string.

* obj-etag does appear in a unit test, but not part of the regular
code.

Change-Id: I914fc189514207df2535731eda10cb4b3d30cc6c

commit_message:
Use direct mount for puppet docker container

Relies on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/107314/

Removing workaround for mount of /etc/puppet
to /puppet, then ln -s /puppet/{files} into
/etc/puppet, because it breaks upgrade schema
where /etc/puppet/$VER is added.

Change-Id: I31470af079bc88ae4303dc511bfe2b1c1c9c2fed
Partial-Bug: #1339688
(cherry picked from commit 8b658b11be66afea92acbe362064aa5ee41de22a)

[{'created': '2014-04-24 07:00:31.000000000', 'message': 'Container PUT requests and max container per account

If container counter per account is equal or greater than
max_container_per_account, then all PUT requests are failed and
403 is returned.
This is correct behaviour if the request is to create a new
container, however if container already exists PUT should be
allowed, even the max_container_per_account condition has met.

This patch allows to process PUT requests for existing containers,
even if max_container_per_account > = container count.

It indirectly resolve the bug 1306711, since swift-client
uses internally PUT requests for container, prior it upload an
object there.

Change-Id: I2dcf20b6feb27e346111466a565695eba4b4b1da

commit_message:
Container PUT requests and max container per account

If container counter per account is equal or greater than
max_container_per_account, then all PUT requests are failed and
403 is returned.
This is correct behaviour if the request is to create a new
container, however if container already exists PUT should be
allowed, even the max_container_per_account condition has met.

This patch allows to process PUT requests for existing containers,
even if max_container_per_account > = container count.

It indirectly resolve the bug 1306711, since swift-client
uses internally PUT requests for container, prior it upload an
object there.

Change-Id: I2dcf20b6feb27e346111466a565695eba4b4b1da

commit_message:
libvirt: Add configdrive support to LXC

Adds a new configdrive type called 'fs' which allows us to support
configdrive within an LXC guest.

Moves that configdrive directory into the guests rootfs on spawn, avoiding the
need for a bind-mount.

Closes-Bug: 1340834

Change-Id: I44d77525ed7acdf34e8f67d0df2b5f1f0076aa20

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow"}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2014-06-13 20:15:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Fix mistral's service_type

Mistral's service type has been changed to "workflow"
(from "workflow_service") to be more consistent with the
other OpenStack service types.

Change-Id: Ia9a6aa70fd28ee1b7af700480ac71021fd806f49

commit_message:
Enable hacking check H104

* [H104] Files with no code shouldn’t contain any license
         header nor comments, and must be left completely empty.

Change-Id: Ic02858615833b516fd2c68a859146c8e018ae8e1

commit_message:
Make all nodes appear in mysql-wss config

* New Galera requires all nodes in the config
* Remove unused galera_final_config class

Closes-Bug: 1342128

Change-Id: I47eabb0e5272bb8fdeac5fcd8d8173d9ce106202

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

Use explicit loops instead of list comprehensions

Changes only the places where list comprehensions were used instead of loops
and their return values were not used

commit_message:
Specification for Firewall Services on Cisco CSR1kv

Specification addresses the Cisco CSR1kv Service Plugin and
associated Agent design.

Implements: blueprint fwaas-cisco

Change-Id: I014a472082d7efb03c103fd2e324a1e2361c3867

Use auth_token from keystonemiddleware

auth_token middleware in python-keystoneclient is deprecated and has
been moved to the keystonemiddleware repo.

commit_message:
Add validate_log_translations flake8 check

This check ensures all logging calls outside of the tests are
translated. Regex copied from nova/hacking/checks.py.

Change-Id: Ib2250a4f43a1f9fa4e0d01ba7c9195907afc9c31

commit_message:
Building Cloudera hadoop images with Cloudera Manager

* Add element hadoop-cloudera to install Cloudera hadoop packages
* Edit diskimage-create script to build Cloudera images

Partial implements blueprint cdh-plugin

Change-Id: I0368eb12a6c06c8fc900c0f9cca94758437de1df

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-11 19:14:26.000000000', 'message': 'Add compute feature attach_volume

Allow support for specifying if volume attachment is supported.
Default behavior will match existing behavior (assumes it IS
supported).

The api.volume.test_volumes_actions test class was modified to
not create a test instance in the setUp call. This is to prevent
needless instance creation if a test is skipped, thus speeding
up testing.

Change-Id: Icf57589a8dcd914a45aff9072de4b669c359b392
'}]
commit_message:
Add compute feature attach_volume

Allow support for specifying if volume attachment is supported.
Default behavior will match existing behavior (assumes it IS
supported).

The api.volume.test_volumes_actions test class was modified to
not create a test instance in the setUp call. This is to prevent
needless instance creation if a test is skipped, thus speeding
up testing.

Change-Id: Icf57589a8dcd914a45aff9072de4b669c359b392

commit_message:
clean up saio env. after runnning func tests

Added call to delete container in teardown_package().
Tests are leaving objects and containers in saio environment
after finishing running the tests.

Currently, delete_containers() is called in the setUp of each test
class, which cleans up the containers of the previous test,
but leaves the containers of the last test in the saio environment.

Change-Id: I643d7083a2a310fc3d24eab48c565f3798cff25f
Signed-off-by: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-11 05:14:32.000000000', 'message': "Move title length check after name check

Don't check the number of titles in the spec until
after the individual sections are checked for. This
makes it easier to find which section is missing
by having an assertIn failure for the name instead
of an assertEqual failure on the length.

Change-Id: I0761c0a2f70d53c7be204ef76d7256902f900caa
"}]
commit_message:
Move title length check after name check

Don't check the number of titles in the spec until
after the individual sections are checked for. This
makes it easier to find which section is missing
by having an assertIn failure for the name instead
of an assertEqual failure on the length.

Change-Id: I0761c0a2f70d53c7be204ef76d7256902f900caa

The Brocade/Vyatta folks have similar requirements here [1]. Do you think there is overlap worth addressing in a common way between these BPs?

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/101052/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-23 01:53:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-neutron-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/71/91071/11/check/gate-neutron-specs-python27/5d9a2ab : SUCCESS in 1m 00s
- gate-neutron-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/71/91071/11/check/gate-neutron-specs-docs/925734e/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 38s'}, {'account_id': 162, 'date': '2014-06-23 09:48:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Yes, I'm aware of their work/implementation (and vice versa). While the end result is similar I'd say the overlap is more limited in the details. I consider both of these implementations as gap fillers to have something for Juno. 

In the bigger picture, the router service plugin must be evolved to be properly modular (and given the efforts on DVR, HA, service ports, and flavor framework this is realistically not feasible for Juno). In my view, some of what is needed is:
- Change the l3_db code to adopt the new service port construct so that router ports are better modeled/represented
- Adopt the flavor (or whatever) framework to make the service plugin support drivers, with one driver for the "legacy" namespace routers, another driver for distributed routers, yet other drivers for vendor technology-based routers.

It makes more sense to migrate the Brocade/Vyatta and the Cisco implementations to such changes once they are in place. Those migrations can also include adoption of functionality from the service VM efforts.

But in order to achieve something useable for Juno I think vendor independent router service plugins is the only feasible option.'}, {'account_id': 162, 'date': '2014-07-06 22:46:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-06 22:46:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I'm inclined to approve this for Juno-3, based on the fact this has been out for review for quite a while and there are dependent vendor service plugins which require this. As long as it doesn't touch core Neutron code that much, it should be ok."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-14 22:40:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Verified+1

Bob, one comment I have here: Are there any scale numbers you could post in the spec? I'd be curious if there are limits on the number of tenants supported per CSR for the services you plan to run there."}, {'account_id': 162, 'date': '2014-07-15 08:11:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Thanks Kyle!

I will now work on chopping the code patch into smaller pieces and finish tempest for CSR.

As for number of tenants per CSR we'll only support one tenant per CSR VM instance in the code patch submitted to Gerrit. Furthermore, we also limit the number of Neutron routers in one CSR VM instance to one. This is to reduce the size of the code patch. In addition to the Neutron router there can also be firewall instance and VPN instance in one CSR VM instance, initially probably just one of each to reduce code patch sizes. 

I'll update the spec with that information."}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2014-07-15 18:23:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

commit_message:
Describes design of router service plugin for Cisco devices.

- Instantiates Neutron router in a Cisco CSR1kv device.

commit_message:
Don't use oslo's _sanitize_default

This method disappeared from oslo, so provide our own sanitizer. This is
needed for now but can be removed as soon as projects provide
Opts.sample_default values.

Change-Id: I13e76c75a74667fa9bd3c779a6cf45d0281ed680
Closes-Bug: #1341250

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Gives clearer definition of a Linux Bridge

Linux bridge doesn't behave like a hub, it behaves like a switch.

Change-Id: I07a9d528f7a250ad00e7d728fb67c08230a5bf3c
Closes-Bug: 1342619

commit_message:
Enable hacking check H104

* [H104] Files with no code shouldn’t contain any license
         header nor comments, and must be left completely empty.

Change-Id: Ia9006dbf9d3d2f9d4037a428681c3cee929a8e36

commit_message:
Handle keyboard interrupt in task run

Currently cancelling task does not handle keyboard
interrupts. This fix is to add the exception and
abort the task.

Change-Id: Ia3540c5b396212c0f214d41e51797c584329a482
Closes-Bug:#1326051

[{'created': '2014-07-09 21:17:53.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor congress eventlet server code

This patch removes the current wsgi-server in place of the one that keystone
uses which is basically identical to the one that was already in congress.
The only reason I switched it out for the keystone one is just so copying
the keystone integration out of keystone to congress would be easier.
In addition, this patch adds mutiworker support so can use multiple processes
to run our api server (though currently we just default that to 1).
This patch also includes test cases for the eventlet server.

commit_message:
Refactor congress eventlet server code

This patch removes the current wsgi-server in place of the one that keystone
uses which is basically identical to the one that was already in congress.
The only reason I switched it out for the keystone one is just so copying
the keystone integration out of keystone to congress would be easier.
In addition, this patch adds mutiworker support so can use multiple processes
to run our api server (though currently we just default that to 1).
This patch also includes test cases for the eventlet server.

Change-Id: I25ab083d359a4bd85c93356e5261d31061a7e9aa
Closes-bug: 1339880

commit_message:
Format endpoint URLs for validation

Previously, endpoint URL were generated randomly before sending endpoint
requests to the Keystone server. Now that Keystone is validating input
on incoming requests, URLs have to match a regular expression in order
to be considered valid. This change modifies the endpoint URL to be
compliant before sending the endpoint request.

Change-Id: I15d2e8676bcfc338ff4fcad5b33cf0e666a28300

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

Small grammar fix in libvirt/driver.py. fix all occurrences.

Change wording to be more descriptive/correct for greenthread.sleep()
Change-Id: I074391eaa7cfd580b89d89c2dd587796112c4a98

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-06-04 14:09:13.000000000', 'message': 'vmware: Fixes create volume from image error

While creating a volume with an image specified as the volume source,
the VMDK driver tries creating the volume backing file on each host
in the inventory (one by one; until any attempt succeeds). However,
if the attempted host is in a bad connection state, the volume
creation fails and results in the volume going into error state.
Effectively, user cannot create a volume from image in such scenario.
This patch catches the VimFaultException during backing file
creation, so that driver picks the next available host for volume
creation.

Change-Id: I8ffdb849f41e8c28137ad8c0fa1f86c54b5e6fe9
Closes-Bug: #1326366
'}, {'created': '2014-06-06 08:42:59.000000000', 'message': 'vmware: Fixes create volume from image error

While creating a volume with an image specified as the volume source,
the VMDK driver tries creating the volume backing file on each host
in the inventory (one by one; until any attempt succeeds). However,
if the attempted host is in a bad connection state, the volume
creation fails and results in the volume going into error state.
Effectively, user cannot create a volume from image in such scenario.
This patch catches the VimFaultException during backing file
creation, so that driver picks the next available host for volume
creation.

Change-Id: I8ffdb849f41e8c28137ad8c0fa1f86c54b5e6fe9
Closes-Bug: #1326366
'}]
commit_message:
vmware: Fixes create volume from image error

While creating a volume with an image specified as the volume source,
the VMDK driver tries creating the volume backing file on each host
in the inventory (one by one; until any attempt succeeds). However,
if the attempted host is in a bad connection state, the volume
creation fails and results in the volume going into error state.
Effectively, user cannot create a volume from image in such scenario.
This patch catches the VimFaultException during backing file
creation, so that driver picks the next available host for volume
creation.

Change-Id: I8ffdb849f41e8c28137ad8c0fa1f86c54b5e6fe9
Closes-Bug: #1326366

commit_message:
Add a `_retry_on_deadlock` decorator

This patch adds a `_retry_on_deadlock` decorator from Nova. The aim is
to retry db transactions that had failed because of race-conditions.
Although this is not the best and most ideal fix - it'd be better to get
rid of the race condition - the fix does adds a guard against unseen
reace conditions for some of the functions in the database API.

I'll contribute this patch to oslo.db but in the meantime, I'd prefer to
let it land in Glance and then clean it up once it's in `oslo.db`.

Change-Id: Iea1fa94a7c8690c874859b1b1e9fd1cdf29fed21
Fixes-bug: #1339735

I don't like that the DBDuplicateEntry exception is being propagated and caught outside of the db api, but I see that this is done like that in v3 as well.

I'd really prefer if we raise a more higher level exception here and deal with that in the API.

Also a bit off topic - looking at the flavor_extra_specs_update_or_create db api method - I don't understand those retries there, they seem like a bad hack - maybe we should get rid of that as well?"}, {'account_id': 7494, 'date': '2014-01-15 02:47:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Nikola, thanks for the comments.

Agree, I will upload another patch to wrapper DB exception.

For your question related to max retry, it was introduced by:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/db-enforce-unique-keys
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/34578/6

It is used to handle the case of a concurrent transaction for a flavor.'}, {'account_id': 7494, 'date': '2014-01-15 06:26:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-01-15 07:37:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Correct exception for flavor extra spec create/update

When create/update flavor extra spec failed for v2 api, it will not
raise MetadataLimitExceeded for but two exceptions as following:
1) FlavorExtraSpecUpdateCreateFailed
2) FlavorNotFound

When create/update flavor extra spec failed for v3 api, it will not
raise DBDuplicateEntry but raise FlavorExtraSpecUpdateCreateFailed.

This patch updates the exception handling logic for create/update
flavor extra spec.

Change-Id: If3310a1cb44952e8fe2efe0b3358783f729bc190

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-07 10:29:29.000000000', 'message': "shelve doesn't work on nova-cells environment

The compute_api shelve/unshelve methods expect an Instance object,
but cell is still passing the sqlalchemy form.
So adding shelve/unshelve to the list of methods that will receive an
Instance object when using nova-cell.

When shelving instance with nova-cell environment,
instance object needs to contain 'metadata' and 'info_cache'.
So fetching the same from databse and adding it to
instance object before calling shelve/unshelve methods.

Closes-Bug: #1338451
Change-Id: Ia31b33c9a1d347f15d3e0a67fa31ef6b25a7407a
"}, {'created': '2014-07-16 13:51:03.000000000', 'message': "shelve doesn't work on nova-cells environment

The compute_api shelve/unshelve methods expect an Instance object,
but cell is still passing the sqlalchemy form.
So adding shelve/unshelve to the list of methods that will receive an
Instance object when using nova-cell.

When shelving instance with nova-cell environment,
instance object needs to contain 'metadata' and 'info_cache'.
So fetching the same from databse and adding it to
instance object before calling shelve/unshelve methods.

Closes-Bug: #1338451
Change-Id: Ia31b33c9a1d347f15d3e0a67fa31ef6b25a7407a
"}]
commit_message:
shelve doesn't work on nova-cells environment

The compute_api shelve/unshelve methods expect an Instance object,
but cell is still passing the sqlalchemy form.
So adding shelve/unshelve to the list of methods that will receive an
Instance object when using nova-cell.

When shelving instance with nova-cell environment,
instance object needs to contain 'metadata' and 'info_cache'.
So fetching the same from databse and adding it to
instance object before calling shelve/unshelve methods.

Closes-Bug: #1338451
Change-Id: Ia31b33c9a1d347f15d3e0a67fa31ef6b25a7407a

commit_message:
libvirt: add migrateToURI2 method to fakelibvirt

With the merge of

  commit ea7da5152cdca7ba674e2137c3899909995e2287
  Author: Solly Ross <sross@redhat.com>
  Date:   Tue Feb 4 14:27:51 2014 -0500

    Change listen address on libvirt live-migration

the libvirt driver uses migrateToURI2 instead of
migrateToURI. The fakelibvirt class did not define
this method so it was unable to be mocked out.

Change-Id: I74c28119c979e511cece6b839e25a40197b0e5d9
Closes-bug: 1342498
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

Dan,
  Agreed that cpu resources in the kernel are taken here, and it would be nice to only do that as needed.  However there are other criteria that are considered:
a.) the rule only applies only to udp packets
b.) the kernel adds checksums only if not present already.  This is going to be a very quick check. (http://lwn.net/Articles/396466/)

  I'm not sure which of those checks is applied first, but both are about as quick as possible.

Additionally, the previous check would give false positives anywhere where a kernel module was loaded independent of whether or not the hypervisor would use it.  We were already possibly doing extra work.

So, yes, this is worse, but only slightly so.  And checks as you suggested also have shortcommings:
a.) virt-type: (as seen, the "virt type" does not guarantee usage)
b.) kernel-version: in 2 years time, a kernel kernel check would apply to 
c.) the trend here is for virtual network devices to not add checksums, but legacy software that needs to be supported expects those checksums.

In short, this is 100% broken now on current distributions, the proposed change fix fixes, and there are no trivial fixes that do not have shortcomings.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2014-07-16 14:36:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Okay, fair enough, thanks for the detail.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-16 14:36:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

[{'created': '2014-06-27 16:44:42.000000000', 'message': 'add checksums to udp independent of /dev/vhost-net.

In newer kernel versions, the network devices added for lxc containers
do not get checksums added.  The result is the same as previously
occurred when vhost-net became prevalent in kvm guests.

Software that expects the checksums on packets will ignore them.  One example
of such software is udhcpc in cirros.  Without this change, cirros containers
in 3.13 kernels (Ubuntu 14.04) will fail to acquire an address via dhcp.

Closes-Bug: #1335193
Change-Id: Iba305fb7f8236955ca732e467db9e424535be93d
'}]
commit_message:
add checksums to udp independent of /dev/vhost-net.

In newer kernel versions, the network devices added for lxc containers
do not get checksums added.  The result is the same as previously
occurred when vhost-net became prevalent in kvm guests.

Software that expects the checksums on packets will ignore them.  One example
of such software is udhcpc in cirros.  Without this change, cirros containers
in 3.13 kernels (Ubuntu 14.04) will fail to acquire an address via dhcp.

Closes-Bug: #1335193
Change-Id: Iba305fb7f8236955ca732e467db9e424535be93d

commit_message:
Remove redundant method handle_get_attributes

All resources use _resolve_attribute method to resolve attribute
schema. Base neutron class contains confused method
handle_get_attributes that should be deleted.

Change-Id: I4651687acac83312a974b446623f4dd8fd0b746e

commit_message:
Add cinder-manage cmd to update host column

If you deploy Cinder as per the default using the docs,
you can't later decide to add backends using the
multi-backend functionality. The reason is that multi-backend
is implemented by appending a backend-name to the host entry.

So if you convert the config to multi-backend the hostname
for any volumes that you have created are no longer
associated with a valid volume-driver (ie you can no
longer perform operations including delete on these
volumes).

In addition, in the case of using a SAN attached backend if
one redeploys their cinder-volume service to another node
they'll have the same issue.

This patch adds a cinder-manage command that will go through
volumes that are located on a specified host and update
the host column on each of them.

Change-Id: I8758fb8ef3fccbba2a598240c42d625b997e2db6
Closes-Bug: 1320688
(cherry picked from commit 2068164d0f155578d2f7a106afe464ef578032cb)

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-15 22:32:19.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid logging "Expected" exceptions returned over RPC

When an expected exception, such as a NotFound or Duplicate is passed over
RPC, we identify it via the `expected` attribute and raise oslo.messagings
ExpectedException. The internals of ExpectedException effectively save the
current exception details (type, trace, etc) inside the ExpectedException,
when received on the client side, the ExpectedException is detected, and
the saved details are used to bubble the original exception back up. On
both sides of the RPC, logging is avoided when ExpectedException is used.

Change-Id: I143882181e3346c4ebe1f0ad491c75a4db549fe4
Closes-Bug: #1304152
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid logging "Expected" exceptions returned over RPC

When an expected exception, such as a NotFound or Duplicate is passed over
RPC, we identify it via the `expected` attribute and raise oslo.messagings
ExpectedException. The internals of ExpectedException effectively save the
current exception details (type, trace, etc) inside the ExpectedException,
when received on the client side, the ExpectedException is detected, and
the saved details are used to bubble the original exception back up. On
both sides of the RPC, logging is avoided when ExpectedException is used.

Change-Id: I143882181e3346c4ebe1f0ad491c75a4db549fe4
Closes-Bug: #1304152

commit_message:
Update oslo-incubator lockutils module

Changes -
 * Don't import fcntl on Windows
 * pep8: fixed multiple violations
 * fixed typos found by RETF rules

Change-Id: I3c3504fe705ee2d91414323217f7185a7a695e43

commit_message:
Add dbus library, needed for the DRBD cinder driver integration.

DRBDmanage is a cluster-wide service to provide replicated storage
with a simple administration interface; its daemon listens on
the system dbus for commands.

The DRBD cinder volume driver needs to talk to the daemon, and so
needs the dbus library.

The library is available as python-dbus (deb), and dbus-python (rpm)
in most distributions.

Change-Id: I7c0ca5c58f7b533d6fc93ec52f2dae11f69a3db1

commit_message:
Transfer class LazyPluggable from nova to oslo-incubator

Need to transfer code of class LazyPluggable to oslo-incubator
because this code copied in different projects. Also global attribute CONF
is now transmitted in __init__ function.
Also was written test for this class.

commit_message:
Transfer class LazyPluggable from nova to oslo-incubator

Need to transfer code of class LazyPluggable to oslo-incubator
because this code copied in different projects. Also global attribute CONF
is now transmitted in __init__ function.
Also was written test for this class.

This patch adds the ability to benchmark Marconi. The benchmark tool
is a console script, and can be triggered using

$ marconi-bench

The Benchmark tool fires up both a Producer Process and a Consumer
Process, while accepting CLI parameters for the number of processes,
number of workers and duration of test.

The Producer Process publishes messages to a given queue, while the
Consumer consumes the messages by claiming and deleting them.

Setup:

Benchmark dependencies need to be pip installed:

 pip install -r bench-requirements.txt

Export an environment variable called MESSAGES_PATH and set it to the
path of messages.json in marconi/bench

Note: This allows benchmarking with different set of messages rather
than those specified in messages.json

Usage:

$ marconi-bench --p {No. Processes} --w {No. Workers} --d {No. Seconds}

Once the values are entered, the benchmark begins!

Partially Implements: blueprint basic-benchmarking
Change-Id: I57ebe853554199490adba8b2a091423f399b0565

commit_message:
feat(benchmarking) : Producer-Consumer scenario

This patch adds the ability to benchmark Marconi. The benchmark tool
is a console script, and can be triggered using

$ marconi-bench-pc

The Benchmark tool fires up both a Producer Process and a Consumer
Process, while accepting CLI parameters for the number of processes,
number of workers and duration of test.

The Producer Process publishes messages to a given queue, while the
Consumer consumes the messages by claiming and deleting them.

Setup:

Benchmark dependencies need to be pip installed:

 pip install -r bench-requirements.txt

Export an environment variable called MESSAGES_PATH and set it to the
path of messages.json in marconi/bench

Note: This allows benchmarking with different set of messages rather
than those specified in messages.json

Usage:

$ marconi-bench-pc -p {No. Processes} -w {No. Workers} -t {No. Seconds}

Example:

$ marconi-bench-pc -p 2 -w 2 -t 4

Partially Implements: blueprint basic-benchmarking
Change-Id: I57ebe853554199490adba8b2a091423f399b0565

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

(1 comment)

Thanks for working on this, Idan! I have a few general comments:

(1) I wonder whether we should implement this like you did for explicit places in the template, or if we should rather do function processing globally on the template and then lower-level places get the already resolved values.

(2) It seems like we need to recursively resolve functions, so that for example in you testcase the result of the function is not get_input, but really the input value. Did you have this in mind as the end goal and this is only the first piece of the solution?

In general, we have to think about how far we resolve functions. Especially when it comes to get_attribute (which is runtime data), we cannot really resolve it since we do not implement runtime resources. We will only ever be able to resolve user inputs. And then we have to actually resolve to Heat functions for the translator and let Heat do the runtime translation.
This is a general comment not really related to your patch, but I wanted to have it captured so everyone can think about it.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-01 10:52:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Verified

Thomas, Thanks for the review!

1. I think that the parser user should be able to decide whether he wants to resolve static properties or keep their function representation and heat is a good example where you can have both runtime and static properties references so it really depends on the user. Perhaps we can have this configurable when initializing the parser for different resolvings (inputs, properties, runtime properties etc...).

2. Yes I had this in mind, I thought of implementing recursive resolving later on. I suppose that if Tosca had a distinction between properties and runtime properties as different template functions that would be more complete.'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2014-07-11 12:26:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

Idan, I'm ok with doing the recursive function resolution as a next step (point 2 in your last comment). Regarding point 1, I guess we well have to see based on implementation what makes sense.

So I would be for getting this first change in."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-11 12:26:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: -Verified

commit_message:
Added a module for intrinsic function.

Curenntly only handles get_ref_property specified in interface operation
input.

Renamed ntype to node_type.

Change-Id: I4d95b28faba9b55a5d16b9f16dbe36bd3bcd5b4d
Implements: blueprint tosca-ref-property

commit_message:
Transfer class LazyPluggable from nova to oslo-incubator

Need to transfer code of class LazyPluggable to oslo-incubator
because this code copied in different projects. Also global attribute CONF
is now transmitted in __init__ function.
Also was written test for this class.

Change-Id: Ib0ca1941b3f8d6ff88ed6341653a0d3d423633b5

commit_message:
Allow veth_mtu to be configured in openvswitch agent

With openvswitch vlan, default of veth_mtu = 1500 is 4 bytes short and you end up
with either no traffic or abysmal network performance.  Need the 4 extra bytes for
the vlan id.

Change-Id: Idc128c76f6b93ce52acc51bba9da08ccaa308ac3
Closes-Bug: #1325754

commit_message:
Document authentication plugins

Explain the plugins that are provided and some information on how to
write new ones. This will obviously need to be expanded as more features
are added.

Change-Id: Ie67e93f2ed994c3702ac66e388cf216609dd44ff

commit_message:
adapt to python-novaclient-2.18.0

Novaclient renamed HTTPNotImplemented to HttpNotImplemented
and changed the attribute code to status in exceptions

This change should make the code work on newer and older versions.

Closes-Bug: #1340596
(cherry picked from commit 322004f8480e40af5e77ed843ff803005d5af27c)

Conflicts:
	openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/instances/console.py
	openstack_dashboard/test/test_data/exceptions.py

Change-Id: Ifef6c4c1b2924b03df00f427cfe3e6a7f415e569
