revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-16 10:25:22.000000000', 'message': 'add support for source=swift

While we are running both filesystem and swift in parallel, it
would be good to be able to bypass the filesystem to test the
difference between swift and volume performance.

Do this with the addition of a source= cgi parameter. Currently
source=swift is the only thing that will change behavior. Internally
we default it to all.

Refactoring of the cgi param parsing is done to make it cleaner
code and not copy/paste the cgi param parsing a 3rd time.

Change-Id: Ic653bad9a0f74fb5714ff7ccfc7da8d790dcff8b
'}, {'created': '2014-07-16 14:43:55.000000000', 'message': 'add support for source=swift

Change-Id: Ic653bad9a0f74fb5714ff7ccfc7da8d790dcff8b
'}, {'created': '2014-07-16 14:50:06.000000000', 'message': 'add support for source=swift

difference between swift and volume performance.

'}]
commit_message:
add support for source=swift

While we are running both filesystem and swift in parallel, it
would be good to be able to bypass the filesystem to test the
difference between swift and volume performance.

Do this with the addition of a source= cgi parameter. Currently
source=swift is the only thing that will change behavior. Internally
we default it to all.

Refactoring of the cgi param parsing is done to make it cleaner
code and not copy/paste the cgi param parsing a 3rd time.

Change-Id: Ic653bad9a0f74fb5714ff7ccfc7da8d790dcff8b

commit_message:
Adding dependencies for redis support in marconi

Adding the py-redis dependancy to marconi to support
redis storage backend

Adding the dependencies only to test-requirements-*.txt
as database backend requirements will slowly be phased
out of requirements-*.txt

Change-Id: I25581965b3deea201d33a7b53a284294c15290c7
Partially-Implements: bp/redis-storage-driver

commit_message:
Add new requirements install in setup.sh script

* This changeset handle proper db migrations, by installing required libs for postgresql
* Add required packages to /doc/source/install/prepare.rst document

Change-Id: I5819022918af6f240642d6751ab2d47b9be96e2b

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-02 14:40:17.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Fix DB migration scripts

Problem we had:
If the collation of the DB and table is utf8 and the columns we want to index are 512 chars,
it is too big for the index since the max key length is 767 bytes.
Following error message observed:
(OperationalError) (1071, 'Specified key was too long; max key length is 767 bytes')

Fix:
Use prefix indexes on MySQL (128 bytes)

TBD:
* Drop indexes in downgrade script
* Add tests

Change-Id: I4816790e11f225c5dbb130747535094fdf06733e
"}, {'created': '2014-07-03 23:04:11.000000000', 'message': "Fix DB migration scripts

is 767 bytes.

Following error message observed:
(OperationalError) (1071, 'Specified key was too long; max key length is 767 bytes')

Fix:

using by default.

"}, {'created': '2014-07-09 14:05:57.000000000', 'message': "Fix DB migration scripts

Problems we had:
1. If the collation of the DB and table is utf8 and the columns we want to
   index are 512 chars, it is too big for the index since the max key length
   is 767 bytes. Following error message observed:
   (OperationalError) (1071, 'Specified key was too long; max key length is 767 bytes')

2. During migration to Alembic we missed the unique field for the
   'fully_qualified_name' column of the table 'package'. This change
   fixes that issue.

Fixes:
1. Reduce length of indexed columns to fix problem. 128 chars should be probably enough
2. Add uniqe paramater for column fully_qualified_name of table package

Additional changes:
* Test that column is unique in DB migration tests (on real databases)
* Introduced base for DB-related unit-tests. These tests use in-memory
  instance of SQLite
* Test that column is unique in DB-related unit-tests

Closes-Bug: #1339201
Closes-Bug: #1339728
Change-Id: I4816790e11f225c5dbb130747535094fdf06733e

commit_message:
Fix DB migration script

Problems we had:
1. If the collation of the DB and table is utf8 and the columns we want to
   index are 512 chars, it is too big for the index since the max key length
   is 767 bytes. Following error message observed:
   (OperationalError) (1071, 'Specified key was too long; max key length is 767 bytes')

2. During migration to Alembic we missed the unique field for the
   'fully_qualified_name' column of the table 'package'. This change
   fixes that issue.

Fixes:
1. Reduce length of indexed columns to fix problem. 128 chars should be probably enough
2. Add uniqe paramater for column fully_qualified_name of table package

Additional changes:
* Test that column is unique in DB migration tests (on real databases)
* Introduced base for DB-related unit-tests. These tests use in-memory
  instance of SQLite
* Test that column is unique in DB-related unit-tests

Closes-Bug: #1339201
Closes-Bug: #1339728
Change-Id: I4816790e11f225c5dbb130747535094fdf06733e

commit_message:
WIP: Enable haproxy_connect_any port access

Enable a boolean to allow haproxy to proxy any port. If not set,
SELinux, in enforcing mode, denies haproxy access and haproxy will
fail to start.

Bug: 1339938
Change-Id: I882c94f142af3b27d99722bf2098324fe29a9e7e

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

[{'created': '2014-07-01 14:04:52.000000000', 'message': 'Move python-netaddr install to network-utils

Move pythonn-netaddr installation to the network-utils
element where it is used, so that the network-utils element
can be used independently of the boot-stack element.

Change-Id: I67540ef0bfe2b4fb5a382dce8bae22c570cb1a38
'}]
commit_message:
Move python-netaddr install to network-utils

Move pythonn-netaddr installation to the network-utils
element where it is used, so that the network-utils element
can be used independently of the boot-stack element.

Change-Id: I67540ef0bfe2b4fb5a382dce8bae22c570cb1a38

commit_message:
Add share-server-delete API

This API is useful when share-server autodeletion is disabled, which is default behaviour.

Changes:
- added new api method with deletion of share server
- added db method, that takes list of shares by share server id
- changed logic of share manager, that is related to concurrency issues
- added unit and tempest tests to cover changes

Partially-implements blueprint add-admin-api-delete-share-server

Change-Id: I03b452de2cd4fe34c648b2434dab1b9244b1b005

commit_message:
Update oslo-incubator loopingcall module

Changes -
 * Changes calcuation of variable delay
 * Use timestamp in loopingcall
 * Log the function name of looping call

Change-Id: Iebe6913d731b4cee105c11abf7007ec13f0f5787

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-15 15:16:18.000000000', 'message': 'Make logging_context_format_string optional in log.set_defaults

Instead of supporting setting logging_context_format_string to None,
which will break things. Support not specifying
logging_context_format_string in log.set_defaults so projects can set
the default_log_level

Change-Id: I932d5b2148a57c5b59ab3f071e53c87ef43b6a6e
'}]
commit_message:
Make logging_context_format_string optional in log.set_defaults

Instead of supporting setting logging_context_format_string to None,
which will break things. Support not specifying
logging_context_format_string in log.set_defaults so projects can set
the default_log_level

Change-Id: I932d5b2148a57c5b59ab3f071e53c87ef43b6a6e

Update oslo-incubator config.generator module

Changes -
 * generator: remove unused param, small clean up

commit_message:
Display flavor details in instance listing in a popover

This patch moves the flavor details in the instance listing into
a popover to reduce the amount of displayed details in the listing.

Change-Id: Ibd8cd228bae41e0f2870a8a14b6ce21338d61a8f
Closes-Bug: #1314177

commit_message:
Improves pipeline transformer documentation

Adds the Transformers section in the configuration documentation.
Describes each transformer's function, parameters and provides
an example.

Change-Id: I8f2218edcdd23fbd42a160afc5cc8e0af8d73af7

nice find, Timur!!'}, {'account_id': 9981, 'date': '2014-07-14 21:33:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I tried this change and out it makes the datepicker look off -- there are partially overlapping rounded rectangles around each calendar element.  

The change seems logical.  I haven't dug around to figure out if this is the intended style of the datepacker (seems unlikely) or if there is some other problem."}, {'account_id': 9981, 'date': '2014-07-14 21:37:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Maybe this line is relevant?  https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/90474517de73f761c77b29a01cad80c418bd15e9/horizon/templates/horizon/_scripts.html#L29'}, {'account_id': 8040, 'date': '2014-07-15 09:25:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Doug, have hard-reloaded browser cache after you checked out that fix in git. Sometimes strange looking styles are caused by old and new static resources mixed up in cache.

I've made screenshots on my machine, http://imgur.com/aRwM20x,GZHj3BT#0 - master branch, also there is warning: 

DEBUG:scss:Searching for /bootstrap/scss/_datepicker in [u'bootstrap/scss/_datepicker', u'bootstrap/scss/__datepicker.scss', u'bootstrap/scss/__datepicker.sass', u'bootstrap/scss/__datepicker.css', u'bootstrap/scss/_datepicker.scss', u'bootstrap/scss/_datepicker.sass', u'bootstrap/scss/_datepicker.css']
WARNING:scss:File to import not found or unreadable: '/bootstrap/scss/_datepicker' (<string u'@import "/bootstrap/scss/_bootstrap";\n@import "/bo'...>:0)

while http://imgur.com/aRwM20x,GZHj3BT#1 is made with my patch - it looks much better (highlighted current date, grayed out dates from other months, on-hover light gray background for each date).'}, {'account_id': 9981, 'date': '2014-07-15 12:58:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Timur thanks for clarifying.  I'm getting the same behavior you are.  While much of the styling is improved, the use of rounded rectangles at the top of the calendar, which leaves those little white spaces, seemed like a mistake to me.  I can see now that's the intended behavior.  While I don't like it, I consider that concern out of scope for this patch.

Nicely done, and thanks for taking the time to explain and share."}, {'account_id': 8794, 'date': '2014-07-15 13:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8040, 'date': '2014-07-15 14:19:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Doug, I've noticed those gray rounded rectangles in the top of the datepicker only on the fourth try. You have a sharp eye indeed (or maybe I should change my display) :)). Agree that this styling issue should be addressed by another bug."}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2014-07-15 14:23:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

oops, thanks for catching this'}, {'account_id': 9659, 'date': '2014-07-15 14:23:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6914, 'date': '2014-07-16 10:31:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-16 10:31:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

commit_message:
Move _datepicker.scss to a correct place

The place that is referenced by _horizon.scss.
Closes-Bug: #1341655

Change-Id: I2dd796dbfd8ca6083c4d0025905d404e66b36cc5

commit_message:
Cleaned up dict.update(single elem dict) code

There's several places in the code where this type of thing exists:
    form_data.update({'vpnservice_id': vpnservice.id})
better would be this:
    form_data['vpnservice_id'] = vpnservice.id
This type of thing bothers me, so I'm going to clean it up.

Also fixed the two cases of:
    if <some_string>.find(<some_other_string>) != -1:
which should clearly use the "in" operator instead.

Change-Id: Ic72a5b0a17c211f3949edc69732c1101c24590ec
Closes-Bug: 1339849

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-06-18 13:55:49.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for using extensions

This patch registers an extension in vCenter. This enables a third
party, for example OpenStack, to mark that it is responsible for a
resource.

If an administrator tries to update the VM via vCenter then they will
get the following message:

"Solution OpenStack manages the selected virtual machine. You should
not modify the virtual machine directly. Use the management console of
the solution to make changes. Do you want to proceed?"

The following API's have been added:
 - find_extension - checks if a specific extension exists
 - create_extension - creates a new extension

Change-Id: I634b84da8bf32fab6152af3c84ed1bb8c52251af
'}, {'created': '2014-07-03 10:03:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for using extensions

This patch registers an extension in vCenter. This enables a third
party, for example OpenStack, to mark that it is responsible for a
resource.

If an administrator tries to update the VM via vCenter then they will
get the following message:

"Solution OpenStack manages the selected virtual machine. You should
not modify the virtual machine directly. Use the management console of
the solution to make changes. Do you want to proceed?"

The following API's have been added:
 - find_extension - checks if a specific extension exists
 - create_extension - creates a new extension

Change-Id: I634b84da8bf32fab6152af3c84ed1bb8c52251af
'}, {'created': '2014-07-08 11:05:31.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for using extensions

This patch registers an extension in vCenter. This enables a third
party, for example OpenStack, to mark that it is responsible for a
resource.

If an administrator tries to update the VM via vCenter then they will
get the following message:

"Solution OpenStack manages the selected virtual machine. You should
not modify the virtual machine directly. Use the management console of
the solution to make changes. Do you want to proceed?"

The following API's have been added:
 - find_extension - checks if a specific extension exists

commit_message:
Add support for using extensions

This patch registers an extension in vCenter. This enables a third
party, for example OpenStack, to mark that it is responsible for a
resource.

If an administrator tries to update the VM via vCenter then they will
get the following message:

"Solution OpenStack manages the selected virtual machine. You should
not modify the virtual machine directly. Use the management console of
the solution to make changes. Do you want to proceed?"

The following API's have been added:
 - find_extension - checks if a specific extension exists
 - register_extension - registers a new extension

Note that the onus is on the caller to validate that the extension exists.
If not they should handle the exception returned from the backend.

The pseudo code should be as follows:

    if not find_extension(key):
        register_extension(...)

Change-Id: I634b84da8bf32fab6152af3c84ed1bb8c52251af

commit_message:
Refactoring of rabbitmq OCF script

1) Store attributes in CIB instead of files
2) Do not use ocf_run if command may fail
3) Eliminate master_score race condition:
set master_score to 1000 for the older nodes
and do not forget to update their uptime value
4) fix messed interleave/ordered settings
5) set failure-timeout to 60 seconds to recover
from RabbitMQ master node failure
6) for slave nodes only run beam and
start rabbitmq only if there is master promoted
7) stop RMQ app on slaves in case of master demotion
8) clean up other nodes master attribute in case
of promotion
9) fix exit codes for failed services start and cluster
joining
10) get running nodes into running_nodes variable
11) apply timeout command to cluster_status function

Closes-bug: #1339080
Closes-bug: #1336777

Change-Id: I271c6d7db4cf8fe4c9dfc7599954cb0ec8813293

127 function _clean_lvm_backing_file {
128     local vg=$1
129     local backing_file=$2
130 
131     # if there is no logical volume left, it's safe to attempt a cleanup
132     # of the backing file
133     if [[ -z "$(sudo lvs --noheadings -o lv_name $vg 2>/dev/null)" ]]; then
134         # if the backing physical device is a loop device, it was probably setup by devstack
135         VG_DEV=$(sudo losetup -j $backing_file | awk -F':' '/backing-file/ { print $1}')
136         if [[ -n "$VG_DEV" ]] && [[ -e "$VG_DEV" ]]; then
137             sudo losetup -d $VG_DEV

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-08 16:31:02.000000000', 'message': 'WIP:Don't match editor backup files in environment

Retesting this patch with extra debug info to find what went wrong

The current glob match for environment files can source editor backup
files (foo.bash~) which will override the real changes you have made.

Other parts matche use the regex to avoid matching such files, so do
the same for environment file matching.  Note this has to match "."
unlike the other regex, as most env files are "foo.bash"

Change-Id: Ib0ca7fc4dc1003516e21bfcf881a8a3510934d8b
'}]
commit_message:
WIP:Don't match editor backup files in environment

Retesting this patch with extra debug info to find what went wrong

The current glob match for environment files can source editor backup
files (foo.bash~) which will override the real changes you have made.

Other parts matche use the regex to avoid matching such files, so do
the same for environment file matching.  Note this has to match "."
unlike the other regex, as most env files are "foo.bash"

Change-Id: Ib0ca7fc4dc1003516e21bfcf881a8a3510934d8b

[{'created': '2014-07-13 16:56:52.000000000', 'message': "Use /usr/bin/env python instead of /usr/bin/python

The usage of /usr/bin/env ensures that the first interpreter
found in the environment's $PATH variable is used. This should
be preferred.

Change-Id: I4011ec477534f920092cc323a26e75ff26a90051
"}]
commit_message:
Use /usr/bin/env python instead of /usr/bin/python

The usage of /usr/bin/env ensures that the first interpreter
found in the environment's $PATH variable is used. This should
be preferred.

Change-Id: I4011ec477534f920092cc323a26e75ff26a90051

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Add shared functions for hardware discovery

New module ironic.common.discovery is introduced with functions:
- store_inventory: store hardware inventory in a given Node
- find_node: find Node object, given full hardware inventory

Change-Id: Ia585d27153b7cbc85ce5b5402948689fb969df1d
Implements: blueprint generic-hardware-discovery

Do not merge this patch.

resources.

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-16 09:44:01.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Fix use of novaclient.exceptions.NotFound"

It was fixed in nova client now, so, we need to revert this fix too.
https://github.com/openstack/python-novaclient/releases/tag/2.18.1

https://github.com/openstack/python-novaclient/compare/2.18.0...2.18.1

This reverts commit 29026c88a1a0528ca9a73a941cb9d49015d83342.

commit_message:
Fix typo in select methods definition

Constructor of Support.Select object expects webelement, just one
argument is necessary, therefore the asterisk is redundant.

It seems like this method was refactored and was originaly used with
locator.

Partially implements blueprint: selenium-integration-testing

Change-Id: Id0b1432a8a254283d8d03ec03da7cb4c3e30347b

I think it's valuable to expose and consume the volume type information in order to retain parity with the EC2 API.  But I don't think that relying on volume extra specs is the way that this should go.  Until Cinder can officially support the idea of volume types in a way that can be mapped to EC2 volume types it seems like everything should be considered standard.

If/when Cinder provides a blessed method for specifying a guaranteed IOPs volume then this can leverage that for the io1 type.

So I think the scope of this should be reduced to just exposing a volume type attribute and just keeping it as standard for now."}, {'account_id': 5538, 'date': '2014-07-03 04:54:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-03 04:54:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I'm primarily an operator, and really like this idea, since these services without APIs are somewhat difficult to monitor.  But I want to be sure that the heartbeat file can really be trusted to accurately reflect the status of the service.  See comments."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2014-06-25 16:31:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Agree with Dan. At the very least, this spec needs to address why the current liveliness solution - i.e. the servicegroup drivers with the default one being the DB driver which requires an update every 60 seconds (configurable with service_down_time in nova.conf)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-05 16:14:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

Hi Dan, Mark, thanks for your reviews. Honestly I didn't know about the DB thing, that's why I wrote a file. It does have the advantage of simplicity however!

To follow your suggestion, I'd need to write an Icinga check which can parse nova.conf and query the DB. Not vastly complex maybe but more than nothing. The future of that approach is also in doubt with conductor rapidly gaining momentum. Checking a file's mtime on the other hand is possible using a pre-packaged check."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-16 11:52:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

[{'created': '2014-06-25 14:16:43.000000000', 'message': "Add periodic task heartbeat file

At present it's difficult to verify that all Nova services are
responsive, rather than merely running. Touch a heartbeat file, the
freshness of which can easily be monitored by EG an Icinga check.

Change-Id: Ibbc62fb9866b33d046ff2fe13588b4d02db3d250
"}]
commit_message:
Add periodic task heartbeat file

At present it's difficult to verify that all Nova services are
responsive, rather than merely running. Touch a heartbeat file, the
freshness of which can easily be monitored by EG an Icinga check.

Thanks for the BP. I like the aspect of favoring datastore selection based on whether an image is cached in the datastore, but I have some concerns about the use cross-datastore linked clone part of the design.'}, {'account_id': 8027, 'date': '2014-06-11 23:18:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

Correcting some of my own typos and added elaboration.'}, {'account_id': 7239, 'date': '2014-06-12 09:09:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(7 comments)

Thanks for your feedback.
I think we have a consensus on the idea of using the datastore that already has the cache.
Additional responses inline. The short summary is - 
The cross datastore linked clones can be a configurable option. The default will be to copy the image file to the new datastore from the cache of the datastore that has the image. This would mean that after the copy, the existing behavior will be used. The benefit we get is to avoid the network copy.
When the config option is used, the proposed cross datastore referencing (point #2 of the blueprint) will be used.'}, {'account_id': 7239, 'date': '2014-06-12 09:50:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-12 09:50:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-12 10:06:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/04/98704/5/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/7d20dd3 : SUCCESS in 1m 01s
- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/04/98704/5/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/a9018c3/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 31s'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-06-24 14:44:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I actually don't think adding (yet) another configuration option is the right approach to this. I would greatly prefer to see the VMWare driver code simply change to use multiple datastore's cached images and use linked clones than have a configuration option control that behaviour. There really is no benefit in continuing the existing behaviour of copying the image bits all over the place.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-24 14:44:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Verified

Starting check jobs.

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/04/98704/5/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/b562db9/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 35s'}, {'account_id': 7239, 'date': '2014-06-24 15:32:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

@Jay Pipes,
A concern was raised about creating linked clones using the base disk from a different datastore. 
In vCenter a datastore can be placed in maintenance mode. A datastore can be placed in maintenance mode when there are no VMs accessing the datastore. The concern was that it would be difficult for the admin to identify the children of a specific base disk and move the disks. 
Thats the reason of making it configurable. Default would be not to create linked that are across datastores of the cluster. (Existing implementation). When the admin prefers to use linked clones across the datastores then the option can be set and get the benefit of saving storage and improved deployment time.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-06-25 18:24:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Kiran, that makes sense and would be a good reason for making this behaviour optional. Thanks!

-jay'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2014-06-25 19:01:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
VMware nova-Storage optimization for clusters with multiple datastores

This blueprint storage-optimization-for-multi-datastore-clusters allows
images to launch faster and saves disk space by creating linked clones
of instances using the base disk already present in the image cache of
other datastore of the ESX cluster.
VMware ESX cluster can have multiple datastores that are shared across all the
hosts of the cluster. Its much more efficient to have a single copy of the
image in only one datastore of the cluster and create linked clones using
this image.

blueprint: storage-optimization-for-multi-datastore-clusters
Change-Id: I6442137549804f0632a28199d25df403ebf18e0d

* I feel like the image should say "supports SPICE USB", then maybe nova is configured to supploy N devices, where N is in nova.conf? Not really sure about the best way.

commit_message:
Support function of USB-redirection

There are requirements for USB-redirection function like redirect a USB printer from TC(Think client) to cloud by some kind of protocols like spice,
then user can use printer device in cloud environment

blueprint usb-redirection

Change-Id: I20f9e3e127b3a2f5d98ad69fd278ef657c3bd47d

commit_message:
Add separated policy rule for each v3 api

This bp is propose to add separated policy rule for each v3 api.
That will provide finer granularity to permission control and
consistent way to configure policy rule

Part of blueprint separated-policy-rule-v3-api

Change-Id: I7a8abc3803b780b5fad759e1dfd23482a004f61d

I'm very much opposed to introducing this sort of change into Nova. The 'node' construct in nova-compute is pretty widely hated, and we've made strides to rid ourselves of as much of its use as possible."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-07-03 19:01:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

A strong -1 from me on this. It flies in the face of the original scale-out architecture of nova-compute that was thrown out with the introduction of the bare metal and vmware drivers.'}, {'account_id': 10487, 'date': '2014-07-04 04:06:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I completely disagree here. The reasons are the 4 problem described in the blueprints are real facts and following is the another fact:

As a Cloud Service provider, i would expect openstack to provide me a freedom to configure A given nova-compute with multiple hypervisors. Otherwise if i restricted one nova-compute "node" per hypervisor, this will increase my Capital and Operational expense as i need to install & maintain as many nova-compute "node" as the hypervisors. So i would expect the nova-compute to let me decide the choice deployment of nova-compute whether one node per hyperviosr or mutiple hypervisors based on my cloud requirements. Otherwise i got restricted. This blue print enable the freedom.

Based on this 5 facts, i would expect nova-compute "process" to be restricted per hypervisor and not the nova-compute "node" per hypervisor. This is how other openstack components such as cinder-volume is working today.

Kindly ignore the "way" i described here but please consider the "facts" mentioned.

Thanks
Kanagaraj M'}, {'account_id': 10487, 'date': '2014-07-04 04:39:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2014-07-16 11:47:33.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Sorry, this blueprint has missed the Juno spec approval freeze 10 July:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-July/039259.html
Please consider re-submitting when we open nova-specs for the K release.
If you are wanting an exception, please raise this in the next nova-meeting.'}]

commit_message:
vmware: enables mutliple backend drivers

It enables the multiple backend drivers for
nova-compute to improve the node usage,
scalability of nova-compute and to enable
one nova-compute per hypervisor

Change-Id: I9c90246b3bb5419efa04b6b66ef1c026b556891d

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/66/93466/4/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/5eeb13e/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 23s'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2014-06-20 22:23:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Several things stand out to me. Most importantly, synchronous replication in both mysql and postgres merely assures that at least one slave has copied the committing transaction to its local logs prior to the master completing the commit.

IT DOES NOT MEAN that the slave has APPLIED that transaction locally, and thereby, there is no guarantee that reads on the slave can access the committed data yet.

A replication slave can be significantly behind in APPLYING the logs. 

The assumption that "this has been commited on the master, therefor it can be read from a slave" only applies to MySQL+GaleraCluster or NDB. It is not available via replication in any way that I'm aware of.'}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2014-06-22 19:56:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Devananda

This is specifically geared towards Galera or NDB synchronous replication. I'll make this clearer in the spec."}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2014-06-22 20:02:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

@Devananda

I should clarify that the most important semantic difference between this and the current slave support is that we assume this handle has no lag at all.'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2014-06-23 18:32:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Ah, ok. So I totally missed that if that is the intent.

Galera supports writing to any node in the galera cluster -- I have never heard it referred to as "synchronous slave". Much of the proposal's language is geared towards a "replication slave", which is not a term used to reference nodes in a galera replication cluster, which is I think what threw me off. For what it's worth, Galera is called "synchronous multi-master replication". 

Re-interpreting the rest of the spec with this in mind, I think the general intent makes lot more sense, but much of the wording is confusing. There are still a few things worth pointing out:

- galera requires at least 3 servers for quorum, not two. Each one requires different connection parameters.
- there is no "replication slave" to which one would send reads in a galera cluster
- all galera nodes are equal with respect to reads
- the application can also improve write performance (slightly) by partitioning writes in a consistent way, eg:

  get_galera_host_for(object):
    target_host = ALL_HOSTS[int(object) % NUM_HOSTS]
    return target_host

Lastly, NDB is probably unsuitable for use with Nova because Nova relies heavily on JOINs and range scans, whereas NDB was designed for primary-key lookups. I would be fascinated to talk to anyone who has successfully used NDB with OpenStack -- AFAIK, it hasn't been done. Also, NDB is not called "synchronous replication" and has nothing to do with replication at all. It's just called "NDB cluster".

With all that in mind, I would suggest changing the title of this proposal to "add support for galera cluster". 

FWIW, I think this would be a great addition to Nova.

Thanks,
Devananda'}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2014-06-23 19:52:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Devananda

Thx for the feedback again, I'm re-spinning this to be more Galera oriented inline with your suggestions. I hadn't thought about partitioning writes also, that's a great suggestion that I'll incorporate."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-08 12:33:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2014-07-08 12:33:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-08 12:35:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Introduce support for a synchronous slave

We were able to introduce support for offloading reads to a slave
connection in Icehouse. However the slaving model was left up to
the deployer. Because we assumed that a deployer could use an async
slave we weren't able to fully segregate reads. This spec aims
to solve this problem.

(9 inline comments)

XenAPI driver already does. Each hypervisors has its own slightly different default behaviour. Some code can be shared, other code is hypervisor specific. It would be good to consider how this would all work.

Please look at how this renders in HTML, the formatting still needs work. See the jenkins job output to see how this works.

Maybe we should have a summit session on how best to integrate with some of the Glance v2 features. But I think its just a "devil in the details" kind of issue.'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2014-04-14 13:52:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (9 inline comments)

Hi John Garbutt,

>> XenAPI driver already does. Each hypervisors has its own slightly different default behaviour. Some code can be shared, other code is hypervisor specific. It would be good to consider how this would all work.
IIUC, what we did in XenAPI driver is just for Xen hypervisor but others.

I will do those shared logics in a common place for different hypervisors, like BaseImageHandler, handler loading logic; and follow-up blueprints (see references in spec) will implements different handlers for specific hypervisors, e.g. VMware Datastore copy/zero-copy image handler for ESXi/VC driver, RBD clone image handler for libvirt driver. IMO this approach just separated those logics into common and hypervisor-specific two layers. Anything I missed?

>> Please look at how this renders in HTML, the formatting still needs work. See the jenkins job output to see how this works.
Done, please latest PS.

>> Maybe we should have a summit session on how best to integrate with some of the Glance v2 features. But I think its just a "devil in the details" kind of issue.
Sounds reasonable and Yes. Actually Glance team has talked this in Icehouse mini-summit, we are using https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/use-glance-v2-api to cover the works of V2 integration.

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2014-04-14 13:52:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-04-14 13:52:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)

Hello John Garbutt,

Thanks for your re-view and inputs, I replied your comments, and answered your below concerns as in-line comments.

>>> I think you should look at implementing this for libvirt only, for a start, but in a away that other drivers could also use that system.

At start, we checked libvirt and vmware drivers, and implemented all function for them (you can check references in spce). And I checked xenapi and hyper-v as well a little.

>>> The reason being, its hard to make this work for all hypervisors, particularly given how XenAPI currently works, it really doesn't fit into the thing you describe here, in its current form.

For XenAPI, I agreed its logic of image handling is a little different, IMO the root causes of that is XenAPI currently doesn't leverage standard glance.images functions but do own implementation. So I think is a common/dedicated pain for nova, so we proposed a plan/workitem in use-glance-v2-api spec (change #84887, the dependency of this change), to "Update drivers using Glance directly (such as XenServer)", for details pls check my relevant comment.

And I'd like to know the details for your concerns of other hypervior(s), besides XenAPI.'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2014-07-04 09:26:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-04 09:26:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

commit_message:
Propose: Adding generic image transfer layer to nova.virt

Take advantage of the Glance image multiple location feature, adding a
layer to transparently dispatch image consuming request, e.g. download,
upload, to relevant handler plug-ins which working for different storage
backend with appropriate approach.

Related to blueprint virt-image-transfer-layer

Change-Id: Ifd1c0b6c31325ec7e1b838d8010fc0f2454988a2
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

proposed blueprint for pci extra info provisioning

facility which provisioning PCI device extra information to
Nova besides the vendor_id/product_id.

blueprint pci-extra-info-provisioning

Change-Id: I1812022c748b1232c3ca763c4e3611fd0af738ea

commit_message:
Propose: Implement percentage-based RAM Weigher

Continuation of the bp normalize-scheduler-weights. This blueprint is
targeted on the adaptation of the RAMWeigher to be able to use
percentages (i.e. relative values) for scheduling.

Change-Id: Ie4b83bbdca3617b8d3910803e422895f90acc69e
Implements: blueprint ram-as-percentage

commit_message:
Propose associate least recently used fixed IP address

This blueprint would associate the least recently used fixed IP address
instead of the first available one.

Related to blueprint associate-lru-fixed-ip-address

Change-Id: Id7ff0e0c2a2d83178f448e12c399d01a5e9b2716

commit_message:
Don't try to install if packages is empty

After running through pkg-map we could have no packages to install,
if so, don't attempt to run a malformed command.

Change-Id: Idc37f037e6416e3cf00f054f8d40926cac0818be

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-05-03 12:49:47.000000000', 'message': 'support multiple image backends for libvirt driver

Currently, the cloud administrator can not choose ephemeral storage backend
device (e.g. SSD or non-SSD) and driver (e.g. qcow2 or ceph) for per flavor.
The lack of these features restrict the price strategy for different
performance and functional requirements. So we should add support to
configure multiple libvirt image backends, and then in the flavor
indicate which backend should be used for per instance.

Related to blueprint libvirt-multiple-image-backends

Change-Id: I9c30f2cc15357301f033a2d10c2f9da464e8247b
'}]
commit_message:
support multiple image backends for libvirt driver

Currently, the cloud administrator can not choose ephemeral storage backend
device (e.g. SSD or non-SSD) and driver (e.g. qcow2 or ceph) for per flavor.
The lack of these features restrict the price strategy for different
performance and functional requirements. So we should add support to
configure multiple libvirt image backends, and then in the flavor
indicate which backend should be used for per instance.

Related to blueprint libvirt-multiple-image-backends

Change-Id: I9c30f2cc15357301f033a2d10c2f9da464e8247b

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-07 09:00:16.000000000', 'message': "HyperV nova driver enhancement to create highly available instances

This blueprint creating-hyperv-ha-instances allows creating of highly
available instances in a HyperV hosts that are in a failover cluster.
Highly available virtual machines are defined by the the document
http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc967323.aspx as
'Highly available virtual machines, also known as HAVMs, can easily be
migrated to a different virtual machine host in a failover cluster to provide
continuing service when their current host needs maintenance. If their current
host fails, the HAVMs automatically migrate to a different host in the cluster
through a process known as failover.'

Change-Id: Ia2abf97d9d42ad37ac237d0457471e0533ff1945
blueprint: creating-hyperv-ha-instances
"}, {'created': '2014-07-07 09:09:28.000000000', 'message': "HyperV nova driver enhancement to create highly available instances

This blueprint creating-hyperv-ha-instances allows creating of highly
available instances in a HyperV hosts that are in a failover cluster.
Highly available virtual machines are defined by the the document
http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc967323.aspx as
'Highly available virtual machines, also known as HAVMs, can easily be
migrated to a different virtual machine host in a failover cluster to provide
continuing service when their current host needs maintenance. If their current
host fails, the HAVMs automatically migrate to a different host in the cluster
through a process known as failover.'

commit_message:
HyperV nova driver enhancement to create highly available instances

This blueprint creating-hyperv-ha-instances allows creating of highly
available instances in a HyperV hosts that are in a failover cluster.
Highly available virtual machines are defined by the the document
http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc967323.aspx as
'Highly available virtual machines, also known as HAVMs, can easily be
migrated to a different virtual machine host in a failover cluster to provide
continuing service when their current host needs maintenance. If their current
host fails, the HAVMs automatically migrate to a different host in the cluster
through a process known as failover.'

Change-Id: Ia2abf97d9d42ad37ac237d0457471e0533ff1945
blueprint: creating-hyperv-ha-instances

commit_message:
Initial step towards instance-level snapshots

This feature aims to implement an initial step towards achieving
per-instance transaction snapshots of all attached volumes.

Change-Id: I3f574c194b1e4d6cb2eb7f99f84cdbc200f94c4b

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

Hi John,

I had submitted it in June, and on 26th June your comment was that this looks fine. The only dependency was the cinder team to approve the cinder driver. The cinder team hasn't approved it yet but has asked us to start the code review. I believe they may have a deadline later than 10th July.

So I request you to approve this spec so that we can start the code review process for nova also. The two drivers go together so if we get only the cinder driver but not the nova driver then it's only a partial solution."}]

commit_message:
EMC: ScaleIO Data Client (SDC) Libvirt Driver

This blueprint proposes to add a libvirt driver for the support of SDC
(ScaleIO Data Client) connected volumes. The addition of SDC support to
libvirt will be leveraged by Nova to attach/detach volumes provided by
products such as EMC ScaleIO and ECS (Elastic Cloud Storage).

blueprint emc-sdc-libvirt-driver

CCLA SCHEDULE B SUBMISSION

Change-Id: I5b866be6ba3103e8c2603d1ab6d5fe8a5f2f03e8

commit_message:
Implement policy should be enforced at REST API layer

This is proposed blueprint for implementing policy should be enforced
at REST API layer for ec2, v2 and v2.1/v3 API. And provide consistent
policy rule for v2.1/v3 API.

Part of blueprint v3-api-policy

commit_message:
Revert updates to NetworkInterfaces and SubnetId

Revert "Make sure NetworkInterfaces and SubnetId updatable".

This reverts commit 0ddd9e0d9f6298500b8f0d7c2c847b7c254de2b0.

Reason is that AWS supports updates to NetworkInterfaces and SubnetId
properties only in UpdateReplace manner [1].

[1] http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-ec2-instance.html

Conflicts:
	heat/engine/resources/instance.py
	heat/tests/test_instance.py

Change-Id: I8ea301610c20b4c65328cae7c6d35fcc9626a562
Closes-Bug: #1340065

(11 comments)

Hi Khanh, thx for your proposal. I feel like there are a number of problems with the spec, as I've commented inline. Overall, I would say that the policy-based scheduling feels like it's overkill and more complex than it needs to be. Perhaps I could change my mind if the spec were written to include examples of how the end-user would work with this new policy-based scheduler. As it stands now, the spec is pretty confusing to me.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-23 16:21:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

commit_message:
Create a scheduler that functions based on policies defined by admin.

This blueprint proposes a new scheduler that allows admin to apply different
policies to different part of the infrastructures or different projects while
performing scheduling. Admin can define scheduling rules for each client,
each aggreggate, each availabiloity-zone or the whole infrastructure
separatedly. Admin can also modify these rules in real time without restarting
the scheduler.

Change-Id: I34dec5ae73514389dd439cf20b9124ea0e4a875e
Implements: blueprint policy-based-scheduler

commit_message:
Blueprint to enable tls mode for spice/vnc console

In this blueprint, we aim to connect to spice/vnc console
of the vm using SSL wrapped socket, if enabled in the configuration.

Part of blueprint console-tls-mode

Change-Id: Ia44a9814f27bbed8af5e229e896cc6b315ca012d

OK, so I am not sure its the best cinder driver in the world, but it could be a nice thing for some small private clouds with odd types of external storage.

Personally I would love to have seen the attaching of the "parent" shared storage volume automated, but at least it is well documented what the deployer has to do.

Anyway, it could easily be expanded in the future to have connection parameters for the "parent" volume, and references other volume drivers. So this seems like a nice evolutionary step in that direction.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2014-07-10 18:41:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I messed up here, joe is correct, we would like to see the cinder part approved first, and it looks like cinder have rejected this.

Sorry, this blueprint has missed the Juno spec approval freeze 10 July:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-July/039259.html
Please consider re-submitting when we open nova-specs for the K release.
If you are wanting an exception, please raise this in the next nova-meeting.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2014-07-16 11:25:01.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-06-03 19:21:41.000000000', 'message': 'LVM: Support a volume-gorup on shared storage

Current LVM cinder driver only supports iSCSI topology and a guest instance
on nova compute is connected to a cinder volume(logical volume) on a
volume-group via iSCSI target.

This proposal adds a feature to connect cinder volume to an instance directly
using LVM on a shared storage volume.

As a result, an instance which uses cinder volume can directly issue I/O to
volumes via FC and this provides better I/O performance to a instance.

In this feature, both cinder and nova pieces are necessary, and blueprint
for cinder piece was already approved.

Change-Id: Ifdce68ef859e9cd2936f8678c9c49d8066d67704
Implements: blueprint lvm-driver-for-shared-storage

commit_message:
LVM: Support a volume-group on shared storage

Current LVM cinder driver only supports iSCSI topology and a guest instance
on nova compute is connected to a cinder volume(logical volume) on a
volume-group via iSCSI target.

This proposal adds a feature to connect cinder volume to an instance directly
using LVM on a shared storage volume.

As a result, an instance which uses cinder volume can directly issue I/O to
volumes via FC and this provides better I/O performance to a instance.

In this feature, both cinder and nova pieces are necessary, and blueprint
for cinder piece was already approved.

Change-Id: Ifdce68ef859e9cd2936f8678c9c49d8066d67704
Implements: blueprint lvm-driver-for-shared-storage

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-11 13:53:47.000000000', 'message': "Cinder-api service throws error on SIGHUP signal

Added reset method in WSGIService class.

After adding reset method when SIGHUP signal is sent to
wsgi service parent process,then it sends SIGHUP signal
to all of its child processes. Each child process handles
SIGHUP signal by first stopping the service and then calls
service start method again. When it stops the service, it
kills the eventlet thread, which internally closes the wsgi
server socket object. This server socket object is now not
usable again and it throws following error, while restarting
the service:

error: [Errno 9] Bad file descriptor

To resolve 'Bad file descriptor' error, creating duplicate
socket object, every time service starts.

Closes-Bug: #1337796

Change-Id: Iab32a3fe230a11692a8cad274304214247d6c2c6

commit_message:
Cinder-api service throws error on SIGHUP signal

Added reset method in WSGIService class.

After adding reset method when SIGHUP signal is sent to
wsgi service parent process,then it sends SIGHUP signal
to all of its child processes. Each child process handles
SIGHUP signal by first stopping the service and then calls
service start method again. When it stops the service, it
kills the eventlet thread, which internally closes the wsgi
server socket object. This server socket object is now not
usable again and it throws following error, while restarting
the service:

error: [Errno 9] Bad file descriptor

To resolve 'Bad file descriptor' error, creating duplicate
socket object, every time service starts.

Closes-Bug: #1337796

Change-Id: Iab32a3fe230a11692a8cad274304214247d6c2c6

make nova hypervisor to list available resources for scheduling

This will make nova hypervisor-* to return the current available
resources for scheduling on the host.

Change-Id: I18030a9c0400807731b880b6fdbf12b13b26c7be

commit_message:
Add missing DeprecationWarning category to warning

This is a deprecation warning but it lacks the category specifier
for DeprecationWarning.

Change-Id: I4f31c2cd64b94564ff53d944cae36bff472491d4

subject: Only allow admins to delete VMs from down compute nodes
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 91, 'name': 'Alvaro', 'email': 'aloga@ifca.unican.es', 'username': 'aloga'}, {'_account_id': 1297, 'name': 'Joshua Harlow', 'email': 'jxharlow@godaddy.com', 'username': 'harlowja'}, {'_account_id': 1298, 'name': 'Ken Thomas', 'email': 'krt@yahoo-inc.com', 'username': 'krt'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 5441, 'name': 'Andrew Laski', 'email': 'andrew@lascii.com', 'username': 'alaski'}, {'_account_id': 10165, 'name': 'Marco Morais', 'email': 'mmorais@yahoo-inc.com', 'username': 'mmorais'}, {'_account_id': 11801, 'name': 'Trey Hoehne', 'email': 'trey.hoehne@rackspace.com', 'username': 'Treyhoehne'}]

[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-02 21:38:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2014-06-02 21:38:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-03 04:05:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGit#Test_Failures

- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/50/97350/1/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/ec4186b : FAILURE in 45s
- gate-nova-specs-docs http://logs.openstack.org/50/97350/1/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/4471804 : FAILURE in 29s'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2014-06-03 17:28:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2014-06-03 17:45:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I see a big issue with this change, and that is that the lifetime of an instance has billing implications in some cloud environments.  And telling a user that they have to continue paying for their instance because some piece of infrastructure is down is not going to go well.

As an alternative I would suggest that a better job could be done of handling these deleted instances on compute startup.'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2014-06-03 18:30:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Good point. One way to deal with the billing issue is for those clusters to set the config option to keep the old behavior.'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2014-06-03 19:38:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-03 22:49:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-03 22:50:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-03 23:47:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/50/97350/3/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/2ea652b : SUCCESS in 29s
- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/50/97350/3/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/1e428f0/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 45s'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2014-06-04 07:50:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I don't think this is the right approach for solving this issue.

IMHO the problem should be solved by cleaning the instance and its IP when the compute node is restored. Moreover, a user should be abstracted from the details of the underlying infrastructure (the user may not even knot what a compute node is).

Also, there's a problem with billing (as staged by Andrew), but also with quotas: the user will be accounted (and its quota consumed) for resources he is not using."}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2014-06-04 13:46:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I respectfully disagree.

There may be times that you *do* want the VMs on a down compute node to come back up.  (Maybe someone just tripped over the power cable and there's really nothing wrong.) There are other times that you don't. (Maybe the compute node caught on fire and is now a heap of molten slag.) Giving the admin the ability to choose to clean up or not without having users corrupt things in the meantime is what this is all about. 

About the billing issue... as I mentioned before, we're proposing that there be a config setting so that folks can specify the current behavior if they find that fits into their business model better.

As for mentioning the compute nodes to the users... We don't have to phrase the error message that way.  Something as simple as "Sorry, we're unable to delete your VM at the moment. Please try again later or contact your admin" would probably take care of that. I'm open to suggestions.

The bottom line is that we will be using this change here at Yahoo because we've learned the hard way that it's dangerous otherwise. We would prefer not to continue doing this as a local patch.  It's a very small and simple change ( ~5 lines of code) that could save some other folks the pain that we've gone through.'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2014-06-04 14:45:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi again Ken.

I agree that there are a lot of scenarios when you want the machines running in a node to come up again, so where I said: "the problem should be solved by cleaning the instance and its IP when the compute node is restored" I should have added "if the instance has been deleted when the node was offline".

I do agree that this may impose a problem if the machine is restored but it was deleted when the machine was in downtime, but I think the change you're proposing is a wrong approach. In my opinion it is simpler and much more consistent across deployments to just ensure that the instances and their IPs should be there when the compute node comes up again. If they have been deleted, just delete them.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2014-06-04 15:02:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I agree with Alvaro, who has stated the alternative approach better than I did.'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2014-06-04 15:37:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Would you please point me to where this alternative change would go?  I'm not familiar with the compute node processing, but I thought that the VMs would boot up as soon as the host is restarted whether or not the nova-compute process starts."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2014-06-05 13:32:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Take a look in _init_instance in nova/compute/manager.py as a likely place to update.

If your hypervisor is starting VMs after a reboot regardless of their previous state that seems like a bug with the hypervisor to me.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2014-06-05 13:38:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Nvm, I've missed the point slightly about what's happening.

I can see a couple of possibilities here.  Rather than just doing a local delete if the compute service is down perhaps it should retry for a short period of time.  And if a hypervisor is down longer than that period of time then maybe it's better to evacuate the instances than bring them up on that node again.

There's likely other better options as well, but ultimately I think a users delete needs to be honored no matter what is going on behind the scenes."}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2014-06-05 14:06:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Having an automatic recovery/clean up sounds like a fine idea, but there are installations like ours where we would prefer to avoid the potential mess in the first place.

How about a two pronged approach?

For clusters like ours, we have this proposed feature in and enabled in the configuration.  Anybody who chooses to restrict this type of user initiated corruption is free to do so.

For other clusters, where billing/quota is more important, then the feature is disabled in the configuration.  Things work exactly as they do today and any automatic retry/recovery/clean up can take place once its been implemented.

Seriously guys, this is a five line change that saves us (and potentially other folks) a whole lot of grief. As I've said, we would prefer not to do this as a local patch but it has saved us so much time and effort that we can't survive without it. I do believe that as other folks scale up, there are going to be other folks who would appreciate the flexibility of enabling admin only local deletes when the compute node is down.  If they don't want it, then don't enable it."}, {'account_id': 11801, 'date': '2014-06-05 15:15:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I tend to agree with Andrew on honoring the user delete no matter what is going on behind the scenes. At the root of it changing the API's default behavior based on a config option seems incorrect. Instead of a config option could this use case be served by an API extension that adds this functionality?"}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2014-06-05 16:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I think we have a basic disagreement then.  

We feel that preventing the situation is better than trying to recover from it. We feel that the admin should have the flexibility to have final word on whether to allow this behavior or not.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2014-06-05 19:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10165, 'date': '2014-06-05 19:35:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Trey and @Andrew: Your point about having the API behave differently based on configuration setting seems valid.  Instead could we change the behavior for all deployments such that when a user attempts to delete a resource which is on compute node which is down, the operation is instead converted to a suspend.  This has the following benefits:

* the user can choose to resume the instance when and if the compute node comes back online

* the user does not accrue billing charges associated with a running instance

* should the compute node come back up, the user's instance is not automatically started avoiding the ip race condition described by Ken (and other similar race conditions which might arise)"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-05 21:46:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I agree with those that have already said this is the wrong approach to solving the problem - the instance belongs to the user and if they want to delete it they must always be able to do that.  The state of the compute node (and the Server and VM could be up with just nova-compute down) shouldn't come into it.   That's an infrastructure problem that shouldn't be exposed to the user.

Suspend instead isn't an option - you can't assume that has less billing impacts than delete.

The problem stated at the top of the commit is to avoid the possibility of multiple VMs using the same IP.   This presumably is only a nova-net issue then (as the API will server will still call Neutron to delete ports for a local delete of an instance) - so we shouldn't be making major changes at this stage to work around a nova-net issue.    And secondly I thought nova-net already doesn't free up IP addresses until some time after the VM was deleted and the lease expired - specifically to avoid this kind of issue."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-06 14:37:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2014-07-06 14:37:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

I agree with Phil, this isn't the correct solution for the stated issue. I would rather try to fix this issue directly in nova-network versus working around it here."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-06 14:39:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/50/97350/3/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/0435903 : SUCCESS in 38s
- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/50/97350/3/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/c911064/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 49s'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2014-07-07 13:37:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Just curious, is there any point in changing the title of this to "Give admins an option to control local deletes from down compute nodes"?

Fixing the underlying issue is a Big Deal. Making things a little better by giving admins the ability (if they wish) to control the situation is trivial.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2014-07-10 19:18:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Ken, I would rather focus on fixing the root cause instead of working around it.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-10 19:18:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-10 19:21:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Sorry, this blueprint has missed the Juno spec approval freeze 10 July:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-July/039259.html
Please consider re-submitting when we open nova-specs for the K release.

commit_message:
Only allow admins to delete VMs from down compute nodes

Only allow admins to do local deletes to avoid the possibility of
multiple VMs using the same IP.

Change 1: Fix RST syntax errors

Change 2: Fix a couple of typos

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

Ok, I see your point. Leaving some hosts for evacuation purposes only was just an example of utilizing the 'action_type' field in filters or weighers. I didn't assume to create such functionality. I just wanted to point out that 'action_type' could be useful for people wanting to create their own scheduling algorithms. In the above example, user would need to create his own filter and basing on the host aggregates extra specs and 'action_type' he could very easily achieve the functionality of leaving some hosts for evacuation purposes. I will describe this in details in the specification and commit it again. 

There is really no advanced logic in the implementation of this blueprint. My use case of 'action_type' is for reporting purposes - in my custom filter I create an instantiation report and save the information what action triggered the scheduling. But this is only my use case and the others can also benefit from this change."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-08 13:02:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Action type aware scheduling.

Blueprint proposes to add "action_type" key to "filter_properties"
so that filters and weighers could be aware of currently processed
action (scheduling / rescheduling / migration / resize / live-migration
/ evacuation / unshelving).

Change-Id: I36624233b5d436aedcb289848e6fd5e535efa1c7

[{'created': '2014-06-18 16:33:09.000000000', 'message': 'Make resize opertaions that attempt to reduce disk size an error

Current hypervisors have a range of checks against reduction in disk size for
resize operations, ranging from checking root and ephemeral to not checking at
all. Blocking any resize operation to a flavor with less disk capacity will
provide a better and more consistent user experience.

Change-Id: Ie95cb7a67d0d0de5a257a4f4cdb1a5779529ae90
'}, {'created': '2014-06-18 17:38:22.000000000', 'message': 'Fail resize operations that attempt to reduce disk size

Current hypervisors have a range of checks against reduction in disk size for
resize operations, ranging from checking root and ephemeral to not checking at
all. Blocking any resize operation to a flavor with less disk capacity will
provide a better and more consistent user experience.

Change-Id: Ie95cb7a67d0d0de5a257a4f4cdb1a5779529ae90
'}]
commit_message:
Fail resize operations that attempt to reduce disk size

Current hypervisors have a range of checks against reduction in disk size for
resize operations, ranging from checking root and ephemeral to not checking at
all. Blocking any resize operation to a flavor with less disk capacity will
provide a better and more consistent user experience.

Change-Id: Ie95cb7a67d0d0de5a257a4f4cdb1a5779529ae90

given cluster. This work provides a nova client extension, and a corresponding

easily get the current resource availability data, which is same as those

commit_message:
make nova host-describe to return available resources seen by scheduler

Currently, there is no easy way to check the current available 
resources on a given hypervisor. This work extends 'nova host-describe'
to also return available resources, which is same as those seen 
by scheduler.

Change-Id: Ie274f64f151dc9824cbe8e83a2737d660e4bacd6

commit_message:
Standardize Client Parameters

This spec represents one of the goals of the Session work happening
within the clients, to standardize the security and authentication
parameters (and code).

There is ongoing work in the client to define the correct names and
methods of loading the same parameters for multiple clients. To make
sure that that work is accepted I would like to make sure that the
servers are onboard with the direction. Whilst this is for nova if
accepted the same pattern will be deployed to the other services as
well.

Change-Id: Ifce7283dd0ff432b44332d4cc8003dc91936ff71

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2014-06-26 09:42:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

I think we need to go back to the use cases here, and how the billing works.

Currently we can hot-plug a VIF, so the SRIOV work should just use the existing hot plug VIF work. So please exclude NICs from this spec.

When we come to GPU, currently we bill and describe that in the flavor.

And when you request the hotplug, the host may not have the resources it needs to give them to the guest.

Now, we do support "Resize" of an instance which should help you add or remove GPUs from your instance.

So now we need to think about what extra use cases you are adding here, and how this would really work in practice? Would you live-migrate somewhere that has a PCI device to passthrough? How does this scale and work with the scheduling system?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-26 09:46:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified-1

commit_message:
Support pci passthrough device hotplug

Add the ability to hotplug and hotunplug a pci passthrough device
to an instance.

blueprint pci-hotplug

Change-Id: I19ef76c2c5aa127fa33f5a163bcdca46d6475f24

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/99/94299/4/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/5455986/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 33s'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-06-02 15:52:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I'm not sold on the idea that this is something that needs a public REST API.

Also a concern for me:

1) The sheer amount of fixed IPs returned from the proposed call to GET /os-fixed-ips when using a FlatDHCP model potentially makes this REST API call a non-starter. For class A subnets, the list of available IPs is absolutely huge.

2) I don't see why tenants would need this information, or even why anyone other than the cloud operator would need this information. The number and specific IP addresses available for tenants to use is technically an implementation detail for the deployment, and I'm not sure it makes sense to expose this information in a tenant-facing API (as opposed to, say, a nova-manage command)

3) The spec should state under Alternatives that the standard solution for this on the operator side -- to get number of available *floating* addresses is to issue a database query in some NRPE check script and alert when under a specific threshold.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 10263, 'date': '2014-06-02 21:58:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-02 21:58:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 10263, 'date': '2014-06-02 22:00:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-02 22:00:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 10263, 'date': '2014-06-02 22:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Jay,

[1] Makes sense. It won't work for flatDHCP model, since the db wont
give you the required information. Also, if you have a bunch of class A
subnets, this query will be extremely costly.. It would make sense to
return just the number of available Ips by default, and keep returned list
of ip's part configurable. It might also help to return list of available ips
for a particular network.

[2] nova-manage might be deprecated soon(https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg15028.html). And who can run what command can be controlled through policy. Also, makes sense to keep this command operator-only.

[3] Updated the "Alternative" section. I guess here you are recommending a direct DB query, which is what we are trying to avoid. With underlying database schema changes there are higher risk of the DB query failure and hence such an extension here. We can keep this alternative but this is dangerous and prone to human error. Hence the
extension makes sense.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-03 04:33:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified+1

commit_message:
Set up brocadeport up to models

In models for brocadeport for columns admin_state_up and network_id
have nullable=False, but it was skipped in migrations. Also vlan_id
have type Sring(10) instead of String(36).

Partial-Bug: #1337185

Change-Id: I882a9ec08ad47b195a0604b1bcb36a65b283faeb

commit_message:
libvirt/linux_net refactor to work on FreeBSD

A proposal to implement freebsd_net and refactor libvirt.vif
module not use use only linux_net, but allow to choose
what network driver to use.

Change-Id: Ic9fe64da5c0a4c605ca9aae03de05520a62b880d

So I think keeping them separate makes the most sense.  However, if it will make the process go faster we can also combine them."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2014-04-17 21:27:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

If you think these are separate blueprints with the other one dependent on this, can you clarify that. When reading the problem statement in both I see almost the same thing.

A few more things:
* You mention download methods, can you add a link to that blueprint. If I remember correctly that is only partially completed.
* The proposed change doesn't align with the scope of the problem etc. can you clarify the blueprint to clearly identify what the long term things are and what the immediate problem this is solving."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-04-21 18:21:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 8430, 'date': '2014-04-21 18:21:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-04-21 18:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 8430, 'date': '2014-04-21 18:32:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Did my best to address concerns raised in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/85768/ and combined Blueprints since that was the feedback.  Also worked to address:

download methods - this isn't related too a partially completed blueprint.  It was to give drivers the option to choose download method since some drivers (Xen) already have this as configuration magic.
