(16 comments)

Looking close.

I don't think we should have the "download_method" in the API. We don't want driver specific details leaking out the API, and its easier to just not add that attribute for now.

Probably should mention work to add python-novaclient support for the new API.

I worry there is currently no way to find out success vs error for this operation. I presume the rest API will cast a message to the compute (so not sure how you find the 412 error?). Adding a new notifications (start/end/error, etc) might a the easiest way to do that. While not a pure API, it seems workable for most use cases, and has minimal maintenance, as it should have.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-23 14:54:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Sorry I'm coming in a bit late to the discussion here, but I'm really not sure about the whole approach of making this an action that is performed on specific nodes one at a time.

It feels that capturing the desired state and having a period task that converges on that would be much easier to operate.  So for example if did this via aggregates we could:

- Create an aggregate with metadata to say which images should be pre-cached.
- Add host to that aggregate to define which host we want to have do this
- Have a periodic task that looks for and maintains the pre-cached images (as part of the existing image cache management) 
- It also makes it really easy to change the list of pre-cached images across multiple hosts in one operation
- And by using an aggregate it makes it easy to expose this to the scheduler"}, {'account_id': 8430, 'date': '2014-05-23 14:55:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

(12 comments)

Thanks for feedback. Adding notifications makes sense.  I think that's something I can add in the next few days.  I want feedback from belliott on removing the download_method.  I'm not opposed to this in the Juno release cycle.  It will make some other things a bit more challenging, but doable.  That being said, I think I was in the middle with download_method vs. nothing vs. all options in metadata."}, {'account_id': 8430, 'date': '2014-05-23 16:09:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8430, 'date': '2014-05-23 16:14:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Phil,

My understanding is the service idea was discussed at the summit and viewed as too controversial to consider for Juno.  We are looking at putting up a service implementation on stackforge to handle this.  Right now the consensus view was to keep the service outside nova.  So we are considering what is needed from an admin API point of view to support that service.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2014-05-23 16:29:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

@phil my memory of the conversation is that we need to co-ordinate which hosts do the download, so they don't Denial of service each other. Hence there is some cross host orchestration.

That kind of thing (inter host orchestration) we kinda decided to be out of scope for nova (for the moment), so we are creating the APIs for such a thing to use, given it lives outside of nova, hence this now reduced scope of this spec/blueprint.

I think the plan is that what rackspace produce for the co-ordination will go on stackforge for now. If that helps cushion the blow?"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-23 16:58:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I'd of thought it was possible to add sufficiently randomness into the periodic task to make the downloads sufficently staggered to avoid the Glance issue - its not as if getting the image pre-cahced onto all of the nodes is time critical - so it could be configured via teh agregate to span 10's of minutes.   The image is going to be in the Glance cache as soon as the first download starts, so why is this seen as a much bigger load than Glance has to cope with when starting a large number of instances (which may be needing images that Glance hasn't cached) ?

Doing this kind of thing one node at a time and then having to manage the consistency across node that may have been off line really sucks in practice"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-24 06:35:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

You can also control the rate/concurrency at which servers download images by controlling the rate at which servers are added or removed to/from the aggregate.  For example suppose Agg_Images_1 is set up to contain the initial list of images to be pre-cached, and severs are then added to X per minute.   Then when the list needs to be changes Agg_Images_2 is set up with the revised list, and servers are moved between Agg_Images_a and Agg_Images_2 at a rate of X per minute.

This would use an existing Nova mechanism, no need for a new API, provide a simple stateful view of the current state of image pre-caching, and be very simple to extend to scheduling.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-27 05:07:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: -Verified

Sorry - but I don;t see any of my comments about this could be achieved via aggregates being addressed so far.

At the very least I think they need to be included in alternatives - but I still haven't seen any answer as to why this can't be better implemented using aggregates rather than introducing a new set of APIs and external mgmt tooling to both load and then audit / manage which hosts have which images cached onto them."}, {'account_id': 8430, 'date': '2014-05-28 18:21:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Apologies Phil.  I can definitely add some discussion to the alternatives section.  As discussed by John this falls into that category of how much are we ready to put into nova.  Using the aggregates would in effect mean we dump the service proposal into nova now.  That's the line of the discussion (my understanding) where folks were not comfortable.  

On a strictly pragmatic point, aggregates are not supported everywhere (ie. cells) which is one of the places this feature would be most useful."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2014-05-28 18:21:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Code-Review+1

Regarding aggregates - I don't think one should be forced to define host aggregates in order to use pre-caching.  They seem like separate concerns.

Listing the aggregate discussion under alternatives might be worthwhile."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-29 12:36:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)

Ok, I'm not exactly wild about the concept of "code being ready" taking precedence over whether we have the best/right design, because that was exactly the kind of issue that the nova-specs review was meant to address, and from a deployer perspective this still feels like a more un-wieldy solution.

If having it for cells meant that it had to wait for cells to support aggregates (which is also already planned I think) then I'd be inclined to wait for that.

However since you seem to be really keen to push on with this can live with the aggregates design being covered in the alternatives (even if I do still think its a much better design :-).

There is also an in-line comment asking for a clarification on a couple of points.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-05 19:22:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: -Verified

Sorry I missed you comments on patch set 13 - I think you do need to explain about how the pre-cahed images wil be sticky. Currently the compute manager will by default delete all unused base images after 24 hours (virt/imagecache.py) which seems counter to what you're trying to achieve here.

If the intent is that admins have to keep re-doing the pre caching then that needs to be covered.

The arguments against the aggregate design in the alternatives section aren't valid.  If as previous stated the reason for going ahead is because code is already written then I think it should be openly recoded as such"}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2014-06-08 15:12:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Thanks for the clarifications.

I'm going to stay a -1 on this because to me its trying to add functionality that just doesn't integrate with the exiting image management which I think will be a significant source of confusion for users.

Specifically as proposed the new call will pre-cache an image onto a server as a one-off activity, and that image will only remain pre-cached until the image cache management code removes it.  Admins have to then make periodic calls into the API to re-cache the images.  As a public cloud operator I just can't see this being a significantly useful addition to the system for what feels like a pretty small optimisation given the existing image caching.

There are hints that this will at some point be integrated with the scheduler, but since stickiness and management of cached images are out of scope for this change I'm not convinced that this approach lays the groundwork for that really."}, {'account_id': 8430, 'date': '2014-06-20 21:49:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Thanks for the feedback.  I think it's a bit unfair to say that this is a small optimization for public cloud providers where the specific problem they are solving today is launching 1500+ VMs in a very short period of time (under an hour) and would like to prepay the the download cost.  

The current alternative is to boot VMs and/or custom backend fill scripts which have to understand the caching strategy of the driver."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-20 21:49:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: -Verified

Chris,

If Phil is right and the per-node image cache management will fight against the pre-cache code, I agree that's a problem that needs to be addressed."}, {'account_id': 8430, 'date': '2014-06-25 19:02:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

If we add an eviction command and ask driver's to perform the stickiness is that a reasonable solution.  My concerns with any type of public marking is that we have to unify cache management prior to getting any type of caching in place.  In my mind that's a long road.

If libvirt really does evict every 24 hours unused images regardless of current capacity that's something that should probably also be addressed.  That isn't cache management that's garbage collection."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-25 21:48:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Call it what you will - cache mgmt or garbage collection - there is a form of existing active image management already implemented as part of the compute manager.  I just don't see a good case for adding an additional set of APIs to trigger  load/re-load/evacuate commands, including now having to save state in terms of "stickyness" somewhere when that existing functionality could be simply extended to do the same job based on aggregate properties.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-25 21:49:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

... which then also easily extends into scheduling.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2014-06-26 17:21:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Phil, I disagree a bit on using aggregate properties for this.  I think there's value in having an api to the image cache that aggregate properties could use for this behaviour, but I don't think that those properties should be the api.  This feature has value without being coupled to aggregates.  Though I do think that aggregates are the way to expose this to the scheduler as you've mentioned."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-27 21:04:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Hi Andrew,  My main concerns are that at the moment this BP doesn't address either how the pre-caching will integrate with the existing cache manager in the compute manager, or how the list of pre-cached images will be made available to the scheduler.

Both of those would seem to require the list of images that are intended to be pre-cached to be saved somewhere, and it seems to me that aggregates could be an elegant way of handling this (since the already provide the concept of a set of hosts that share some configuration the scheduler needs to be aware of), but I'm open to alternatives providing the do address those two points."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2014-06-30 15:51:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Can we explicitly declare cache management policy to be out of scope here?  It's something that's done inside the virt driver and these blueprint doesn't dictate how drivers will implement the pre-caching requests.

My hope is we can then punt the "how should the eviction policy" work to another driver-specific specs so we can move forward.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-30 15:52:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: -Verified

Starting check jobs.

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-01 22:54:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-02 22:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

So I get the use case for showing the names instead of the IDs, but this kind of ID to name mapping feels like its something that belongs more in the nova-client shell layer than in the Nova API itself.

For example the client already maps locally between server names and servers uuids.

So the client shell could (optionally) take the IDs that Nova already returns and then do the lookup directly to Keystone to get the names.

But the Nova API should IMO just stay at the level of using and reporting IDs.'}, {'account_id': 8515, 'date': '2014-05-05 20:58:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Phil,

I was going through your comment. I dont know which part of the code you are talking about when you say - "client already maps locally between server names and servers uuids"

I see that, when nova api responds to servers/detail, 

{
  "servers": [
    {
      "status": "ACTIVE",
      "username": "spandhe",
      "updated": "2014-05-02T01:13:05Z",
      "hostId": "some_id",
      "OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host": "hv1",
      "addresses": {
        "default": [
        ]
      },
      },
      "id": "uuid",
      "OS-SRV-USG:terminated_at": null,
      "OS-EXT-AZ:availability_zone": "nova",
      "user_id": "uuid",
      "name": "test9",
      "created": "2014-05-02T01:12:29Z",
      "tenant_id": "uuid",
      "hostname": "abc.test",
      "OS-DCF:diskConfig": "MANUAL",
      "os-extended-volumes:volumes_attached": [
      ],
  ]
}

Also, for nova-client to be able to fetch this information directly from keystone-client without any help from nova api, keystone-client would have to be a dependency for nova-client, which doesn't seem like the default case right now. If we decide to implement this blueprint that way, we will have to add that dependency.

Please let me know if my understanding is correct.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-07 18:09:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Shraddah,

Sorry for the confusion - what I meant to say is that the Nova client already does name to id mapping for operations like "nova delete <name>"  so that it can proved a more friendly interface that the ID base API.  My point being that ID to name mapping as a convinence is better handled (IMO) in the client than adding it into the API as such.

In this specific case user_id and project_id are really just foreign keys in Nova, so making the Nova API server always do an additional round trip to Keystone to add in the name when for the (possibly few) cases where this is required the client layer could do that itself just feels the wrong model.

Making the nova client depend on the keystone client is probably something needed anyway to add Keystone V3 support - and better than making Nova itself depend on the Keytstone client.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-07 18:09:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-07 18:14:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

I think return the user information for 'nova list' should be helpful, but I agree with Phil that the translation from user_id to user_name should not be in scope of nova API, but in client, and that will make things easier."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-24 01:30:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Hi Phil and Yunhong,

The only concern I have with that approach is, with this support on server side, there is an option to cache the userlist, whereas we cant do that on client side. That makes it a bit more expensive on client side.

Please let me know your opinions on that.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-30 23:23:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Verified

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-13 14:14:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Re the ability to cache user names on the client side; I kind of worry about caching any foreign information in Nova when we have no way to know if its fixed or current.  We've been caching network info from Neutron for a long time and its been a very brittle part of the system.

If in can be cached for peformance reasons it should be by the Keystone API servers, not in nova.   

Caching in the Nova client on per request basis (i.e. so you only have to look up each tenant once per list) would be OK"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-13 14:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

commit_message:
Add username in the response of nova list command

Description: Currently nova list command does not show which user the
particular VM belong too. In enterprise deployments, knowing which user
booted the VM could be very useful for the cluster administrator.
This will save admin a lot of manual steps before knowing the owner of
the VM. In this blueprint, we plan to add an additional column
'username' to 'nova list' output which will facilitate cluster
maintenance for the administrator

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/add-username-in-nova-list-response

Change-Id: Ib729572431d343ce240079e4af33f396a935e7ba

commit_message:
Generic Hardware Discovery Bits

This specification tries to set some common ground for future work on
hardware discovery, so that we don't end up with bunch of completely
incompatible implementations of the same things.

Change-Id: I7b701a87b3ed65996fe6e28ecb350d3aa64d73da

[{'created': '2014-07-11 11:05:10.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for cinder scheduler hints

When booting an instance with nova boot --block-device-mapping i.e.
allowing Nova to autocreate storage for a new instance, there is
currently no way for Nova to hint to the Cinder scheduler how it
should go about creating/placing this volumes. This blueprint
proposes adding support for storing cinder scheduler hints in Nova
flavor extra-specs and adding in support for those hints to be
passed to Cinder when volumes are created.

Change-Id: If79cdcdc31b570e2d1e16c5ed014242c961417b8

commit_message:
Add support for cinder scheduler hints

When booting an instance with nova boot --block-device i.e.
asking Nova to auto-create storage for a new instance, there
is currently no way for Nova to hint to the Cinder scheduler
how it should go about creating/placing this volumes. This
specification proposes adding support for storing cinder
extra_specs in Nova flavors and passing them to Cinder when
volumes are created.

Change-Id: If79cdcdc31b570e2d1e16c5ed014242c961417b8

This is very well presented and I like it a lot.  I have two concerns though.  The first is that it's not clear what causes a major version bump, but that should be easy enough to explain.  The second concern is something I've brought up on the original proposal, which is that I think it's useful to indicate to a client what has changed with a version increase.  If I see the version go from 2.114 to 2.115 how do I know which call has changed?  Maybe the answer is just to consult some release notes, but it would be nice if there was some signal in the API for that."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2014-06-23 00:25:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

fwiw I don't think we should be trying to describe what API changes occur between version numbers in the API itself (beyond what discoverability we may eventually have with JSON-HOME stuff etc). I think the release notes/documentation is where that should be described."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2014-06-23 15:43:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Christopher:  JSON-HOME does seem to be the answer I'm looking for.  But for this discussion I'm not so much concerned about knowing exactly what changed in a call as I want to know which call changed.

The scenario I'm considering is the following.  I'm a user of some OpenStack cloud and I see that there's an API version increase.  I want to know what might break if I use the newer version, so I want to know if the change is backwards compatible or not and which call has changed if it is backwards incompatible.  Docs may be the answer to this but within a release I'm not sure we'll have docs available to help out users.

An alternative would be to make it clear to users that clients should not use a new global major version until they've consulted docs and tested that they can work with that newer version.  Then it's not important to make it clear in the API which call has changed in a backwards incompatible way.

I'd just like it to be clear to users how they can gather information about API changes."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2014-06-23 17:21:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2014-06-23 18:15:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)

Adding a few thoughts, I will try roll some of this, which some example use cases, into the other micro-version proposal, and see if I can make it much clearer that way.

The main thing this doesn't seem to cover is backwards in-compatible changes that we would like to do. And prehaps some details on the experimental versions. The original proposal doesn't cover these either, but just trying to think them through a little more."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2014-06-23 23:45:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

@Andrew - yes, my preference would be that we tell users not to ask for a later version until they know what they're getting into. I agree docs is an issue now, though the goal is autogenerate them, so although a "diff" may be still hard to generate, they would have a correct reference doc.

I guess we could start up an APIImpact flag as well to make creating an diff document easier as well.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-23 23:45:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-23 23:46:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2014-06-25 13:54:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

Please add more detail in this spec about doc -- and autogeneration especially. If it's in the other spec, refer to that here, but discuss how this alternative proposal would be documented."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2014-06-25 15:58:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2014-06-25 16:08:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Throwing a -1 on this since nobody has for their legit complaints.

Note that I'm very much more in favor of this (so far) than the non-alt microversions patch."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2014-06-25 17:37:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-06-25 21:23:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2014-06-25 22:07:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2014-06-26 10:40:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

The global version, plus versioning of API resources, works for me. Thats basically what I was trying to express in my proposal, but I mixed up resources and extensions, because they are almost the same in the current v3 code base, which was a big mistake, this makes much more sense.

I like experimental versions, because we can add extensions into the code base, get them tested by tempest, and only then graduate them to the stable API.

I dislike the vendor extensions, because it gives the wrong message, but I could live with that for now, I guess. Just calling them "not stable" i.e. experimental would make me happier in terms of messaging.

I think JSON-home seems like a good idea we shouldn't ignore, to notify clients about what is currently available. It might be overkill, but we can version its response too.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2014-06-26 10:41:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2014-06-26 13:24:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2014-06-26 22:50:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@john, experimental extensions won't be added to tempest testing."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2014-06-27 09:08:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I prefer the combination of The global version and each extension version.

since Icehouse, server-group API has been implemented but we have discussed its removal through many mails[1]. So server-group API should be experimental at the time and we need a way to represent each API is stable/experimental.

Anyway now this spec seems non-alternative, better to remove it.

[1]: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-April/033746.html'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-28 11:43:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2014-06-28 11:43:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-28 11:44:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

@all - because the other change was abandoned, I rebased to master. Apparently that lost the votes, sorry about that.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2014-06-28 11:48:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@kenichi I think dual versions are impossibly complex from a consumption perspective.

Past mistakes are past mistakes. In the future server_groups would be experimental only, so wouldn't show up in normal API calls until people decided they really thought it was stable. Then, if it was added, well, it was added. Doesn't matter if it's a bad idea, it needs to be deprecated out.

The global version bump would be used on any compatible adds to the API, deprecations (which is not a surface change, but a signalling to the user), or deletes of deprecated interfaces (whenever we decide that's safe)."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2014-06-30 02:29:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2014-06-30 04:50:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

@Sean

Thanks for your explanation, I maybe got the point.

As I mentioned inline, I agree that APIs can be removed as backwards compatible changes in some cases. Especially we can remove experimental APIs easily. The decorator which is mentioned on this spec would contain nice functions, I prefer it.

I have still some questions.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2014-06-30 08:24:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Alternative take on API microversioning

This is a different take on API microversioning that tries to be
a bit stricter on the design approach. It's done as an -alt in
a second patch so that it can be easily seen at the same time, and
debated independently.

It is far from complete, but seemed more useful to propose this
way versus through gerrit comments.

Change-Id: I72cd4cfdbca6ac499468be82d48b5e9857936bb4

commit_message:
vmware: Enable VCDriver with NFS glance source datastore

It enables the VmwareVCDriver to improve the image
copying process from glance to vmware_temp by
exposing glace image file store as NFS share and
mount it on the vCenter cluster as NFS datastore

Change-Id: I5442a5edafe8358c9ace64e8c260b6a7c89343b7

commit_message:
Refactors VIF configuration logic

There are too many if/else checks when we choose the right function to
conduct vif operations. We can do better by getattr on the nessesary
function obj. The vif type needs normalization to remove periods.

Change-Id: I6bb2af45d3e72bdc11470877fd2a993e9d0a4623

commit_message:
Continue on failure of leaf filters of chaining filters

Currently wrapper.py has an implementation error in chaining filters, which
is expecting match_filter() returns None when no leaf filter matches to
arguments, although it actually raises an exception.

This patch fixes this and adds an unit test for it.

Closes-Bug: #1340792
Change-Id: I1ac4535ad176d78769c497fa037285bc610acadf

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-09 13:45:51.000000000', 'message': 'Use direct mount for puppet docker container

Removing workaround for mount of /etc/puppet
to /puppet, then ln -s /puppet/{files} into
/etc/puppet, because it breaks upgrade schema
where /etc/puppet/$VER is added.

Change-Id: I31470af079bc88ae4303dc511bfe2b1c1c9c2fed
Partial-Bug: #1339688
'}]
commit_message:
Use direct mount for puppet docker container

Removing workaround for mount of /etc/puppet
to /puppet, then ln -s /puppet/{files} into
/etc/puppet, because it breaks upgrade schema
where /etc/puppet/$VER is added.

Change-Id: I31470af079bc88ae4303dc511bfe2b1c1c9c2fed
Partial-Bug: #1339688

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-06-30 18:12:43.000000000', 'message': "Improve a bit performance of Ceilometer

we shouldn't use <array>.extend([<generator>]) it's similiar to
<array>.extend(<generator>) but slower

Change-Id: Ic859e9a477f03b680e1ac0db1498261a3dc24997
"}]
commit_message:
Improve a bit performance of Ceilometer

we shouldn't use <array>.extend([<generator>]) it's similiar to
<array>.extend(<generator>) but slower

Change-Id: Ic859e9a477f03b680e1ac0db1498261a3dc24997

[{'created': '2014-07-13 09:05:53.000000000', 'message': 'Fix swift invocation

swift -m adds X-Account-Meta to each parameter, fix the invocation.

Change-Id: I7989829cd22f040c54b2878ab9c5d17a823eacd9
Closes-Bug: #1325780
'}]
commit_message:
Fix swift invocation

swift -m adds X-Account-Meta to each parameter, fix the invocation.

Change-Id: I7989829cd22f040c54b2878ab9c5d17a823eacd9
Closes-Bug: #1325780

Clean up the endpoint filtering configuration docs

There were a few grammatical errors seen in the docs, this patch
should clean those up.

commit_message:
fixed several pep8 issues

  * E126 continuation line over-indented for hanging indent
  * E127 continuation line over-indented for visual indent
  * E128 continuation line under-indented for visual indent
  * E131 continuation line unaligned for hanging indent
  * E251 unexpected spaces around keyword / parameter equals
  * E265 block comment should start with '# '

Change-Id: I10d5b38f9947e04736fbb58e8fac976f0c10daab

commit_message:
Add unit tests for processing utils

Added following unit tests
test_percentile_value_none
test_percentile_equal

Change-Id: I772bcfae418722371b7abcd525fcf913aef1e01e
Implements: blueprint improve-unit-test-coverage-rally

commit_message:
Add tox as global requirement

At the moment tox is missing on http://pypi.openstack.org/.
When using pypi.openstack.org as PyPi mirror for stack.sh (Devstack)
the script will fail because the requirement tox<1.7.0 can
not be fulfilled.

Change-Id: I560bf669ebe9f01a94790a069cfdbfd07cdf3d95
Closes-Bug: #1316751

commit_message:
Fix nova/network direct use of object modules

This replaces all uses of nova.objects.<module>.<object> with
nova.objects.<object> within nova/network and nova/tests/network.

Change-Id: I6438bcf47e06a401323ea708d5a44c69fa00e967
Partial-Blueprint: object-subclassing

commit_message:
Showing a more representive message when instance launching fails

When an instance launch fails due to the flavor disk or memory
size, user only gets a "No valid host was found." message. Instead
of it, this patch will show a more representative message, which was
already on the code, but wrongly mapped from the exception.

Change-Id: I90866e9b9718bb5aabf36dc4df18d0a2572db993
Closes-bug: 1276696

subject: Add nic state aware scheduling

I recognize Ericsson's desire for "carrier-grade cloud", but this isn't appropriate for Nova's scheduler and resource tracker.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-04-21 17:37:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

'}, {'account_id': 10318, 'date': '2014-04-21 20:02:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Doing this in Nvoa for ensuring the Active traffic ports are up and available before scheduling makes good use of Nova nad ensures that before we call for a VM to be instantiated that the actual traffic links are validated for connectivity at Layer-2 status. External mgmt tools can nto do this adn will never be a good place either. The best place to check and validate the Layer-2 "carrier status" is on the actual host itself. 

If you did choose to do this on an external mgmt tool, and i Strongly discourage folks from doing this you have no way of validating that the L-2 link is actually down, because the external mgmt tool would have to have a direct L-2 connection to the compute host or it would have to issue a cmd to initiate a probe to check the L-2 status between the port on the PCI NIC card and the actual external switch entity. 
The proposed blueprint addresses validating L-2 connectivity state in a simple and efficent manner while ensuring Openstack can be "self contained" and not rely upon external entities.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2014-04-21 20:37:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

'while ensuring Openstack can be "self contained" and not rely upon external entities.'

I disagree with this statement, I don't think OpenStack should be self contained, we *should* rely on standard tools for standard problems.

This problem sounds like its out of the scope of nova, but in the scope of TripleO ( the official openstack deployment program).'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-04-21 20:50:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Alan, thanks for your thoughts. In response:

"Doing this in Nvoa for ensuring the Active traffic ports are up and available before scheduling makes good use of Nova nad ensures that before we call for a VM to be instantiated that the actual traffic links are validated for connectivity at Layer-2 status."

I disagree. The Nova resource tracker and scheduler is not a monitoring system. It requests periodic information from compute nodes regarding their usage of compute resources and matches user requests to launch instances to a compute host that can service that request.

Under no circumstances does a compute node that is unavailable or disabled get used by the Nova scheduler to host a new VM.

The solution to this problem is to have an external script running on the nova-compute hosts that queries LLDP or uses an external heartbeat system to monitor for link failure on the data network, and then issue a call to nova-manage service disable that changes the database record for the compute node and effectively removes the node from the scheduler.

Failure of the control plane link is already dealt with, since the scheduler may attempt to schedule a VM on a host that may then have a downed link on the control plane, but the message queue messages for launching the VM will not go through to the compute node and a Reschedule exception will bubble up, causing the VM to be rescheduled onto a different host.

"External mgmt tools can nto do this adn will never be a good place either. The best place to check and validate the Layer-2 "carrier status" is on the actual host itself."

Agreed. See above why this should be a script running on the host if the idea is to check for a downed link on the data plane. If the idea is to check for network issues between VMs on one host and VMs on another, then a check script inside the VM is the appropriate place to put such a check.

"If you did choose to do this on an external mgmt tool, and i Strongly discourage folks from doing this you have no way of validating that the L-2 link is actually down, because the external mgmt tool would have to have a direct L-2 connection to the compute host or it would have to issue a cmd to initiate a probe to check the L-2 status between the port on the PCI NIC card and the actual external switch entity."

See above about the scheduler not scheduling to any host that it can't see on the control plane. And see above about why a script running on the compute host can effectively solve this problem for a downed data plane link when a control plane link is still up.

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 10318, 'date': '2014-04-21 21:49:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Joe

I do understand your point here and we have discussed that a lot and i did give it lots of consideration of using an external tool but my main issue is that an external tool can not check Layer-2 connectivity it can only validate L-3 from a central mgmt point. When it comes to layer-2 the best way is to run validate this on the actual host of the compute blade to validate the L-2 status.
This is 100% in scope of Nova because what we want is to ensure that a given port on the PCI card is connected and valid and that this be registered in Nova_db so that when a VM is to be scheduled you ensure the traffic ports are active. 

If you feel you have an alternative proposal then perhaps you can submit a detailed blueprint to suggest an alternative solution.

When it comes to self contained, imho it makes sense to ensure OS is contained to provide guarantees of its resources being made available to be consumed, you can do that on an external system but then you have overhead, complexity and a larger margin of degree of error. Also to bring "carrier Grade Features to Openstack" it typically has to have some degree of inherent intelligence....which is what i am bring to the table here.

From an Ops perspective this imho folks would find very useful.'}, {'account_id': 10318, 'date': '2014-04-21 22:07:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Jay

I can understand your point of view here, but if you dont do this in resource tracker where would you do this? 
I am not saying the scheduler is a monitoring tool, that is not stated or eluded in the BP, apologies if it is, the main "point at hand in the BP" is to (1) check the L-2 port status when a PCI NIC card driver is enabled by querying the "carrier_Status" of the PCI NIC port on one of the Traffic ports.....there are numerous advantages for doing this as listed in the BP and also on "some PCI NIC devices" that cater for 4 10GB Eth ports typically only 2 are used connected to 2 TOR switches and in other cases all 4 are used and cabled and connected to the TOR's so using this you (2) get to validate what ports are connected and what ones are not. What makes sense is to register the following in Nova_db: "carrier status" and in addition to this also the PCI device types (another BP i am writing up, will submit tomorrow) and the concept is to provide as much info into Nova_db that typical "Telco Applications and Services require" for a carrier grade system.

Yes i do understand how the scheduler works, and adding this nice feature you get to guarantee that when a VM is being instantiated on a given compute node the actual traffic ports aer enabled correctly and traffic should flow after the VM is instantiated completely (storage/networking etc etc). Today we do not have this feature which means it is possible for nova to request for a VM to be instantiated on the O&M port....after time x the user can not send/recieve traffic .......then what? So I hope this explains the reasoning here now?

As i said to you Jay you can use LLDP, but before that you "must validate the carrier status" before you run LLDP and to be honest LLDP is just one solution others are possible but i agree LLDP is what i would use after checking the carrier_state for link layer connectivity between the PCI NIC and TOR switch, but that is during run time, not before!

I dont agree with you on the failure case, the main problem most TElco Systems face with is to know ahead of time before the event takes place, so imho you can do as you say but i would not use that method in a Telco enabled distro, what i would do and plan to do is to ensure that an rpc call/cast to be placed will be able to be received by nova compute in the first place adn that the traffic ports will be up.....lots of other checks i would like to add also...but we take this one first ;-)....the question is the traffic ports on which the "rpc msg is not sent too"...........as it appears i am banging my head here, i hope folks are understanding our views here......or do we need to settle this at the Summit?

The issue is not on VM connectivity, thats a separate issue not related to thsi BP but another issue out of scope of this BP.

Jay, seriously what script are you referring too, perhaps you can make a Blueprint proposal for this, and then i would be open to discuss. 
The BP is suggesting a script on the host to simply check the "carier status".

Hope this explains the intention of the BP.


BR
Alan'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-04-21 23:14:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Alan, responses below.

"I can understand your point of view here, but if you dont do this in resource tracker where would you do this?"

On the compute host, with a script that checks link status and sets the compute host to disables on detection of link failure.

"I am not saying the scheduler is a monitoring tool, that is not stated or eluded in the BP, apologies if it is, the main "point at hand in the BP" is to (1) check the L-2 port status when a PCI NIC card driver is enabled by querying the "carrier_Status" of the PCI NIC port on one of the Traffic ports....."

When is a PCI NIC card driver enabled? Not when a VM is scheduled... which is why I don't think this belongs in the scheduler logic.

"there are numerous advantages for doing this as listed in the BP"

Sorry, I'm not seeing any of those advantages listed in the BP. Would you mind listing them out. I have read the problem description 5 times and still don't see any enumeration of the advantages of having the scheduler check or consider the compute host NIC state.

"and also on "some PCI NIC devices" that cater for 4 10GB Eth ports typically only 2 are used connected to 2 TOR switches and in other cases all 4 are used and cabled and connected to the TOR's so using this you (2) get to validate what ports are connected and what ones are not."

In every platform I've seen or worked on, there have been Nagios or other check scripts that query LLDP, SNMP or some other state system to monitor for changes in expected state. Each deployment's expected state is, of course, different, depending on things like, as you say, whether 2 of the NICs are bonded, cross-connected to one or more TORs, etc. Because these checks are deployer-specific, these check scripts, the frequency with which they run, as well as the action that is taken on warning or critical conditions, is the purview of the deployment, which is what Joe has said.

"What makes sense is to register the following in Nova_db: "carrier status" and in addition to this also the PCI device types (another BP i am writing up, will submit tomorrow) and the concept is to provide as much info into Nova_db that typical "Telco Applications and Services require" for a carrier grade system."

There's nothing fundamentally different between a "carrier grade system" and a "normal" system except the variance in fault tolerance and the action taken to remedy a fault. This variance belongs in the arena of the deployment scaffolding, IMO, which is where such check scripts generally live.

"Yes i do understand how the scheduler works, and adding this nice feature you get to guarantee that when a VM is being instantiated on a given compute node the actual traffic ports aer enabled correctly and traffic should flow after the VM is instantiated completely (storage/networking etc etc)."

You get no such guarantee with this system. The scheduler under this blueprint could schedule a host that has all links up, start a VM on that host, and right after boot, the link would go down and you'd have a VM in the exact same state as without the work in this blueprint. At least with a solution that keeps a check script running in an external system, you'd be able to notify some system to migrate VMs on that failed host. With a scheduler-based system, no such luck.

"Today we do not have this feature which means it is possible for nova to request for a VM to be instantiated on the O&M port....after time x the user can not send/recieve traffic .......then what? So I hope this explains the reasoning here now?"

I'm a little unsure about this last piece... could you elaborate a bit more on it? By O&M, you're referring to an out-of-band network? Or something else? Sorry for being dense, just need a bit more information on that...

"<snip>
I dont agree with you on the failure case, the main problem most TElco Systems face with is to know ahead of time before the event takes place, so imho you can do as you say but i would not use that method in a Telco enabled distro, what i would do and plan to do is to ensure that an rpc call/cast to be placed will be able to be received by nova compute in the first place adn that the traffic ports will be up"

That is completely impossible to guarantee, Alan, and I think you know that already. A compute host's networking can go out in between the scheduling of the VM and the time the VM ultimately starts communicating with some external or internal system, and nothing about this blueprint changes that.

You cannot predict failure, only architect for redundancy. The best you can do to achieve that above type of guarantee in a distributed cloud system is to ensure that any VM you launch is launched in multiples against each availability zone in your deployment and use the first VM that happened to get into ACTIVE status. Even then, there's no guarantee that a catastrophic network failure wouldn't happen on the node that was eventually launched on...

".....lots of other checks i would like to add also...but we take this one first ;-)....the question is the traffic ports on which the "rpc msg is not sent too"...........as it appears i am banging my head here, i hope folks are understanding our views here......or do we need to settle this at the Summit?"

I've asked a few more folks to weigh in on this from the operator's perspective. I certainly don't want to give you the impression that I am blocking this from going forward; I'm doing nothing more than expressing a disagreement. Let's hope we get a few more opinions on here and I'm sure the summit session will be a good one.

"The issue is not on VM connectivity, thats a separate issue not related to thsi BP but another issue out of scope of this BP."

Yes, agreed. Sorry about the one comment inline on the blueprint that made the mistake of saying it was a VM-level problem.

"Jay, seriously what script are you referring too, perhaps you can make a Blueprint proposal for this, and then i would be open to discuss. The BP is suggesting a script on the host to simply check the "carier status"."

I'm referring to Nagios check sciptss or Pacemaker resource agent scripts that would check link state matches expected conditions.

Such a script could go in Triple-O or something like the collection of Chef cookbooks or Puppet modules in Stackforge

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 10318, 'date': '2014-04-22 01:29:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Jay

Appears we agree to disagree on this item ;-) but i guess thats how this goes!

The blueprints is also pointing that a scipt would be used to check the "carrier status" and actually Intel is co-signing this and i believe it would be best to hear their input, after all they make the PCI devices so what better way to get more input from an actual vendor ;-).

"On the compute host, with a script that checks link status and sets the compute host to disables on detection of link failure." 
I dont agree on this, because as i stated in a previous response, just because you detect some NIC ports down does not equal you set the host to disable.....you just note which Phy Port is at status etc.

The PCI NIC driver is enabled upon boot up of the blade. What we are proposing is to validate the status and register that in Nova_db....before run time.

Sure i can list "some of the advantages" here are just a few:(1) Check PCI NIC Port "carrier state" and register this state in Nova_db. (2) apply additional filtering checks so that only VM's will be instantiated on compute blades that have carrier status as enabled/UP. 
(3) REgister additional metadata to describe the PCI Device Types and capabilities to allow for fine grain placement of VM for a given app that requires a specific PCI device or its class or capabilities equivalent (this BP i will register tomorrow/Wednesday).

I think Nagios is fine but its not something everyone uses Jay. AS i said you typically run LLDP during run time, this BP is for device status check before run time. All those options are valid but its just options, i dont want to force myself to use Nagios when i dont need too, hence this BP. The problem with these tools like Nagios imho is they never trouble shoot where the link failure is, and the main element we want here in this BP is to just check link status on the PCI NIC traffic ports and register that state in Nova_db....its something we would fine useful and something we would like to have as a feature set

"There's nothing fundamentally different between a "carrier grade system" and a "normal" system except the variance in fault tolerance and the action taken to remedy a fault. This variance belongs in the arena of the deployment scaffolding, IMO, which is where such check scripts generally live." 

Sorry but i do not agree with you on this at all. From a Telco Cloud perspective what we definitely want is to have  system that is not just fault tolerant but resilient and transactional based and provides atomicity (but thats another whole story.....something we can sit down and explain over beers as its the major pain points i have about OS as a whole and where i see as issues it most likely will not address anytime soon imho)

" You get no such ...... "
Yes i would agree with you on this point, however i believe that adding some additional state and check mechanisms will aide to OS in the long run, also when it comes to link failure and if i may what we typically do is use bonded interfaces as one solution to address link failure on a single phy port or TOR switch/port. I would agree with you that you can run an external script, but before you do that you definitely want to check the as i have said the carrier state and register it in Nova_db and in addition to that register class and capabilities of the PCI device...makes sense right? I agree that an external system can then after this monitor the "L-3 Status" but NOT L-2 status. In the past we typically built probes into our hosts and had an external entity initiate the probe to check the L-2 Link state.

O&M == Operation and Maintenance...yes its the OOB i/f in this scenario and we use dedicated 1GB ports for this for comms to our OS controllers.

"That is completely impossible to guarantee, Alan, and I think you know that already. A compute host's networking can go out in between the scheduling of the VM and the time the VM ultimately starts communicating with some external or internal system, and nothing about this blueprint changes that."

Actually it is possible, we do that in our Telco systems today :-) as do other app vendors today ;-) And this is where i see OS folks like yourself have a different view and experience from us in the Telco world...and I know its hard to agree on this but what else are you asking me here? because i am unsure of your points here....to me these are all possible options...none however i would recommend or use in a Telco Cloud system i am afraid to say!

I think having more people weigh in i am again loosing faith in both Openstack and its process......i am afraid yet again i am frustrated so i am not sure what else you are trying to achieve here apart from trash this BP. Look in the end its an option, an option we want to add and contribute too.....other options are valid and i do not block anyone from making contributions they feel are valid for their "deployments and scenarios"......am i missing something here or is OS going to just adopt one option for every scenario....please tell me this is not that case! Or why not write a Blueprint Jay and submit and we will gladly review your proposals here too.

"I'm referring to Nagios check sciptss or Pacemaker resource agent scripts that would check link state matches expected conditions."

Can you please detail how Nagios would check and validate carrier state? I am lost here, perhaps you can write up a Blueprint and register it as another option??? I believe that would imho be the best way forward.'}, {'account_id': 161, 'date': '2014-04-22 15:56:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

I disagree with the comment that an external management system cannot check from the host. That is the whole point of agents (such as NRPE in the case of nagios). Checks are run on the local host and sent back to the management node. In this specific case, the check should also be written such that a "non-check-in" is considered a failure.

However, designing a monitoring solution aside, I think the crux of this issue is that a 3rd party solution is where this should happen. The scheduler is extendable, so I'd argue it's better to come up with a " NIC availability filter" or some such thing which checks whatever data sources to determine these things, and those data sources would be updated by a monitoring system. This makes the entire system extendable to as many resources as you want to monitor.

Adding it to the resource monitor doesn't make sense to me. (5 inline comments)

Hi Folks,

There are some great comments in this thread. 

The key point of the blueprint presented is that there is a need to have the status of the NIC L2 state on the data plane connection leveraged in VM instantiation decisions.
(There is a related point on dealing with the NIC L2 state on the data plane connection post VM instantiation that is not dealt with in this proposal. I think it is best to park that one for now, as this blueprint is not trying to take the place of a holistic monitoring solution that may help enable that capability.)

There does not appear to be any objection to making the key point happen, just how it should happen and if it should all be contained within OpenStack.
There are a number of steps to making it happen. 
1) How to detect the L2 link state. 
2) Where to store that information.
3) How to filter/schedule based on that information.

1) L2 Link State: 
The blueprint is not specific on how the L2 link state is detected, but there also appears to be consensus that the task is fundamentally carried out by an agent on the host. There are many valid approaches possible.

2) L2 Link State Storage: 
The feedback I see in this thread is that folks do not want to see the Nova resource monitor updated to include status of the NIC. CPU cores, RAM, are in scope, but not the NIC L2 state. This appears to be an arbitrary distinction to make. One comment (by Kevin) explaining this position is that “it’s not meant to be an UP/DOWN monitoring system”. I understand it wasn’t designed with that usage model in mind, but as the use of OpenStack in NFV (carrier grade) usage models grows, so too will the need to make extensions to cater for these specific use cases. 

Part of the alternative solution presented is that an external tool can be used to pull the entire host from the infrastructure if a data plane NICs L2 state is down. This is potentially more drastic than necessary. E.g. You may have many ports on a host working perfectly but one port is down. It may even be down because of an issue at the ToR, so taking out the entire compute blade may not be the correct action to take. It may be acceptable to simply not schedule anything new there. 

3) How to filter/ schedule based on that information:
The blueprint proposed a “network connectivity filter”; Kevin Bringard proposed a “NIC availability filter”; Jay, Dan & Joe are proposing that it is not needed, and just pull the compute node under the direction of an external tool when the NIC L2 state is down. 
A filter approach is our preferred option for similar reasons that Alan has outlined, but also because of the need (that will be articulated in a future blueprint) to extend filtering further based on other NIC related items that are needed as we progress towards NFV enabling.  Perhaps we could look at calling it a “network filter” and use it to look at items such as the L2 link state noted in this blueprint and leave ample room for further extensions. Use of this filter should be op-in by default, so anyone not interested in this pre-instantiation check shouldn’t have to concern themselves with it…

I’m also looking forward to input on how to progress the discussion. 

Regards,
Adrian'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-04-25 18:52:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Alan,

The way this works is people propose things they'd like to see in nova and plan to work on. The nova drivers[1] team decides what is appropriate for inclusion in nova, and what we think we can commit review resources to in a given cycle. I think the majority of the feedback you're getting here is that we don't think this function belongs in nova. That means, there is not reason to write up a blueprint to do this a different way, because the implementation isn't the problem -- it's a scope thing.

Other considerations for things we think *are* in the scope of nova include available development resources to get this done in a cycle and, more importantly, available review resources to commit to reviewing the actual code when it hits.

We very much appreciate your willingness to contribute this feature to Nova, but I think that most folks will agree we believe it is out of scope for the project. Given the tight scheduling at the summit, I don't think it's likely that we'll be able to dedicate a 40 minute timeslot to discussing this, but there are three options. First, last cycle, we had an "unconference" track in nova that allowed for some short 10-minute talks, for which this would be appropriate. Second, feel free to catch developers in between talks at the summit to discuss the feeling on why this isn't something we want to take on in Nova. Third, you can bring this up on the openstack-dev mailing list or in #openstack-nova and try to kick of some discussion.

Thanks!

[1]: https://launchpad.net/~nova-drivers/+members'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-04-25 19:24:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

(4 comments)

Adrian, some answers to your inline comments, thx.

The main point of the opposition to this blueprint is really where the blueprint proposes to place the code for this functionality.

The folks objecting to this design are objecting to changing the resource tracker from tracking *usage* to tracking *status*. Resource usage is tracked by the scheduler in real-time using the claims process, and a periodic task that polls the hypervisor is used to *reconcile* the hypervisor's idea about the used compute resources on the host with Nova (db)'s idea about the current usage of compute resources on the host.

In this blueprint, we're talking about a network resource (physical NICs or virtual NICs or SR-IOV VFs). But the blueprint is not discussing tracking the *usage* of these resources, but instead the *status* of those resources. If this blueprint were instead to describe a method of getting Nova and Neutron's ideas of the usage and capacity of network resources more in-sync or more real-time, then I'd happily support it. But, as it stands now, this spec is attempting to change the fundamental purpose of the resource tracker -- to track *consumption* of available resources -- to a resource monitoring agent, and that's not a direction I and a number of the dissenters on this spec think is appropriate.

Hope that explains things. Looking forward to meeting you all and having conversations about this in ATL next week.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-08 18:11:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Hi everbody, 

After some discussion with Jay Pipes on the summit I give this BP a second try. The basic change is that the new solution is based on the servicegroup feature of nova. Thanks Jay, for the pointer. The main comment against our proposal was that it is better to use the 3rd party monitoring tool to solve this. However nova already has a basic monitoring solution as part of the servicegroup feature. Both the db driver and the memcached driver implementation of the servicegroup creates a task that periodically runs as part of the nova-compute service and update the service state.
Then later on ComputeFilter of the scheduler uses this information to decide if instances can be scheduled on a compute host or not. So what we want to do in this BP is a natural extension to the existing servicegroup feature inside nova.

Jay, I'm happy to have an IRC meeting around this topic to make a decision about the way forward.

Cheers, 
Gibi"}, {'account_id': 10318, 'date': '2014-05-29 15:16:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This seems like a good reasonable proposal, would like to see the details more on how we will add the "carrier state check" though (1) before any VM provisioning and (2)to be able to have a configurable probe time per Compute blade.

Alan'}, {'account_id': 6772, 'date': '2014-05-30 19:12:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I want to state up front that I see the value in being able to monitor the state of the NICs (and potentially other aspects of the host) via Nova itself and factor that information into scheduling.

As currently proposed there is no intersection between this design and the SR-IOV proposal. While that is probably not a bad thing in terms of getting a base implementation upon which to iterate I think there are a couple of potential considerations to discuss here (perhaps something to take back to the M/L).

1) Should any device configured for SR-IOV be automatically included as one we're tracking the state of? It seems like there's almost two classes of NIC devices here, those that you are using for general management/data traffic and those that are involved in some form of pass through (either the whole device or VFs within it).

2) Should the response always be to filter out the host or entirely, or will some providers simply want the ports (and VFs, if applicable) associated with the device removed from the pool available for allocation to instances. Filtering the host out entirely perhaps makes sense for an initial implementation but I suspect more granularity here would be desirable."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-02 16:42:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Verified

commit_message:
Add support for physical CD-ROM when VM is running

Sometimes we need to attach/detach host's or PC's CD-ROM device to a running
instance when we want to access content directly without upload to glance.

blueprint use-physical-cdrom

Change-Id: I5284892e8b4ad47133df568c7dae563178a7dd3f

How long is this going to take? There are bugs in other components that depends on this being done, since using v3 wasn't recommended. How much of an impact is it to implement this here before the changes of v2.1?"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2014-06-17 22:51:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

What sort of bugs depend on this? Can you give some examples.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2014-06-18 11:36:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I'm working in a Sahara bug right now. Sahara should check quotas locally so it can be able to show the user that the cluster can't be created for quotas reasons. Right now, the cluster creation just goes to error state and nothing is outputed to the user. My first idea was to use v3 but there is the "instability" problem and I was told to use v2, since v2 doesn't have this implemented (as is documented) I tought that even with v2.1 working this should be implemented for current v2 users.
If v2.1 is commig out right away than I'm ok, but if its going to take a while I don't see why this should be held off.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2014-06-18 15:40:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

LGTM, I don't think this should be held hostage for v2.1 since it's a documented API in v2 (albeit code is the source of truth), this is a pretty simple fix, and I'm pretty sure this can land before v2.1."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2014-06-18 16:24:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

LGTM, although can you fix up the formatting.

http://docs-draft.openstack.org/49/99949/5/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/b1c27b2/doc/build/html/specs/juno/v2-api-detailed-quotas.html

is hard to read.


my original -1 was because I was under the false impression that there was another way to get this same data in the v2 api. On that note can you update the blueprint to explicitly say that.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2014-06-18 17:05:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-18 17:05:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Nova v2 API should be able to return detailed quotas

Compute V2 API does not return detailed information about quotas.
There is no direct call to retrieve this information and there is no other
way to get this information.

Basically this is a documented part of the os-quota-sets API extension
in V2 but isn't implemented in the V2 API. It's implemented in the V3
API.
This change is adding the detail support for the V2 API so
this works:
/v2/?{tenant_id}?/os-quota-sets/?{tenant_id}?/detail/?{user_id}?

implements: blueprint v2-api-detailed-quotas
Change-Id: I7572e8f8feb8a5a8ca0fd66b76dace57459878e5

Policy ENFORCER's method 'clear' does not really
delete cached file as written in its docstring.

This commit adds 'delete_cached_file' to fileutils

commit_message:
Fix deletion of cached file for policy enforcer

Policy ENFORCER's method 'clear' does not really
delete cached file as written in its docstring.

This commit adds 'delete_cached_file' to fileutils
and makes 'clear' method of ENFORCER use it.

Change-Id: I855d5f2001ac721249217d9fbd782c64af9db874
Closes-Bug: #1340843

'}, {'created': '2014-06-24 09:45:54.000000000', 'message': 'Blueprint for the implementation of Nested Quota Driver API

Nested Quota Driver API helps in the enforcement of

commit_message:
Blueprint for the implementation of Nested Quota Driver API

Nested Quota Driver API helps in the enforcement of
quotas in hierarchical projects

Change-Id: I26fda89e3a3a6eed15fc13daf8a49111e13c30e2

Can you please look at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/84281/ there seems to be some overlap here."}, {'account_id': 7239, 'date': '2014-04-02 10:37:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Gary,
I did check that after submitting this review. They are very similar in the intent - to avoid image transfer when the image is on the datastore already.
The differences are
 - this blueprint doesnt rely on the datastore glance backend. So should work fine in the way users today upload images to glance into non datastore backend
 - the same image in glance will work for multiple vCenters. With datastore backed glance storage, the image has to be uploaded once into the datastore for each vCenter.'}, {'account_id': 8759, 'date': '2014-04-02 17:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Kiran for this proposal:
About this:
"the same image in glance will work for multiple vCenters. With datastore backed glance storage, the image has to be uploaded once into the datastore for each vCenter." This is not exactly true: my proposal will still work in this case, you just don't get the optimization.

In general I think our proposals do not overlap: your proposal happens when the image is already in the cache where mine is for the transfer from Glance to the cache.

I can actually see a combination of both working perfectly fine: I use the Glance datastore backend, upload the image Glance which implicitly goes to the datastore, spawn a VM (the disk goes to the cache), your logic copies the bits contained in the cache somewhere else, then I spawn an instance using the same image from another cluster, the disk is already in the cache.

Please correct me if this is wrong... 

In case this is correct, I actually think the combination of both makes the datastore/storage story much more robust than what is upstream today for the VMware driver.

Thanks
Arnaud'}, {'account_id': 7239, 'date': '2014-04-03 08:34:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Arnaud for the review.
Your interpretation is correct.
This blueprint will speedup the boot when the image is already available in the cache of another cluster of the same vCenter but the nova boot is requested for the same image to a different cluster.
The speedup will not be much _if_ the user uses a datastore backed glance image repository
Therefore the two can co-exist.'}, {'account_id': 7400, 'date': '2014-04-08 21:52:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

i think you may need to think about/cover conditions where you have more than 1 n-compute using the same VC and they upload images to their cache.  But in general this is  nice idea"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-04-08 21:52:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

(5 comments)

Many, many thanks for the updates, I think I understand what you are try to do now.

However, I feel this is the wrong approach, long term. Here is why...

Glance v2 can expose custom properties that let you access the image in an efficient way, like datastore connection location, etc, when you glance is using the VMware datastore.

Using vCenter metadata and querying all clusters, etc, seems very hacky to me. Now we want to make progress independent of glance, and prehaps this is the best we can do in the mean time, but this all should get discussed in the spec.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-07 12:38:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(11 comments)

Various suggestions for clarification in-line

@John: I'm not sure you have the right mode here - As I understood it from the description this change doesn't touch the Nova/Glance interaction at all, its more of a transparent performance optimisation exploiting a capability that already exists in VMware to copy an image from one datastore to another.  Its kind of like allowing a nova-compute to snoop into the image cache of another nova-compute instead of going to Glance when it needs an image (except that it all happens down in the VMware layer)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-07 13:06:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Verified

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/62/84662/6/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/ba6b411/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 18s'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2014-06-24 09:33:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

I think we need to better describe how to implement some good locking to make sure there are no races.

Assume each host owns its own cache, we need to make sure the image doesn't get deleted or modified while the other host makes a copy of that image, and we need to know when the image is ready to be copied, etc.

Maybe we have an extra RPC call from one compute to the other, saying please copy the image to me, similar to how migrate works today. That way each compute can take out its own local lock during the operation.

However, the above is not very easily secured, so probably better to ask the conductor to co-ordinate the operation."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-24 09:33:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-24 09:34:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified+1

PS I could be wrong, and there is no race here. Thats fine, but I would like to see a discussion of how you avoid the race, given the current spawn operation  in VMware is hitting lots of these issues, I would like this to make things better not worse.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2014-06-24 09:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

If you are wanting an exception, please raise this in the next nova-meeting.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-16 10:20:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: -Verified

commit_message:
VMware nova driver - datastore image cache update improvements

If an image is available in the cache of one cluster, then copy of
image from glance to nova (proxy VM) can be completely avoided by using
vCenter APIs to copy the cached image from one datastore to another
datastore.

Change-Id: I0ef1e073afaabd66416937a028bd1611b244b79d

Hi Alexis, thx for your spec!

commit_message:
Address slow queries

Analysis of the MySQL slow query log has revealed some queries which are not
using indexes. This causes a scalability issue when combined with soft
delete.

Advances blueprint: nova-juno-slow-queries

Change-Id: If4ed37d81b74d4ab41cc05d89d12fe3578005dbc

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/54/95054/4/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/9282e5a/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 02s'}, {'account_id': 9060, 'date': '2014-05-27 03:30:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

Comments around if the end user stops the qga.

Also, I don't understand this focus on max_vcpus_limit.  I am pretty green on CPU hotplugging, so maybe I am just missing something.  Do certain kernels have limits on how many CPUs can be hotplugged at once?  Are there different limits for number of CPUs supported for hotplug vs. a cold boot of the guest?  Why is this max vcpus limit important for live-resize, but not for cold-resize?"}, {'account_id': 8021, 'date': '2014-05-27 07:04:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

Hi Mike,

There's one deprecated nova-spec for "cpu_hotplug" I submitted before, the link is https://review.openstack.org/#/c/86273/.

The reason why I add 'max_vcpus_limit' is libvirt driver needs it now. Part of structure of libvirt.xml for hotplugging is like "<vcpus current='X'>'Y'</vcpus>". So if you want to hot-plugged additional vcpus to the instance, you need to indicate current vcpus number('X', should equals to flavor.vcpus) & the max vcpus limit('Y') in the config before you execute 'vcpus hot-plug'. In other words, you need to specify these two values during instance creation.

But now, the original usage in libvirt driver only has 'Y'(equals to flavor.vcpus) in the structure above, no 'X' value. So, all these old-style instances can't be hot-plugged.

Therefore, I need to add this tag.
By the way, VMware doesn't have this limitation.

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 9060, 'date': '2014-05-27 13:53:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
API: Live Resize

'Cold-resize' had been implemented previously.
But instance needs to be rebooted during the period.

So this plan aims to add 'live-resize' function into Nova.
This is useful and convenient for users.

Change-Id: I656f7b79ad22583c19bd044b81e69143ee8d3304
Implements: blueprint hot-resize

commit_message:
Add unit tests for vm benchmark scenarios

Added following tests

test__boot_server_with_sec_group
test__boot_server_with_sec_group
test__boot_server_with_similar_sec_group

Created method to remove repeated
assert_called_once_with calls

Change-Id: I65b2e398826a5883d033eb8b5214dd41ceea3063
Implements: blueprint improve-unit-test-coverage-rally

I hate that this field is binary, but I think you're on the right track here.

Do we have a clear definition of what each capability actually means ? I'm a bit confused by what "compute-auth" is about.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2014-06-20 19:30:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-20 19:30:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:
