revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-09 17:23:40.000000000', 'message': "Make ComputeCapabilitiesFilter work with Ironic

It is not currently possible to selectively associate a Nova flavor
with certain nodes in Ironic, beyond variances in the cpu/ram/disk.

The ComputeCapabilitiesFilter exists in Nova for just this purpose,
but the nova.virt.ironic driver is not propagating the correct
data up to the scheduler.

This patch passes the node.properties['capabilities'] field up to
Nova so that it can be matched against
flavor.extra_specs['capabilities'] by this scheduler filter.

Change-Id: Ide39f4a2796b169025bf0083e021166ae35f30f8
Closes-bug: 1339816

commit_message:
Make ComputeCapabilitiesFilter work with Ironic

It is not currently possible to selectively associate a Nova flavor
with certain nodes in Ironic, beyond variances in the cpu/ram/disk.

The ComputeCapabilitiesFilter exists in Nova for just this purpose,
but the nova.virt.ironic driver is not propagating the correct
data up to the scheduler.

This patch parses the node.properties['capabilities'] as a series of
comma-separated k:v pairs and passes them up to Nova so that it can
be matched against flavor.extra_specs['capabilities'] by the
scheduler filter.

Co-Author: Matthew Gilliard <matthew.gilliard@hp.com>
DocImpact: adds the ability to specify multiple capabilities
           to a node for scheduling purposes
Closes-bug: 1339816
Change-Id: Ide39f4a2796b169025bf0083e021166ae35f30f8

commit_message:
Rename mariadb-rdo to mariadb-rpm

* mariadb-galera-cluster is now in fedora repositories so there is no need
to install it from RDO repository. This patch removes dependency on RDO repository.

* same package set should be also available in rhel and centos repositories soon
(after adding proper channels/repositories), so it makes sense to rename
it from '-rdo' to '-rpm'.

Change-Id: I90e7ca4803516b86179b0f6639e307a60297960b

[{'created': '2014-07-14 19:57:47.000000000', 'message': 'The Most Obvious Way to Get a Service Catalog That You Have to See to Believe

This introduces a new call for authenticated users to retrieve a service
catalog from Keystone. It is designed to compliment tokens generated
using ?nocatalog.

blueprint: get-catalog
Change-Id: Ia967032839c5575c72a6459974114a0165921cc9
'}]
commit_message:
The Most Obvious Way to Get a Service Catalog That You Have to See to Believe

This introduces a new call for authenticated users to retrieve a service
catalog from Keystone. It is designed to compliment tokens generated
using ?nocatalog.

blueprint: get-catalog
Change-Id: Ia967032839c5575c72a6459974114a0165921cc9

commit_message:
Fix 500 error for secret PUT

Two issues here caused failure for secret PUT.

First, constructor for secret wasn't passing in the metadata repo when
saving off to self.repos.  Added the secret_meta_repo to self.repos.

Second the PUT controller wasn't passing in the right value to the plugin
to store the sercret.  It was sending in a function object rather than
the result of calling that function.  Two parens made things all better...

Also updated unit tests.

Change-Id: I89d329c718e10fb3e64c6a81867df86ada22b02e
Closes-Bug: 1339460

Ok, with current defaults max_limit=1000, recursion is not a problem. Still, while it's theoretically possible to set max_limit=10 for whatever reasons, reaching recursion limit no longer seems impossible to me.

Also I've checked, that recursion limits affect generators with this example:

 def f(x):
     yield x
     if x > 0:
             for i in f(x - 1):
                     yield i

 >>> list(f(1000))
 RuntimeError: maximum recursion depth exceeded"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-30 17:13:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Verified

If I'm reading correctly, this introduces a significant functionality change. Namely, when there are more resources than will be returned by a single GET /v1/{resource}/ request, the client will now *always* walk the results "next" links until all resources have been retrieved (or the recursion depth is maxed out and python crashes).

Besides the obvious problem with recursion here, I think it's an antifeature. Users of the library and the CLI should be able to determine their own pagination, and it should not default to "show me everything".

If there are 1M nodes in a system, and some new sysadmin runs "ironic node-list" it shouldn't walk through 1,000 pages of results and flood his terminal with 1,000,000 lines. It should print the first 1,000.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2014-06-25 14:01:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-25 14:01:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Lucas, I was trying to understand this and had a couple of questions:

1. Our RESTful API [1] shows that there are 4 parameters used wrt lists: marker, limit, sort_key, and sort_dir. This handles marker and limit. Are sort_key and sort_dir also useful but should be handled in a separate patch, or do we not want to allow the specification of that. 

2. With respect to the handling of 'limit' here. From what I can tell, with the REST API, the default if limit isn't specified, is to use Ironic's default (ie, the api.max_limit config setting). I had expected the CLI to use similar logic/defaults, but the limit defaults to 100 here. I was wondering why.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/webapi/v1.html"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-08 20:37:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Build succeeded.

- check-tripleo-ironic-undercloud-precise http://logs.openstack.org/85/91585/4/check-tripleo/check-tripleo-ironic-undercloud-precise/740a910 : SUCCESS in 1h 22m 39s'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2014-07-09 09:41:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi Ruby,

1)Yes I think we should allow the specification of sort_dir and sort_key, but I also would prefer to do that in a separated patch, this one is already 400+ lines of code and it was primarily meant to fix the problem with the client library not being able to follow the 'next' links returned by the pagination of the Ironic API.

2) So in the Ironic API that max_limit config is what the API uses to know how many items should be returned per request, and to access the next "batch" the client should have to follow the 'next' link returned as part of the request response, what this patch is doing is adding support for our client library to follow that 'next' link and be able to return all the {nodes | chassis | ports} registered in Ironic, so in the client libraries it's going to return all {nodes | chassis | ports} registered  by default, I think that behavior is expected for the applications using our library when they want to list the resources (that's how we use it on the Nova driver). Now on the CLI which I believe is mostly used by people, so I set the limit by default to 100, cause more than that wouldn't even fit on the screen. So 100 was an assumption, do you think we should have no limit on the CLI by default as well? Or set a higher/lower value?'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2014-07-09 14:26:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Lucas,

wrt 1. I added a bug for sort_key and sort_id [1].

wrt 2. My preference is to have consistency between the CLI and the REST API, so I would vote for 'limit' defaulting to the same default as for CLI, which is use Ironic's default (ie, the api.max_limit config setting). 


[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-ironicclient/+bug/1339731"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-10 11:10:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

[{'created': '2014-05-01 15:20:43.000000000', 'message': "Add pagination support to {node, port, chassis}-list

'next' field is the indicator to continue pagination until there're no
more values to be returned.

Closes-Bug: #1314992
Change-Id: I77cc7a7df65c3d2a84144b12a001487ff6832045
"}, {'created': '2014-05-19 09:22:38.000000000', 'message': "Add pagination support to {node, port, chassis}-list

"}, {'created': '2014-06-25 14:01:09.000000000', 'message': "Add pagination support to {node, port, chassis}-list

the presence of a 'next' field is the indicator to continue pagination
until there're no more values to be returned.

On the CLI two new options were added to commands used to list resources:

* --limit: The maximum number of results to return per request, 0 for no
           limit. Default: 100

* --marker: The UUID of the last item of the previous result set; we
 	    return the next results after this item

Closes-Bug: #1314992
Change-Id: I77cc7a7df65c3d2a84144b12a001487ff6832045
"}, {'created': '2014-07-08 16:07:48.000000000', 'message': "Add pagination support to {node, port, chassis}-list

Closes-Bug: #1314992
Change-Id: I77cc7a7df65c3d2a84144b12a001487ff6832045
"}, {'created': '2014-07-10 11:10:22.000000000', 'message': "Add pagination support to {node, port, chassis}-list

the presence of a 'next' field is the indicator to continue pagination
until there're no more values to be returned.

On the CLI two new options were added to commands used to list resources:

* --marker: The UUID of the last item of the previous result set; we
 	    return the next results after this item

* --limit: The maximum number of results to return per request, 0 for no
           limit.

    This is included if:

    1) 'limit' param is specified and equals the number of items.

    2) 'limit' param is specified and equals 0, in this case
    it means no limit and it's going to iterate over the next
    links until there's no more items to be returned.

    3) 'limit' param is NOT specified (None), in this case the
    number of items returned respect the maximum imposed by the
    Ironic API by default (api.max_limit config option).

Closes-Bug: #1314992
Change-Id: I77cc7a7df65c3d2a84144b12a001487ff6832045
"}, {'created': '2014-07-11 11:10:03.000000000', 'message': "Add pagination support to {node, port, chassis}-list

the presence of a 'next' field is the indicator to continue pagination
until there're no more values to be returned.

On the CLI two new options were added to commands used to list resources:

* --marker: Optional, the UUID of an item, eg the last item from a
  previous result set. Return the next result set.

* --limit: The maximum number of results to return per request, if:

  1) limit > 0, the maximum number of items to return.
  2) limit == 0, return the entire list of items.
  3) limit param is NOT specified (None), the number of items
  returned respect the maximum imposed by the Ironic API
  (see Ironic's api.max_limit option).

Closes-Bug: #1314992
Change-Id: I77cc7a7df65c3d2a84144b12a001487ff6832045
"}, {'created': '2014-07-15 10:04:34.000000000', 'message': "Add pagination support to {node, port, chassis}-list

the presence of a 'next' field is the indicator to continue pagination
until there're no more values to be returned.

On the CLI two new options were added to commands used to list resources:

* --marker: Optional, the UUID of an item, eg the last item from a
  previous result set. Return the next result set.

* --limit: The maximum number of results to return per request, if:

  1) limit > 0, the maximum number of items to return.
  2) limit == 0, return the entire list of items.
  3) limit param is NOT specified (None), the number of items
  returned respect the maximum imposed by the Ironic API
  (see Ironic's api.max_limit option).

Closes-Bug: #1314992
Change-Id: I77cc7a7df65c3d2a84144b12a001487ff6832045
"}]
commit_message:
Add pagination support to {node, port, chassis}-list

the presence of a 'next' field is the indicator to continue pagination
until there're no more values to be returned.

On the CLI two new options were added to commands used to list resources:

* --marker: Optional, the UUID of an item, eg the last item from a
  previous result set. Return the next result set.

* --limit: The maximum number of results to return per request, if:

  1) limit > 0, the maximum number of items to return.
  2) limit == 0, return the entire list of items.
  3) limit param is NOT specified (None), the number of items
  returned respect the maximum imposed by the Ironic API
  (see Ironic's api.max_limit option).

Closes-Bug: #1314992
Change-Id: I77cc7a7df65c3d2a84144b12a001487ff6832045

commit_message:
Fix interfaces template for two interfaces and IPv6

If you have more than one interface and IPv6 enabled, then the interfaces file
emitted would have the incorrect syntax: the `auto eth1` line would be
appended to the end of the `gateway` line of the previous stanza.

This was a result of improper whitespace control in the Jinja template which
this patch fixes.

In order to prevent regressions, this patch swaps out the existing tests with
corresponding tests that are whitespace sensitive. This is important because
it's difficult to tweak Jinja templates in a way that fixes the whitespace
for one scenario while not breaking another.

Closes-Bug: 1339888

Change-Id: Id5566ea2f93ee1a6b8bc42e83bc64a1c6a09e680

Add dbaas.api.replication to black-box group

Added dbaas.api.replication to the default trove integration
tests as part of the black-box group.

Partially-implements: blueprint replication-v1

commit_message:
Set a more generous default image cache size

Master images of non-trivial filesystems will run 3+G (even though
the qcow2 might be < 1G) so we need to make it big enough to be useful
:). Ideally we'd autotune this based on free space or something, but
for now, this is large enough to cache e.g. TripleO cluster workloads
but small enough to fit in test VMs. This patch sets the default cache
to 20G.

Change-Id: I11ca629589e8a90f727abcc5b1c7e72dbd9e4b0f

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2014-06-06 15:35:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The changes which were made to the proposal:

It's been simplified. It's much easier to add extensions later on, than to cut features if at least one person depends on them. That means mainly that I'm assuming pem-formatted pkcs#10 and pem-formatted keys world. If other formats are required, alternatives can be added with pkcs10/pem preserved as the default options.

This resolves the issue of request-type and key-type as mentioned by Arvind and Rob. They can be inferred from the request/key envelope.

Also, the very specific options for certificate generation have been replaced with a simpler one (pretty much the same one certmonger uses). It should satisfy the standard use cases and anything more complex can be handled using CSRs.

I also found a problem with CA / backend selection - when requesting a self-signed certificate, there's no issuer to identify a backend anymore. This was resolved by removing the "self-signed" option. There's no practical reason to use it really. I did not add backend selection as explained in the comment previously - issuer CA should always identify the backend. (if anyone has a use case where that's not true, please explain)

Regarding order type for signing/generating - I think it's obvious from the message structure which one is required - one needs "request", the other needs "certificate_key(_ref)".

I've added the option to supplying the key in the same request as the certificate generation order, but didn't add the "generate both the certificate and key" option - this turned out to be very confusing operation with way too many options.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-06 15:52:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Add bash completion support for ironic cli

This commit adds the 'bash-completion' option to
ironic cli which prints all sub-commands and
options, and bash_completion scripts for bash
auto completion.

Change-Id: Ide5b29e262b4217046f124d86902cd0abfdab1b6
Closes-Bug: 1332408

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow"}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2014-07-15 18:29:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

[{'created': '2014-07-14 15:22:21.000000000', 'message': "Avoid re-adding iptables rules for instances that have disappeared

The remove_filters_for_instance() method fails silently if the
instance's chain is gone (i.e. it's been deleted). If this
happens while we're refreshing security group rules, we will
not notice this case and re-add stale rules for an old instance,
breaking our firewall for new instances.

This adds a quick check after we've captured the lock to see if
the associated chain exists, and bails if it doesn't.

Change-Id: Ic75988939f82de49735d85fe99a9eecd4baf45c9
Related-bug: #1182131
(cherry picked from commit 6aa368b99249d01f8fd7183c15d11986ad6a6fb7)

commit_message:
Avoid re-adding iptables rules for instances that have disappeared

The remove_filters_for_instance() method fails silently if the
instance's chain is gone (i.e. it's been deleted). If this
happens while we're refreshing security group rules, we will
not notice this case and re-add stale rules for an old instance,
breaking our firewall for new instances.

This adds a quick check after we've captured the lock to see if
the associated chain exists, and bails if it doesn't.

Change-Id: Ic75988939f82de49735d85fe99a9eecd4baf45c9
Related-bug: #1182131
(cherry picked from commit 6aa368b99249d01f8fd7183c15d11986ad6a6fb7)

It looks to me that you are trying to patch the test so that it passes rather than fixing the root cause of the problem.

Shouldn't the fix be fixing the initial state of cassandra instances so that they start with 'BUILD' instead of 'SHUTDOWN'?"}, {'account_id': 8415, 'date': '2014-06-12 06:48:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Steve. This is first step to fix cassandra integration. There are alot differences between cassandra and other datastores integrated in Trove.
The problem is in time of starting cassandra service - it takes a lot time while guest seeing that cassandra run running at this point of time (but actually starting in a backgroud) reporting that instance is in SHUTDOWN state. And this short time range between reporting and finishing launch causes SHUTDOWN state. This state exists for 2-3 secs.'}, {'account_id': 8415, 'date': '2014-06-12 15:15:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 8415, 'date': '2014-07-07 15:12:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-07 15:12:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

You have some unrecognized errors.
For bug details see: http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/'}, {'account_id': 9664, 'date': '2014-07-11 17:19:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This change appears to torniquet around a couple of things. 

First, for some reason, cassandra takes a long time to start on first boot. 

There are at least a couple of reasons that I know of. First, unlike MySQL (for example), the cassandra guest image requires much bigger instances to run on. This appears at least in part due to the fact that Java is being configured with default sizing and cassandra is launching with pretty large memory demands.

When run in a virtualized environment, this is clearly a pig. So I verified that MySQL does the same thing if you set its memory requirements to be large.

There are also some places where I think we poll the server to death and cqlsh appears to want to launch a new JVM for each invocation. Now, that's another pig.

There may be other reasons I don't know of but these are things that bugged me no end when testing rsync and I had to bump test_begin.conf in my trove-integration directory to medium sized instances before I could even get cassandra to run reasonably and run int-tests with group=cassandra.

Now this proposed change attempts to poll for status on something that should be a rather straightforward state machine. 

We launch Cassandra (there's a service start command) and we terminate Cassandra (service stop command). Once service start is issued, we should push the expected cassandra state to 'starting' and not have to watch log files to guess whether the thing is starting or not. Instead pick a time (call it 1s and back off slowly to 30s) and poll whether the database is up or not. When it comes up, mark it online. Till then it is starting. Have a timeout if you want, right now there isn't one, I wouldn't invent one. 

When the service stop command is executed, you can push it in the opposite direction. In the middle, you expect it is up and running and can do your periodic polling.

Most of the code that I see in this change attempts to paper around the fact that we don't quite know why cassandra is taking as long as it does to startup. Let's fix that problem and this code and our testing infrastructure will be the better for it."}, {'account_id': 8415, 'date': '2014-07-11 20:33:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2014-07-11 21:15:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

[{'created': '2014-06-11 16:33:22.000000000', 'message': 'Fix assertion while waiting for ACTIVE status

Reasons:
 - For certain reasons Cassandra instances are in
   SHUTDOWN state for short period of time, and it's breaks
   assertion in test that waiting for guest to become active.

Changes:
 - fixing assertion from expecting only BUILD state to expect one of:
   "BUILD" or "SHUTDOWN".

Change-Id: I6009e4c0979abb9a469aed4d3cf2b0f53df4c046
Partial-Bug: #1314980
'}, {'created': '2014-07-07 15:12:47.000000000', 'message': "Fix Cassandra service status definition

Reasons:
 - At slow environment (small flavors, etc.),
   for certain reasons Cassandra instances are in SHUTDOWN state
   for short period of time. This issue breaks assertion
   in int-test that waits for guest to reach ACTIVE state.

Changes:
 - adding validation for Cassandra log file:
   - if status check exec will exit with exit code equals to '1' instead of '0'
     Cassandra log file will be checked for modifications during specific
     time range (at least 5 seconds). If log wouldn't be modified,
     Trove guest will report its status as SHUTDOWN.

commit_message:
Fix Cassandra service status definition

Reasons:
 - At slow environment (small flavors, etc.),
   for certain reasons Cassandra instances are in SHUTDOWN state
   for short period of time. This issue breaks assertion
   in int-test that waits for guest to reach ACTIVE state.

Changes:
 - adding validation for Cassandra log file:
   - if status check exec will exit with exit code equals to '1' instead of '0'
     Cassandra log file will be checked for modifications during specific
     time range (at least 5 seconds). If log wouldn't be modified,
     Trove guest will report its status as SHUTDOWN.

Change-Id: I6009e4c0979abb9a469aed4d3cf2b0f53df4c046
Closes-Bug: #1314980

commit_message:
Update tox.ini to match rest of project

There's a few things - most notably the missing venv env,
but also getting tox to skip the sdist step in builds that
will align python-barbicanclient with the rest of the project.

Change-Id: I7b3c8f992040c0a7f0cace1452a93f4958d0cd2a

commit_message:
Added API data models

The API system passes HTTP(S) requests down to data models, which
in turn are responsible for producing (Python) answers to the API
calls.

This change adds API models for policy, datasource, table, row, rule.
Not every model is as flushed out as we would like, but there is
enough functionality to do end-to-end testing.

Change-Id: Ia3c66262d8ad94f419d3b2174d20c92a45648215

[{'created': '2014-07-14 19:47:08.000000000', 'message': 'Fix libvirt unit tests for older versions

When packaging and running unit tests with older versions of
libvirt < 0.9.13, we see failures unrelated to actual bugs
in the driver code.  The fix is to recognize when
older versions are in play and unit test appropriately.

Change-Id: Ie9f260afd82dded3759dd8e9f87958f57c425c53
Closes-bug: 1341729
'}, {'created': '2014-07-14 20:58:47.000000000', 'message': 'Fix libvirt unit tests for older versions

When packaging and running unit tests with older versions of
libvirt < 0.9.13, we see failures unrelated to actual bugs
in the driver code.  The fix is to recognize when

commit_message:
Fix libvirt unit tests for older versions

When packaging and running unit tests with older versions of
libvirt < 0.9.13, we see failures unrelated to actual bugs
in the driver code.  The fix is to recognize when
older versions are in play and unit test appropriately.

Change-Id: Ie9f260afd82dded3759dd8e9f87958f57c425c53
Closes-bug: 1341729

commit_message:
Expect _prev from glance.image_list_detailed

Glance changed recently to allow paging both ways
(forward and backward). Resulting openstack_dashboard change
broke the modal dialog in murano because we're only trying
to unpack images, _more. Patch adds _prev, but also tries
the older way if that fails.

Change-Id: I62237c15c082676afcc04ea2f94642049a8babde
Closes-Bug: 1339261

commit_message:
Fixup the spec repo

- Removed empty.rst from the juno directory, which is superfluous.
- Removed an erroneous entry from the base spec template.

Change-Id: Ia2e6514b28307037052a2493f5cafd1965c2ad7d

Great feature - thank you!

However, we shouldn't be instantiating drivers in the API service, and the list of available drivers may vary from one conductor service to the next within the same cluster.

All the code on the driver side looks good. You should use an RPC call to gather the info -- either fan-out (rpc broadcast) or look at the hash_ring and directly query one conductor for each driver in the list of available drives (we can assume that all instances of a driver have the same list of properties)."}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2014-02-19 03:58:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-02-19 03:58:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2014-03-13 16:29:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Do not merge

I think the implementation is good, and the feature is required, but it's not ready for Icehouse.

After some discussion, I see that this needs to wait until after the node.instance_info refactoring is complete so that node.driver_info only exposes static hardware-specific *driver* information. Right now, several instance-specific pieces of information are stashed within the PXE driver and would be exposed by the API proposed in this patch, which will mislead users.

I'm blocking until Juno opens, at which point, I would like to land this immediately and start refactoring some driver info into node.instance_info."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2014-03-21 06:03:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

- check-tripleo-ironic-undercloud-precise http://logs.openstack.org/05/73005/14/check-tripleo/check-tripleo-ironic-undercloud-precise/87ee3d9 : FAILURE in 1h 11m 35s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 6623, 'date': '2014-05-29 12:44:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

I think these thoughts might have appeared too late (cuz there are 14 change-sets here) but that is just my opinion for the discussion.

Each driver has its own properties. Properties are implemented as a static set of items (which I think is right). However, to get the list of them, this implementation queries the conductor over RPC.

The fact, that driver properties do not change while the conductor is running makes it unreasonable to query it over the RPC on every request. I would rather read some driver's properties from the database.

Conductors store the information about drivers they have to the database. If we just extend that information and save more metadata about the drivers, we will be able to get rid of unnecessary RPC calls and improve the performance of this part of the API.

Again, this is just my opinion and I'm really sorry, if it causes you to redo the things after everything you did."}, {'account_id': 6623, 'date': '2014-05-29 12:45:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

I would like to add that the trend is to make the API asynchronous and the approach I described seems to be in line with it.'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2014-05-29 18:06:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Workflow-1

@Roman. Thx. No need to be sorry, better late than never :-)

Yes, querying over RPC seems like overkill. I think I rationalized it as being OK because it is geared for humans to issue the query, and I don't think they'd issue it that frequently. But one can never underestimate how/when it will be used. I'm not sure I like storing this information, esp the descriptions, in a database though. That seems like overkill too.

Setting this as work-in-progress while I mull over it, so others don't spend time reviewing something that will change."}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2014-06-16 22:58:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

I think it's highly likely this API will be consumed by automated systems.

While this was started in the middle of last cycle, making it async is indeed in line with other ongoing work. Even though I'd like to see this land, I am adding a -1 for that reason now. I like Roman's suggestion, and think it would be fairly easy to implement.

Conductor already publishes its list of drivers to the database when it comes online. We can extend that to include a list of the fields that each driver expects."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-16 22:58:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: -Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-02-12 17:33:52.000000000', 'message': 'Implement API to get driver properties

Implement GET /v1/drivers/<driver>/properties that returns two lists
with the names of the required properties and optional properties
of the specified driver. An invalid driver name results in an HTTP 400.

Eg: 'GET /v1/drivers/pxe_ipminative/properties' results in:
{"required":
    ["ipmi_address", "ipmi_password", "ipmi_username", "pxe_deploy_kernel",
     "pxe_deploy_ramdisk", "pxe_image_source", "pxe_root_gb"],
  "optional":
    ["pxe_deploy_key", "pxe_instance_name", "pxe_key_data", "pxe_swap_mb"]
}

Change-Id: Iab5bb1c86d8ff8e741167ea7fe55e4b266a3bf45
Closes-Bug: #1261915
'}, {'created': '2014-02-19 03:58:08.000000000', 'message': 'Implement API to get driver properties

Implement GET /v1/drivers/<driver>/properties that returns two lists
with the names of the required properties and optional properties
of the specified driver. An invalid driver name results in an HTTP 400.

Eg: 'GET /v1/drivers/pxe_ipminative/properties' results in:
{"required":
    ["ipmi_address", "ipmi_password", "ipmi_username", "pxe_deploy_kernel",
     "pxe_deploy_ramdisk", "pxe_image_source", "pxe_root_gb"],
  "optional":
    ["pxe_deploy_key", "pxe_instance_name", "pxe_key_data", "pxe_swap_mb"]
}

Change-Id: Iab5bb1c86d8ff8e741167ea7fe55e4b266a3bf45
Closes-Bug: #1261915
'}, {'created': '2014-02-25 02:45:08.000000000', 'message': 'Implement API to get driver properties

Implement GET /v1/drivers/<driver>/properties that returns a dictionary of
properties of the specified driver. Each entry in the dictionary is:
  key: name of the property
  value: a dictionary with these entries:
    'required': True if it is a required property; False otherwise.
    'description': description of the property.
An invalid driver name results in an HTTP 400.

Eg: 'GET /v1/drivers/pxe_ipminative/properties' returns:
{"pxe_deploy_ramdisk": {"required": true, "description": "UUID ..."},
 "pxe_image_source": {"required": true, "description": "UUID ..."},
 "pxe_root_gb": {"required": true, "description": "size (in GB) of ..."},
 "ipmi_username": {"required": true, "description": "IPMI username"},
 "ipmi_address": {"required": true, "description": "IP of the node's BMC"},
 "ipmi_password": {"required": true, "description": "IPMI password"},
 "pxe_deploy_kernel": {"required": true, "description": "UUID ..."},
 "pxe_swap_mb": {"required": false, "description": "size (in MB) of ..."}
}

Change-Id: Iab5bb1c86d8ff8e741167ea7fe55e4b266a3bf45
Closes-Bug: #1261915
'}, {'created': '2014-02-25 14:38:10.000000000', 'message': 'Implement API to get driver properties

'}, {'created': '2014-04-29 15:42:47.000000000', 'message': 'Implement API to get driver properties

Implement GET /v1/drivers/<driver>/properties that returns a dictionary of
properties of the specified driver. Each entry in the dictionary is:
  key: name of the property
  value: a dictionary with these entries:
    'required': True if it is a required property; False otherwise.
    'description': description of the property.
An invalid driver name results in an HTTP 404.

Eg: 'GET /v1/drivers/pxe_ipminative/properties' returns:
{"pxe_deploy_ramdisk": {"required": true, "description": "UUID ..."},
 "pxe_image_source": {"required": true, "description": "UUID ..."},
 "pxe_root_gb": {"required": true, "description": "size (in GB) of ..."},
 "ipmi_username": {"required": true, "description": "IPMI username"},
 "ipmi_address": {"required": true, "description": "IP of the node's BMC"},
 "ipmi_password": {"required": true, "description": "IPMI password"},
 "pxe_deploy_kernel": {"required": true, "description": "UUID ..."},
 "pxe_swap_mb": {"required": false, "description": "size (in MB) of ..."}
 ...
}

The driver interfaces (DeployInterface, PowerInterface, ...) have a
new get_properties() method that returns a tuple (required, optional),
where required and optional are dictionaries (key is the property name;
value is a description of the property) of required and optional properties,
respectively.

Change-Id: Iab5bb1c86d8ff8e741167ea7fe55e4b266a3bf45
Closes-Bug: #1261915

commit_message:
Implement API to get driver properties

Implement GET /v1/drivers/<driver>/properties that returns a dictionary of
properties of the specified driver. Each entry in the dictionary is:
  key: name of the property
  value: a dictionary with these entries:
    'required': True if it is a required property; False otherwise.
    'description': description of the property.
An invalid driver name results in an HTTP 404.

Eg: 'GET /v1/drivers/pxe_ipminative/properties' returns:
{"pxe_deploy_ramdisk": {"required": true, "description": "UUID ..."},
 "pxe_image_source": {"required": true, "description": "UUID ..."},
 "pxe_root_gb": {"required": true, "description": "size (in GiB) of ..."},
 "ipmi_username": {"required": true, "description": "IPMI username"},
 "ipmi_address": {"required": true, "description": "IP of the node's BMC"},
 "ipmi_password": {"required": true, "description": "IPMI password"},
 "pxe_deploy_kernel": {"required": true, "description": "UUID ..."},
 "pxe_swap_mb": {"required": false, "description": "size (in MiB) of ..."}
 ...
}

The driver interfaces (DeployInterface, PowerInterface, ...) have a
new get_properties() method that returns a tuple (required, optional),
where required and optional are dictionaries (key is the property name;
value is a description of the property) of required and optional properties,
respectively.

Change-Id: Iab5bb1c86d8ff8e741167ea7fe55e4b266a3bf45
Closes-Bug: #1261915

commit_message:
allow a user's default tenant to be modified

This patch adds a tenant argument to the user-update command making it
possible to change the default tenant for a user in V2

Change-Id: I43c73ab351605b868ef1c5f033eb52641c523270
Closes-Bug: #1177224

commit_message:
Fix gate missing test-requirement httpretty

Not quite sure how the gate got broken but I'm guessing it's
because we are not pining the python-novaclient and they added
this requirement which broke us.

Change-Id: I85c966de7d55f9628e9ce0867fd4f363b5ed2c91
Closes-bug: 1341929

commit_message:
Revert "Reuse exceptions from Oslo"

This reverts commit 3bde9c3f427110dae3480644752f49b79ac66ec5.

This change is a part of a series that is not backwards compatible.
It broke applications using the client library.

Change-Id: Id01a0a0feb601539d3855f445ebaf6a3cc000610
Partial-Bug: #1340596

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-05-20 12:36:31.000000000', 'message': "TESTING ONLY: Get some debug info about mounted FS

There are nondeterministic failures on neutron grenade job caused by
loop device in use while mounted filesystem isn't in /proc/mounts. This
patch should output some information on what process is still accessing
the device.

Change-Id: I130123b5e516084eb22886504fe0648ae83b7300
"}, {'created': '2014-05-20 13:21:02.000000000', 'message': "TESTING ONLY: Get some debug info about mounted FS

There are nondeterministic failures on neutron grenade job caused by
loop device in use while mounted filesystem isn't in /proc/mounts. This
patch should output some information on what process is still accessing
the device.

Change-Id: I130123b5e516084eb22886504fe0648ae83b7300
"}, {'created': '2014-05-20 14:15:16.000000000', 'message': "TESTING ONLY: Get some debug info about mounted FS

There are nondeterministic failures on neutron grenade job caused by
loop device in use while mounted filesystem isn't in /proc/mounts. This
patch should output some information on what process is still accessing
the device.

Change-Id: I130123b5e516084eb22886504fe0648ae83b7300
"}]
commit_message:
TESTING ONLY: Get some debug info about mounted FS

There are nondeterministic failures on neutron grenade job caused by
loop device in use while mounted filesystem isn't in /proc/mounts. This
patch should output some information on what process is still accessing
the device.

Change-Id: I130123b5e516084eb22886504fe0648ae83b7300

[{'created': '2014-07-10 13:06:24.000000000', 'message': "Detail 'other' directories in the README

Elements can use arbitrary directories in diskimage-builder, so
ensure we make mention of that, and give an example of such a use.

Change-Id: I0e57ece82629c1be4e0f9612c2a565802b222687
"}]
commit_message:
Detail 'other' directories in the README

Elements can use arbitrary directories in diskimage-builder, so
ensure we make mention of that, and give an example of such a use.

Change-Id: I0e57ece82629c1be4e0f9612c2a565802b222687

commit_message:
Allow overwriting old images

The two duplicated functions, save_image and finish_image will move
an existing image out of the way if it exists, but it isn't
configurable. Check an environment variable is 0 before doing so.

Switch save_image to just calling finish_image, rather than
duplicating its code exactly.

Change-Id: I26a5a8fa4b6e853c9440bffab195b0bc3728be40

commit_message:
Test(recreate tables)

tables - list of all tables scheme
test - some functions
update_tables - list of table that has more that one migration
44dd66c4b46e_test_of_functions - just test how functions work
requirements.txt - to use get_unique_constraints in SQLAlchemy
inspector needs SQLAlchemy>=0.8.4

Change-Id: Ibf35a7f860a5eef82b4db79ea6acebde17f6862a

commit_message:
Properly kill running server after tests

- verify that server is up and running by http request,
  and not port scanning
- look for process pid when verification is done for server
- use lsof for server pid detection
- fix return from function, it should be either echoi $pid in function,
  or echo $?

Change-Id: I10b13eaec267dd7ccb779acc2d12200884074e1d
Closes-Bug: #1335847

commit_message:
memcached: use retrying rather than sleeping

That should allow better handling of retrying, sleep delays, etc.

Change-Id: I7658b4d5bacb0aef84a8c377a7e487327011b7ee

commit_message:
Use retrying instead of our custom code

This pulls in retrying that handles the retry logic better than ours
custom made one.

Change-Id: Iedf00e245702add4cf122ed39732378de44eb3db

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-06-05 21:02:17.000000000', 'message': "Set the volume access mode during volume attach

cinderclient supports an optional keyword argument named 'mode'
for volumes.attach(), which allows you to set the access mode of
a volume at attach time. The keyword argument is not passed in
by nova when it attaches a read-only volume, making the volume
access mode default to 'rw' instead of the desired 'ro'. This
patch finds the access mode of the volume and passes it to
cinderclient, so the correct access mode is used at attach
time.

Change-Id: Ib62f454292e60114f96debbad96c4a356dc32a21
Closes-Bug: #1307088
(cherry picked from commit de05c2994212e83eba3cedf2544cdc549d9f8184)
"}]
commit_message:
Set the volume access mode during volume attach

cinderclient supports an optional keyword argument named 'mode'
for volumes.attach(), which allows you to set the access mode of
a volume at attach time. The keyword argument is not passed in
by nova when it attaches a read-only volume, making the volume
access mode default to 'rw' instead of the desired 'ro'. This
patch finds the access mode of the volume and passes it to
cinderclient, so the correct access mode is used at attach
time.

Change-Id: Ib62f454292e60114f96debbad96c4a356dc32a21
Closes-Bug: #1307088
(cherry picked from commit de05c2994212e83eba3cedf2544cdc549d9f8184)

commit_message:
Fixes incorrect exchange lock in fake driver

The exchanges lock in the fake driver was being disregarded,
probably due to a typo.

Closes-Bug: #1342088
Change-Id: I45261fce501a867b9253112e1608b14ed5afea26

If worker have problem with AMQP connection it can sometimes
do not get acknowledgements for message(main task) instantly
and if worker disconect at this time, message will be requeued

commit_message:
Prevent to requeue main task (run same main task in parallel).

If worker have problem with AMQP connection it can sometimes
do not get acknowledgements for message(main task) instantly
and if worker disconect at this time, message will be requeued
and we get several working tasks running in parallel.

Change-Id: If038079e263feb811d019d08944ff1dacd11f30a
Closes-Bug: #1340704

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-14 23:25:51.000000000', 'message': 'Tolerant behavior in case of RabbitMQ connection problem

- do not requeue task if we have problem with RabbitMQ;
- prevent throttle if only one worker exist;
- more correct message about publishing report to Nailgun.

Notice: after this change Nailgun will not fail task if
Astute perform unexpected exit because we do not requeue
task. In this case we will again see dangling deploy
instead of incorrect error.

Special thanks to Evgeniy L for help.

Change-Id: Ic2e771a6133eb0f95e478417f30c1398647c2597
Closes-Bug: #1316761
(cherry picked from commit 55f9687e635ea3247aff23cae82f6b44b371cc3d)
'}]
commit_message:
Tolerant behavior in case of RabbitMQ connection problem

- do not requeue task if we have problem with RabbitMQ;
- prevent throttle if only one worker exist;
- more correct message about publishing report to Nailgun.

Notice: after this change Nailgun will not fail task if
Astute perform unexpected exit because we do not requeue
task. In this case we will again see dangling deploy
instead of incorrect error.

Special thanks to Evgeniy L for help.

Change-Id: Ic2e771a6133eb0f95e478417f30c1398647c2597
Closes-Bug: #1316761
(cherry picked from commit 55f9687e635ea3247aff23cae82f6b44b371cc3d)

commit_message:
Enable usage of config-drive for file injection

* Some nova deployments allow the use of config-drive to do file
  injection.  Trove, when booting an instance, needs to send this
  to Nova when config-drive is to be used.

Closes-Bug: #1329535

Change-Id: I950b93a32f6c7224f30cf930e5f95710c07cbc26

commit_message:
Implement cinder client plugin

This moves the client creation code out of Clients._cinder() into
its own client plugin.

Cinder is a core project, and python-cinderclient is a dependency,
so the import is now mandatory (including the volume_backups import).

Change-Id: I6b937422cd8e20fa620a7e875ae8b4c61e8f9cf8

Locking added into flush db method

commit_message:
setup logger name of NeutronCommand automatically

It is a common pattern to add
class XXXCommand(NeutronCommand):
    log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + '.<command name>').
So introduce a metaclass to do that automatically in order to simplify
the code a bit.

Change-Id: I7febdcd806eb2da51781a5866cc5fac5422b1721
